description:
This place drew us in like a magnet, the crispy chicken Sammie's kicked ass! The pickled vegetables were fantastic. Not overpowering, perfect.

Fast polite service, not over service, (hic) if you're in the area, stop in here.
author: Bradley B.

description:
I had a WOW experience at Myriad Gastropub. 

Firstly, I'd like to define Gastropub: "a pub that specializes in serving high-quality food." Before I went to Myriad, any restaurant with "pub" in its name was basically a bar with mediocre food to me. However, the food was excellent at Myriad (it is on the Michelin Recommended list).

We had booked a reservation for a Friday night date night and arrived by BART.  They seated us immediately and we took a look at the menu. The menu was quite diverse: "globally inspired." 

The first glance took me by surprise because there was a tomato soup (I love tomato soups) that I hadn't noticed on the online menu. We ordered this immediately and it came out promptly and perfectly. It was so good. It was probably one of the best tomato soups I've every had and it was a little unique because it had a salsa drizzle on it. 

For my meal, I ordered the farm toast. As a big fan of burrata, I was extremely please with this option as well. The only problem was that the toast was so thick that I had trouble fitting it in my mouth without pouring all the tomatoes on the table. My friend ordered the hanger steak, which came with some roasted potatoes with cotija cheese which was delicious as well. We also tried the steak fries (I usually love fat fries), and they were good but not great. I think I tend to like them a little less crispy and more soft. 

Service was great, except for that we waited for the check for a long time. It was a little pricey, but our meal was great. We will definitely be back.
author: Kristin A.

description:
Pros: ambiance, service, decent food
Cons: $$$

Came here for a catch-up dinner with a good friend. The restaurant is fun to look at and hang out in, there's a bar/restaurant set up in one room and a restaurant-only space in the next room. You'll be most comfortable here in groups of 2-6, preferably 4 max. 

Food is not especially memorable aside from the fact that it's done reasonably well with good service. Expect the usual bar fare with a bit more fancy ingredients. Beer, wine list are extensive and the cocktails seem interesting. 

The biggest downside frankly is the price of entry here. Cocktails are at a minimum $12 and the cheapest beer is a Modelo for $6. My hamburger was $17 and well, it tasted like a hamburger. My eyebrows definitely went up when I saw that a salad was almost $20. I think to command such prices you either have to have a knockout atmosphere or food and I don't really think this place has either... instead it seems to be trying to cater to a crowd who after overpaying to rent an apartment in the area, are now looking for a cleaner place to eat than what this part of the Mission can usually offer. Not sure if that's a sustainable formula for success.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I had a great dinner here with my bf on a Saturday night. We made reservations through Yelp about an hour beforehand and it worked out perfectly. Service was friendly and prompt, and food was delicious. I highly recommend the steak fries and pasta with pork cheeks! They don't have a liquor license though, so don't expect liquor cocktails. They have drinks made with soju though.

Steak fries: steaming hot thick, long potato wedges! Soooo good. (5/5)

Pasta with pork cheeks: get this!! This was my favorite of the night. I usually don't eat pasta either, but this really blew my mind. Great flavor and the pork was so tender. (5/5)

Spicy shrimp: shrimp were plump and bursted with flavor. I wasn't a big fan of the grits though-- it had too much of a buttermilk taste to it, but my bf liked it. He polished off this dish. He would rate it a (4/5), and I'd say (3.5/5).

Deviled eggs: good, and worth trying. I like the onions on top! (4/5) With the Yelp check-in, we get free deviled eggs-- they usually give out just one per person (4 max for a table), but the waitress kindly gave us 4 for the 2 of us. Props on that!

Pickles: good assortment of veggies. Nice and sour (4/5)

Overall we had a great experience and would be willing to come back.
author: Christina W.

description:
Came here after a particularly boozy yet wholesome day in Dolores Park. Me and a crew of fashionable Asians made our way to Myriad Gastropub, feeling it would be appropriate as I've already had myriad experiences that day. 

We sat down pretty much immediately, and my eye went to the flank parpardelle pasta. I ordered that ish because my stomach was practically eating itself. Everybody else ordered a burger, but I was feeling noncomformity that day. 

The pasta was 7/10 solid, and I scarfed this down in approximately five minutes. Level of hunger at that moment: Pitchfork writer as they're about to tear down an Ed Sheeran album. 

Very juicy, had a slight alcoholic taste to it -- I'm sure some wine was used in the cooking. Not that I needed more wine that day but, hahahaa. My friend had ordered like $11-12 sliders and they were the size of a baby's foot. The rest of my Dolo squad said the burgers were either nothing special or alright. Docking this place down for the price and for the apparently non-special burgers.
author: Celena C.

description:
No hate at all for this place so don't let the 3 star fool you. It was ok in my books. The menu was thoughtful and full of options for our group who had quite a few dietary restrictions. And the cocktail menu, while not having my favourite drink (old fashioned) had many specialty options I'd certainly go back to try. 

For appetizers I got to try the thai chicken wings, and the fried chicken Sammie's (sliders). Both of these were excellent and I could have been satisfied eating these all night. Highly recommended both. 

For my main I split the hanger steak and the pork cheek parpadelle. The parpadelle was outstanding, and I'm super picky about my pasta choices. The beef and mushrooms were so tender and the pasta was cooked to a perfect al dente. 

The hanger steak on the other hand was disappointing. A tiny portion that although requested medium rare was medium or more. It came pre slices which likely added to the dryness of the dish. The patatas bravas were good but dominated the plate. Even my coworkers who ordered the same dish had the same feedback on the dish overall. 

For dessert I had the zeppole. Which were tiny deep fried balls with two dipping options. These were OK but not how my italian family traditionally would eat them. 

We were a large group and overall we felt the service was a little lacking and eventually were made to feel like we might have been a burden. This area could have used some improvement. 

It wasn't a cheap meal either for our group. 

I'd come back for apps and drinks but would seek out other options for dinner in future

Eatcrest Out.
author: Kris U.

description:
Came here with a large group of girlfriends on a Friday evening. 

Food - delicious - pleasantly surprised. Nice eclectic menu. We ordered (ordered in my preference in the realm of deliciousness), the below. All these dishes were easily shareable !

Pappardelle pasta with pork Cheeks (large plate): my favorite. Order if your absolutely love mushrooms. The brown beech mushrooms and kale combine for the most earthy fresh flavor. Mixed with fresh wide noodles and cheese...... amazing! they can make this with or without the pork cheeks if you prefer vegetarian!

Crispy Fried chicken sammies (small plate): SO good. The perfect slider type bite. Chicken was crunchy, non greasy, tender. Good ratio of bun/chicken/slaw. Ate two myself and wanted more.

Thai wings: whatever these are marinated in, I wish they came in an entire basket. Reminded me a bit of some awesome wings I had in Portland (pok pok)! But I liked these more, less salty, more sweet. And can't beat the fact that these are free range wings! Let's those wings flyyyyy... over here.

Tres Leches butter almond cake (dessert) almonds + tres Leches..... nutty milky buttery goodness. I still dream of it.

Salmon with Manila clams and chorizo (large plate): dish of scrumptious seafood. Chorizo added a nice "pop" against the seafood flavors. Fresh flavors, everything on the plate was well paired.

Veggie skillet (large plate): curried veggies, the curry adds a lot of flavor to this and this was a hit for both vegetarians and non vegetarians at the table- hearty veggie dish that was not spicy.

Mpg spiced potato chips (snacks): good munchie while waiting for the friends. Spicy kettle style chips. Small portion for the price.

Sorbet (dessert): chocolate and mango? Sorbet scoops with two cookies on top. Both were spiced- I didn't enjoy the spice in my dessert but others did.

Market salad: eh pretty bland. See pictures :)

Drinks - delicious! Looks like they lack a full alcohol license but great beer selection and the mixed drinks were tasty (I had the Freshie)!

Service- great! Our server was attentive - almost overly attentive and a little pushy but I'll take that over neglectful service.

Pricey place, but has good atmosphere, noms (food), and great place for groups big and small

Parking is difficult.

Note that if the sun is out and you're here during sunset - it can get extremely WARM by the windows... aka sweaty... so plan accordingly :)
author: Karen H.

description: Came here to celebrate my birthday, came on a Wednesday evening and was immediately seated for a table of two at around 6 p.m. We had come 5 minutes before happy hour ended so we ended up ordering happy hour at our table and immediately proceeded to dinner. Overall the food was quite tasty, service was excellent, and the food came out promptly. I think the highlight of the night was the pork cheeks. I think it's worth a try if you are in town.
author: Ben C.

description:
Unimpressive. Myriad came to us highly recommended from a trusted, super awesome colleague in the area who knows great food. I had high hopes, but unfortunately Myriad somehow just missed the mark in a major way. 
For starters, the hospitality was lacking. Our waitress was cold and it felt like we were troubling her to ask questions or place our order. Our group of 10 enjoyed plenty of bottles of malbec in their cozy, intimate ambiance which was easily the highlight of the night. 

The food itself, not so much. It was bland and missed the mark. I got the popped elote: buttered popcorn with chili, lime, cotija cheese. Although it sounded mouthwatering and delicious, it was essentially unseasoned, unfilling popcorn. Not a true Mexican-style elote flavor in sight. The veggie skillet I got as an entree was even more off the mark. Thai curry vegetable stew, bulgar pilaf, cilantro, lime, basil... With all those ingredients, you'd expect salt at a minimum and a little heat flavor from the curry. I don't know what I ate, but it wasn't any curry flavor that I regularly know and thoroughly appreciate. Maybe it was an off day, but I left hungry and disappointed with the entire experience.
author: Helina G.

description: Cool spot, great drinks and good food. We started with the complimentary deviled eggs (it benefits to have the help app) which were the perfect bite. We then split the grilled peaches with goat cheese mousse. This dish was really good at first bite but after bite 3 the smoke from the grilled peach was a bit overwhelming and my pallat was searching for something to cleanse it. It would have benefited from a fresh herb dressing- like a basil vinaigrette just to offer a bit of relief. The pickled vegetables were good, but expensive for what you got. And the burger was standard. All and all a good meal.
author: Allie P.

description:
Food here is so good! It's all prepared very well, but this is a fancy restaurant so the prices are a little high for how much food you get! So if you're super hungry just know it will be a little expensive dinner! 

I definitely recommend the lamb sandwich and the Thai wings. The meat at this restaurant is very good. The service was also fantastic and the ambiance of this restaurant was great. This is a great place for a nice fancy dinner out in the city.
author: Rithika V.

description:
Our large group stumbled in around 8:45PM for drinks, snacks and dinner -- depending on what people had consumed ahead of time.  Because I checked in on Yelp, we got a free deviled egg!!

I drank a glass of Oakland United black lager, which I recommend very highly, and ordered the cochinita pibil (braised mayan pork) off the "large plates" section of the dinner menu.  The pork was quite good -- both our server and the dude who brought my plate to the table told me that I had selected the best thing on the menu.

The main point is that we got to hang out with each other -- Myriad Gastropub did a fine job in greeting us, making us feel comfortable and serving us good food and drink.  My three-star rating reflects the reality that our evening went by without a hitch without anyone thinking too hard about what was on our plates and in our glasses.
author: Kenneth R.

description:
I'm surprised this is a '3' for me. I came here expecting a transcendent experience. It was recommended by someone who has wonderful taste and many friends/colleagues had told me that they'd enjoyed their time here as well. I suppose it just wasn't meant to be.

From the time my group arrived until the time we left, things just felt... askew. I have been in restaurants (and part of groups) that were rowdy, boisterous and embarrassing. This wasn't such a time. Truth be told, I wondered why we (the group) were so subdued and thought, 'everyone must be really tired.' So, bad behavior can't have been the reason that our server could - and would - not with us. It's awkward to dine in a place where you're not wanted. This wasn't a hateful situation (I would have left; no one's got time for that) but body language cues and the like let us know that she was not the one and we were not the customers.

Unfortunately, the menu was not the isht. Everything sounded wonderful but the execution - to my tastes - didn't match the expectation. There was, however, one exception. I checked in at the beginning of the meal for the complimentary deviled egg. I need to eat gluten-free so mine was a bit doctored from the usual variety but it was a fine deviled egg. It was a nice amuse bouche to begin the evening. As I am wont to do, I also started with a cocktail. Because I'm fancy (and Brasilian), I ordered the Obrigado. I was happy to see that it was a cocktail of substance. This was no 'two sips and you're done' drink. The bright citrus profile was a bit blunted by the overall sweetness (and I don't shy from sweet) but I appreciated the value. To accompany my beverage, I decided on the shrimp & grits. I'm a Southerner. I knew better. I'll leave it at that. Changing up for dinner, I went red wine and big plate. Both were misses. My tempranillo was bitter and acidic. I don't know whether it was the particular wine or whether the bottle was compromised in some sort of way. The rest of the table was going to town on another red so I think it was just my bad luck.* The cochinita, too, was a let down. First, there was a mini issue with me requesting gluten-free tortillas. The response was, 'I'll have to check.' Aren't we in SF? Aren't corn tortillas more plentiful than rain water? What is the issue? The dish itself was rather basic. It presented as stewed pork in a semi-spicy sauce with sparsely-apportioned onions and jalapenos. I needed to shred the pork with a fork to make it suitable for the tortillas. It was fine. For $24 I felt I had to work for it, but it was fine.

Because I am a fat man, I wanted dessert. Suspicious that my problematic belly would keep me away from the sweet stuff, I resigned myself to a dessert of wine. Ahh, what's this? Mexican chocolate sorbet? Done. I ordered it and it came complete with flour-based cookies (not part of the description). I asked if I could get the sorbet sans cookies. One sigh later and it was done. Sorry.

*I joined in on that party.
author: Johnny T.

description:
My friend and I stumbled upon Myriad after looking for somewhere to eat where there wasn't a ridiculous wait at 8:30 pm on a Friday. We were not disappointed at all in our choice. We sat at the bar and made chitchat with the nice bartender Paige, she was a hoot. 

Anyway, we decided to order a few small plates and then just share everything since we weren't starving just hungry. We ordered the wedge salad, crispy fried chicken sammies, spiced shrimp, and farm toast. Also, if you check-in you will get a free deviled egg and it is pretty tasty. I really really enjoyed everything we ordered but definitely my favorite had to be the spiced shrimp, the shrimps were perfectly cooked and they come served over delicious grits, definitely took me back to my Texas days. The farm toast was a close second, it was the perfect combination of sweet and salty with the goat cheese and the compote they put on top of the cheese. Everything was really good, I would actually go back and order the same things minus maybe the wedge salad just because I'd rather get something less healthy, ha. They have a good selection of wine and beer also. 

Overall, it was a super great experience and the food was on point. I would definitely go there again (planned) and not just because it was a random stop.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Excellent, creative plates of food are what you'll find at Myriad Gastropub in the Mission! This modern restaurant serves dishes with inspired flavors from all around the world, and the service is so friendly to boot! Coming in for dinner, we started with the popped elote, the deviled eggs, and a seasonal market salad, but the real standout to me were the main dishes.

First, the spiced shrimp over grits were plump and juicy, and they contrasted so nicely with the grainy yet thick and creamy grits--eating the corn mixture was like eating a savory, delicious pudding! The salmon was grilled perfectly and was served with manila clams, cubes of chorizo, and corn, over a puree of parsnip and celery root. The textural contrast of the puree, the sweetness of the corn, and the smokiness of the chorizo collided perfectly. I was also a huge fan of the pappardelle pasta, which had an amazing texture and was served with tender pork cheeks and mushrooms. The crispy Brussels sprouts with hazelnuts made for a fantastic side, but my favorite dish of all was the lamb sandwich, which consisted of thin slices of lamb roast served in a crispy round bun with Moroccan tomato jam, feta, cilantro aioli, and a delicious arugula salad on the side. What an explosion of flavor!

Yes, the food and service here are fantastic and creative--do be prepared to pay SF prices, but I do wonder what other interesting plates this place can turn out!
author: David K.

description:
I ate here with a crew of 10, 8 of whom have dietary restrictions. I'm fairly certain the server was through with us 10 minutes in, but honestly, fair enough. Allergies, requests and a rowdy group on a busy night are a lot to handle. 

I am one of the lucky and less thoughtful individuals in the group, so I had a little bit of everything. Delicious California red wine, deviled eggs, a medium rare steak and some of the pork paparadelle. I was into everything I had.  

If you drop in, don't forget to check in on Yelp. Get your free deviled egg, angel.
author: Evelyn A.

description: Good portion and delicious. Went with the recommended salmon option. It was cooked to perfection. Could have used a little more spice on the beans. The fries are must have
author: Sambida P.

description:
Spectacular meal and sips! 
We had the delish deviled eggs, grilled Frog Hollow peaches, farm toast, and pink bubbly! We will definitely be back...Cheers!
author: Debra T.

description:
Great variety of food, flavors, textures, and drinks!  It is affordable to nearly all budgets and whatever you choose you can taste the difference and care in.  I have visited several times and even dishes I might normally avoid, such as the "veggie skillet" were incredibly delicious and I'd order again without hesitation.

The atmosphere is also nice, encouraging conversation and being able to share food.  

This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco and turned me onto gastropubs in general.  I'd absolutely recommend a visit!
author: John B.

description: Layers of great flavors-a shoutout to the worlds palette-what a unique fun place.  Thanks for a wonderful Variation of plates served by a professional friendly and attentive waiter.  Loved our experience.  All dishes we chose we enjoyed -beverages were great!  Will be back.  Thanks Check Please for highlighting this neighborhood place.  Only negative-it was my birthday and they charged us for the dessert!
author: Nancy M.

description:
Friendly and attentive service, cool venue, but the food is just too expensive for what it is. Our party of 10 tried an array of the appetizers - deviled eggs, edamame, spiced potato chips, market salad, potted chicken liver & mousse, spiced shrimp (like shrimp and grits), thai wings, grilled ciabbata bread with burrata, and brussels sprouts, and it was all decent but not spectacular. I can't justify $15 for a slice of bread with burrata and some tough half twigs of asparagus when it's gone in 3 underwhelming bites. I can't speak to the others in my party who got the lamb sandwich, burger, or steak.

And FYI, there are no free refills on the soda or lemonade. I guess it's their version of a sugar tax? Fat tax? I didn't get the drinks, so it didn't bother me, but just a bit surprising. They also charged an additional $1 for extra crostini to finish off the pot of chicken liver mousse. I mean, come on . . . there wasn't enough crostini unless we laid a 2-inch brick of mousse on each. and that's not enjoyable. 

General advice for the restaurant would be not to scrimp so much on the little things . . .  y'all are, after all, making a killing on things like an ol' $16 burger and $30 for 4 (literal) scraps of grilled steak.
author: Christina S.

description:
We came here for the first time a couple of weekends ago for brunch since we had a Gilt City deal.

The service was great, our waitress was very helpful when it came to recommendations and what to order given portion sizes.

With that said, my partner got an iced coffee (which he really liked), biscuits, and half order of French toast. The French toast was huge! The biscuits though are what made his heart jump because of the texture and the side of honey butter.

With my gluten free diet, I got the loaded fries (to share) and the grits entree. The fries were delicious! The grits were good.. I did think it was a tad bit salty, but I really loved the corn paired with it. I didn't love the squash that came with it.

For dessert we got sorbet... mango and kaffir lime. It good, but not great.. especially for $7.
author: Gita r.

description:
Everything we got was really good, but like any other gastropub, the portions are small and very expensive. I came with a friend on a Friday for lunch and there was barely anyone in the restaurant. 

We ordered:
* Popped elote: it was really just popcorn...(not worth the price) It wasn't as crunchy as I would hope. 
* Brussel sprouts: it was REALLY GOOD!! I couldn't stop eating it! It was very flavorful and the macadamia nuts were a really nice touch as it gave the dish more of a crunch. 
* Crispy chicken sammies : These were really good as well, but they were tinyyyy! The fried chicken is really crispy and the sauce was great as well. (p.s. it's fried in canola oil, so don't worry for those who are allergic to peanuts!)
* Deviled eggs: received the deviled eggs for free with check-in (one per person, so don't forget to check-in) It was really good as well. They were very different from your typical deviled eggs.
author: Jamie N.

description:
Outstanding food!!! Dogs are welcome! We were desperately looking for a restaurant with drinks, good food and a place to bring our friendly dog. We were greeted at the door right away and told we could take a seat inside with our pooch. Hallelujah! Our feet thanked them. 

Now to the real good stuff. The menu sounded scrumptious. With $5 mimosas we couldn't have found a better spot. Friendly staff and high quality ingredients. 

We will return!
author: Corrina Q.

description:
I saw this place being raved about on Check Please.  When I got there I realized I had been there before (but had not written a review) - in fact I think we had the same exact seats.

TIP - you get a free deviled egg with Yelp check in (EACH yelp check in)

We started with the Korean chicken wings and the elote popcorn (which was a rip off for less than 2 cups of popcorn, good thing I got that free egg!)  For entrées we split the ginger carrot soup - good - but I could make it at home and the pappardelle pasta with the beef cheeks - Very good, but could have been hotter.

The highlight was dessert, the zeppoli (Italian beignets) with 2 incredibly delectable sauces a chai custard and a bourbon caramel. Only 4 of them though, I wish it has been 6.
author: Amy W.

description:
Horrible place. Please don't come.

Hopefully that scared off some people because Myriad has become my biggest SF secret. I really really really don't want you people to know. 

Sunday brunch? No line here and the food is bomb! Dinner date? The price is right and the drinks are awesome! The decor is hip and cozy enough for a tinder date (or whatever app the kids use these days). New Year's Eve? Literally the only place in SF that doesn't have a stupidly expensive prix fixe tasting menu. Yep that's where I'm going for my very last meal of 2017 and I can't wait to stuff my face there tomorrow!

Love the popped elote (fancy popcorn that even my I-like-my-popcorn-plain boyfriend enjoy), zeppole, literally every single brunch plate because yes I've tried them all and they all hit the spot, mission Statement the drink, cochinita pibil, and that pot I' chicken liver mousse. Note that I tried very damn hard not listing every item from the menu.

Now that you know, keep the top secret hush hush. ;)
author: Nana L.

description:
I came to myriad with a few friends and we all loved this place! Even though it was dinner time, it was not too packed so we were seated quite fast. The service we received was super great. The servers were really attentive and really nice.

FOOD: 
I ate the deviled egg (free with check in), braised pork cheek pappardelle pasta, and chicken liver mousse. 

- I checked in and received the free deviled egg, and it was delicious! Perfectly creamy and packed with pickled flavor. 

- The braised pork pappardelle pasta as quite tasty. The pork was very flavorful and blended well with the peas. I asked for Parmesan as well and it really accentuated all the flavors. 

- the chicken liver mousse was by FAR the BEST item I ordered. The onions blended so well with the mousse, and had such a rich taste. I would come back solely for that chicken mousse.

Would definitely come back to eat here! It is a bit higher in price point but totally worth it!
author: Alice L.

description:
What a fun spot with an amazing menu! We had a movie last night at 7pm but took BART in early to explore and walk around a bit when we stumbled into Myriad. 

A welcoming smile and an open table greeted us upon entry. We were seated after our kind hostess checked availability as many had reservations. We were seated and offered menus and drinks. A great happy hour menu was available. I tried the Persephone's on Fire which was fabulous and garnished with a jalapeño and a glass rimmed with ancho chili. This Texan approves! It was closest thing to my nostalgic Mexican martini I've had since relocating from Austin. 

I cannot wait to come back sans my boyfriend's brother for a nice meal as their menu really had me considering if I wanted to eat at our movie! The cochinita pibil really caught my eye... 

Thank you, Myriad!
author: Ashley L.

description:
I wish I could give this place more stars! We had such a great experience from the delicious food to the atmosphere and the staff were very friendly. The smell of the restaurant was initially what brought us in :) I will definitely be back! 
I highly recommend getting the deviled eggs and the chicken liver mousse crostinis to start. We ordered the ginger carrot soup and pappardelle pasta as our main dish which were also exceptional. I will be recommending this place to everyone!
author: Kristina C.

description:
I LOVE this place! Ive been here on 2 separate occasions and I will surely be back again!
Its a hidden gem in the Mission.
I made a reservation for a large party (6 or more you have to call the restaurant directly and hold with a card) and the service was stellar. They had 2 of their amazing wait staff check on us periodically and serving both sides of the table. 
The food is DELISH! Great selection and theres something for everyone with vegetarian options as well. 
*Tip: We got some free deviled eggs for checking in on YELP so be sure to see what they're offering when you go and enjoy!
author: Marcia B.

description:
Today I had a forest gump moment.. I got on my bicycle and began to ride until I got hungry. Miles later I found myself craving a pulled pork burger. Finding myself in the mission I felt like my chances were low to find what I was looking for, I stopped for a moment, looked up and there it was.. Myriad Gastropub.. I looked at the menu and it had just what I was looking for.. The pulled pork sandwich.. 

Now lemme tell you.. I'm from Texas and have worked for some of the best bbq spots in the world. But today the pulled pork burger that I had was one of the best pulled pork burgers I've ever had. This place is seriously awesome. Great atmosphere, AMAZING food, and great hospitality. I look forward to bringing my girlfriend back here for a date this Sunday.
author: Joe P.

description: Decent food, but nothing mind-blowing
author: Nihar P.

description:
My wife and I stumbled into this place the other night after leaving the San Francisco Burning Man Decompression. We walked in dressed for the playa and were greeted warmly by the staff despite being way over (crazy) dressed... Once we started looking over the menu we realized this was going to be a treat!

   First I noticed the great local draft beer selection so I ordered up a pint of the Oktoberfest from Triple Voodoo brewing, it hit the spot! My wife opted for some bubbles. They also have a full bar offering craft cocktails.

   It was late (almost 11pm) and we were in the mood for munchies so we attacked the snacks and small plates sections of the menu. A check in from Yelp got me a deviled egg to start off, it was ready in what seemed like seconds. It was my first bite and I knew I was going to be stoked with the rest of the meal. Instead of the standard mustard variant they served it up with salsa verde and crispy shallots, yum!

   Next we killed a plate of the chicken sammies. Although I really hate the name "sammies" (probably because of a coworker with the same name), these were AWESOME! Perfectly fried little chicken bites were crispy but juicy, served on soft rolls with sweet chipotle mayo, slaw, and pickled veggies for extra crunch. So good!

   The Thai wings were next, again perfectly fried crisp and juicy in the middle. There were some jalapenos for heat, cilantro and mint for fresh, and fish sauce to take it to the next level. Hard to describe how good these were, you've just got to try them for yourself.

   After all that we asked for a recommendation and they brought us the shrimp and grits. I personally love shrimp and grits and these knocked it out of the park! The shrimp was perfectly cooked and seasoned to perfection. The grits were super creamy with just the right amount of corn texture and drowning in a buttery alborino sauce. A great end to a perfect snack stop.

   I'm not in the city often but this place is worth visiting again next time I'm in town. You should definitely give them a try!
author: Mark F.

description: The bites are just that - bite size plates. We bought a number of bites and they actually were so rich and varied in flavor that we were all full before our own items arrived! We had the olives which were rich in orange peel and pepper. OMG to die! The french beans with chili which tasted like butter and spice. Amazing! The toast with buratta - it was cold, didnt expect that, but still delicious! The edimame with black soy sauce and sesame, which I quite literally could have gotten drunk on. We then ordered shrimp and grits - husband devoured the whole thing. Friend got the pork which she couldn't finish. I had the tomato soup, which was delicious and I had a salad, which I couldn't finish. Don't forget to try to housemade ginger beer. Doesn't pack a punch, but has a nice bite.
author: Roxie B.

description:
Highly underwhelming. We ordered the hanger steak as a shared entree and it literally came with 4 measly bites. No joke, it was probably a 6oz steak that was tough and flavorless. It came with one small green onion on top and about 2/3 of the plate was potatoes. 

Service was lacking and the restaurant was pretty dead.
author: Megan M.

description:
As a vegetarian, I did find the menu to be limiting; but the waiter was very accommodating as he gladly was open to preparing meat dishes with no meat.

I finally choose the off the menu vegetarian pappardelle pasta. It was tasty, but nothing out of box. And definitely not worth $23. 

Overall good expensive food, and great place to hangout with friends over drinks.
author: Kiran K.

description:
On the last day of our trip to San Francisco we intentionally got a little later flight in order to A). not be rushed and B). to have brunch. But after a very long Saturday and sleeping in a little bit, we didn't have all the time in the world. Not to mention, so many brunch spots started a little later than we needed to. Out comes the Yelp app. For the most part, I relied on recommendations from co-workers on the this work trip turned personal for the latter half of the week. But this time, it was up to the app that we all know and love. So I wanted a highly rated brunch, that wasn't light years away, and also took Yelp Reservations. Tap, swipe, tap... BOOM - Myriad Gastropub was our spot.

When we arrived, the place was a Ghost-town. Never a good sign. So the reservation part wasn't really necessary. But as I figured and later found out, we were definitely on the early side for brunch. So the lack of wait really helped us out. We started with coffee and mimosas. Not the best coffee ever and not the best mimosa ever... but they both served their purpose. We opted to start with the goat cheese and chive biscuits with house made preserves. They were absolutely outstanding. I don't usually like jelly/preserves on my biscuit... but these HAD to have this on there. The preserves were definitely big fruit chunks and went so well with these savory biscuits. I am SO glad there weren't more or they weren't bigger, because I would have ruined the rest of my meal.

By the time we were finishing, people were definitely starting to crowd in. The one downfall I have of this place is the quintessential booth wall with tables right next to one another. I know it is a great way to get some tables in. But I'm just personally not a fan to be in arm's length of someone else order of goat cheese and chive biscuits. But I digress.

For my entree, I went with the pork hash with a nice, runny fried egg on top. Now it is not difficult to make a pretty good hash. I mean you are taking mean and potatoes and letting yolky goodness run through it. But this one was particularly spectacular. And there was a ton of it. And for those that know me, I'm not one to leave something this tasty behind. But this was not a dish to be conquered on this day. Even with a few things I would change, the food and the service make it a no doubt five star.
author: Will B.

description: My daughter and I both had the burger. It was excellent! Flavorful beefy patty cooked perfectly to order (medium rare for me, medium for her). The buns were merely ok but the pickled onions really made the burger stand out. The dish was served with four huge and perfectly cooked potato wedges, a side of fancy ketchup and more house made pickles. They got right up to the edge of taking it too far with the pickles and then stopped. My kid devoured them. I devoured them. My 2yo son... really liked the bun and ate some burger, too. The place was surprisingly baby friendly considering how hip it looked. We'll be back next time we are in the area!
author: Andrew H.

description:
WARNING: NO MORE BONE MARROW.
The only let down of the night. Other than that this place was great. Best part I would say was the service, Sarah was amazing and proper. The food came out at the perfect pace. I had the salmon and it was cooked to perfection. Even better was my boyfriends lamb sandwich. The lamb was slow cooked and the least dry lamb I've ever tasted.
At one point I accidentally knocked my wine glass over and Sarah was there within seconds to clean it up and even refilled my glass free of charge.
Great place great service.
If the manager is reading this know that you got a top notch server working for you!
author: Ema D.

description: This place rocks! Izzy and Paige are awesome. I sat at the bar and started with a delicious glass of Burgundy that was recommended. Then I had the cheeseburger which was INSANE. One of the top burgers I've had in the city.  I topped it off with their tres leches dessert and I even said out loud "What is happening!" It was outstanding. I paired it with a Madeira and I was smiling ear to ear. Love this spot and can't wait to go back.
author: E. N.

description: Really delicious yet again. We were craving a burger so stopped in for the burger, lamb sandwich and burrata. Every bite was flavor packed, perfectly seasoned and juicy. The fries with the burger were on a whole other fry level! Our server Paige was an absolute gem. Coming back for the pappardelle next week!
author: Erin L.

description:
Awesome spot in the Mission with really good food and friendly service.  My wife and I came here for lunch during the work week and there weren't many people dining which made it an even easier and quicker experience.  Our server Ross was really nice and helpful. My wife had the chicken sammies with brussels sprouts and I had the lamb sandwich.  Everything was very tasty and the portions are generous.

Make sure to bring your appetite for some amazing food!
author: Blake B.

description:
Saw this place on a local TV show and had been meaning to try it so we finally made a reservation and headed on over to the Mission.

Service was great and I decided to go the app route with deviled eggs, some sliders and fries- which ended up being ginormous potato wedges. Everything was great and we'll definitely be back!
author: Leina K.

description:
Devil eggs, loaded steak fries, salmon dish. Devil eggs are yummy...there is something on them, so they don't taste like normal eggs.  Fries small plate with great sauce....possibly a light harbanero...delicious. Then there is the salmon....with the most different combo ever...chorizo, puree, claims & other mouth watering goodness. This dish is AMAZING perfection!!!!
Topped off by a house made ginger soda...this mealis a hit. Its not a quick process, but well worth every second.
Waitress also spot on....
Thank you...delicious meal!
author: Sharine d.

description: Went here today after world cup final to get some breakfast. They have a little tv so we could see the ceremony. I got the grass fed burger with an egg (best decision this month hands down) and my boyfriend got the Myriad Pork with eggs and potatoes. We loved our food and the service was great. It might seem a bit on the pricey side but I think it was worth it specially with the great service and the quality of the food. I'm excited to go try their drinks and snacks soon.
author: Atieh G.

description:
I went to have a drink with a friend on June 23rd.
We each had a beer, mine was flat and had almost no taste. The server named Michael charged an extra $20 for the tip. I had to call in to talk to the manager to credit me back the money. They did nothing beyond correcting their mistake and causing me such an unpleasant inconvenience. I wish I never went.
author: J S.

description: A very hipster type setting. The food is beyond delicious. You will most likely find a dish there that you may never heard of. The picked vegetables are a must.
author: Jerelle M.

description:
My sister and I were up in SF this past weekend for a quick getaway and we brought along her little dog Sheba for the ride. We researched a few places in SF that allowed dogs since she gets lonely and sad when we ditch her so I found this place in the Mission district.

We got there a little earlier than planned last night because we took the bus (let's just say the 49 bus was a wild ride) but they were able to seat us right away since they weren't too busy. It was quite chilly so we were nervous that we had sit outside (no heat lamps!) but Mark who greeted us and was our server said we could sit indoors as long as Sheba sat under our table and not out in the aisles. 

Mark was great, he petted Sheba and even brought her a water bowl- he was great with her.  

My sister and I started out with a cocktail- we got the Forbidden Lowball because it had ginger beer (our tummy was feeling a little out of sorts the wild bus ride) and the Cardamaro is apparently a digestif and it was helpful as well. The drink was pretty tasty and not too sweet, a nice balanced flavor.

We ordered the following:

deviled egg- a great starter, loved the shallots, it added texture to the already tasty egg!

potted chicken liver mousse- delish, it wasn't gamey and in the beginning I didn't like the port onion jam but as I kept eating it, I really enjoyed it with the mousse. We also at one point ran out of crostini but Mark got us more so we could finish the mousse (well we almost finished).

Pappardelle pasta with pork cheeks- We love this kind of pasta, we don't usually make this at home so it's always nice to order it when we're out. Plus I love pork cheeks, they are usually tender and delicious and this one was exactly that. I also loved the mushrooms and the light sauce on this pasta.

Grilled Hanger Steak with Patatas Bravas- probably my favorite dish of the night- the steak was cooked medium rare and was nice and juicy. The flavors were quite nice and I really liked the salsa verde. The best part in my book though was the patatas bravas- (I love papas bravas in general which is why I ordered this dish), the potatoes were nice and crispy and I loved the romesco sauce with the crunchy cotija cheese-it gave it a light salty flavor and a Mexican touch.

We skipped dessert because we were stuffed to the brim- otherwise I would have ordered the Zeppole. All in all, we had a great dinner there with equally great service. We were really happy to have found this restaurant where we could dine with our pup, looking forward to coming back again when we visit SF.
author: Helen P.

description:
Pretty average spot, probably will not return.

Came here for brunch on Saturday and it was practically dead. I made reservations on OpenTable but they were not necessary. The best part of the brunch was the complimentary deviled eggs that came with the Yelp Check-In. They were amazing, I could eat an entire meal of them. We actually contemplated ordering more but got a bunch of other dishes instead. Their deviled egg prices are very reasonable as well at $2 because we just so happened to have seen deviled eggs at two other places that same week and they were all $3/$4 for ONE deviled egg which is absurd. 

In addition to the eggs we got farm toast which is for sure not worth $13, cheesy grits, and the lamb sandwich. The menu was unimpressive and I had a hard time figuring out what to even order because everything seemed meh.
author: Tiffany V.

description: The deviled eggs were fine but the beer selection was very, very limited. I was hoping for more beer from independent breweries, and, in particular, beer from Bay Area small breweries.  Not much of that here.
author: Kevin H.

description: Loved the lamb sandwich - tender lamb, cherry tomatoes, caramelized red onions and mild feta, in a soft yet crispy bun - it was amazing! Definitely recommend :)
author: Privahini B.

description: Great food and great service. The food taste great and service was also superb! Although I am not a big fan of the atmosphere, I would say worth to visit if you are in the hood.
author: Sarah K.

description: A new favorite. Everything we had was delicious. Carrot ginger soup, pickles veggies, chicken Sammie, Thai wings.
author: Claire F.

description: What an awesome little gem in the busy town that hardly sleeps...San Francisco!  It may look underwhelming on the outside, but once you step inside you are greeted immediately by the wonderful hostess and seated right away (when it's not busy, of course).  The decor...absolutely artistic and pleasing in every which way.  Now to the food - SPECTACULAR.  The temp, the taste, the smell, the presentation...nothing I can say bad about this place.  Very friendly service and very attentive as well.  You will not be disappointed if you are looking for a nice night out with amazing food.  Definitely recommended!!
author: Da I.

description:
I discovered Myriad Gastropub in early January 2018, and have been back 6 times for brunch, happy hour, and dinner. 

This hole in the wall is perfect for someone who enjoys savory food in casual settings.  The wait staff are extremely friendly and professional.

My experiences have not been seamless, but the staff have always been professional in making it right.

Dishes I recommend:
- Lamb Sandwich - soft 'burger' like sandwich with flavorful pieces of thinly sliced lamb, accompanied with a bed of arugula (you can place it in the sandwich too!)
- Deviled Eggs (check in on Yelp for 1 egg / person!)
- Steak Fries - thick cuts of crispy-edged potato wedges
- Grits - a skillet of smooth grits with an assortment of savory vegetables
- French Toast - challah bread + buttery pecan topping.  Perfect if you want something sweet for brunch, and also perfect for sharing!

The only recommendation I have to the management team is to carry enough tea pot toppers for your tea pots.  Bringing out tea pots with small plates as substitutes for missing lids is not convenient for self-pouring :).  Not deducting stars for this review because the staff were friendly in explaining the situation in advance!

I have yet to say hello to the owner, but she is always busy behind the kitchen, ensuring each dish is perfect.
author: Colette C.

description:
I've been here a couple times for brunch and really enjoyed it! Tip - this is a great place to go when you want to make a reservation and wish to avoid long brunch lines elsewhere in SF. I was even able to get a table for a group of 15 the day of. 

The star brunch dishes according to the group are definitely the Shakshuka and the Lamb Burger (and we tried most of them). The Shakshuka is flavored so well and tasted authentic Turkish! It comes with this amazing chickpea toast of sorts that is seasoned well and perfect dipping material for the rich tomato sauce and the runny egg once you break it. The Lamb Burger is delectable! Very very well flavored, moist, and hearty, with the jam and cilantro mayo providing great flavor contrast.

Service was attentive and friendly! Our server kept our coffee mugs full and kept checking in to make sure everything was okay, which is usually difficult given a group of our size. We didn't order any drinks, but were informed that they do cocktails with soju and prosecco since they don't have a liquor license.

Highly recommend this great brunch spot! I'll be back to try their cocktails and their fried chicken sammies.
author: Sabina S.

description:
Really good place for brunch!

They had availability when we walked in but you can also make reservations, like we did for our group of 6.
I got the brunch order of French toast but my friends also tried the potato hash, egg sandwich and shakshuka. Each dish was devoured!
The French toast was good. The bacon bits didn't really taste like bacon anymore because they were in the syrup but they added a nice crunch. Portion was big but they also have half order if you want to share with the table.

No wait, great brunch food in the Mission, what more can you ask?
author: Coralie S.

description: Absolutely wonderful food! I had a delicious mimosa, deviled egg, burger, & potato wedges! Very impressed & would highly recommend!
author: Alexandra S.

description: I loved this place. The server were friendly. The food is unbelievable. We ordered some deviled eggs, chicken liver mousse, lamb sandwich, burgués, 3leches and the pot de creme.
author: Cristina V.

description:
This place was ok, not fantastic. I'd give 3.5 stars if I could. 

We ordered deviled eggs, chicken liver crostini, pickled vegetables, pappardelle with pork cheeks, and the cochinita pibil. 

The deviled eggs were good, but nothing to write home about. The chicken liver crostini was probably my favorite thing. The port wine onions compliment the richness of the liver well. The pickled vegetables use the quick vinegar way to pickle, so expect crunchy vinegary vegetables. They were fine, but there are other ways to pickle that produce better flavors. The pappardelle was also fine, but surprisingly not super flavorful. The cochinita pibil nailed the flavor combination, but the pork was dry. If the pork was moist these would be a home run. 

In summary, it was just ok. We went a bit early (5:40) so maybe they just weren't on their game.
author: Louis D.

description: Want out of the box upscaled & artistic comfort food? Dine here. Want awesome out of the box jazzy bluesy music in the backdrop? Dine here. Want cool, chic but not pretentious service? Dine here. We had several bites plus dinner, all were phenomenally delicious and elegantly presented. I will definitely be back, I can't wait to see what they will cook up next!!
author: L J.

description: I just stumbled upon this place. it was rather small , cramped feeling. I had the deviled egg, very eye pleasing but very Bland to the palate. I also tried the chicken liver crostini. It was way too sweet cancelled out the flavor of the chicken liver pate. Service was good and the Prosecco mediocre
author: Tosh H.

description:
I came to SF for the day on my own and sat down for lunch here as recommended by a friend. It was still AM so I needed my cappuccino, and I had to try one of their craft cocktails, so I went with Myraid's Mary. The coffee was smooth and the cocktail was uniquely made with agave wine and soju- a combination worth trying. Ordered their snack menu's famous deviled eggs and pickled vegetables. The eggs were amazing just like you here and the pickled vegetables are an appropriate compliment. Globally inspired, Myraid's Gastropub shocks your tastebuds with unique flavor. Sweet staff & decorative interior (here during the holidays, so reefs/ lights were up also)

Would recommend if you're looking to try something new & non traditional
author: Courtney R.

description:
I absolutely loved it here. You know what they say, the best things have to be stumbled upon and this restaurant sure took me my surprise.

We were planning to go to Cinema, but they were closed so we took a chance here for brunch. We're from out of town, from Vancouver to be precise (so we're really picky eaters)

Well anyway, our group came here on Christmas Eve and ordered a round of Mimosas for everyone at the table and also ordered pretty much the same thing. Everything we ordered was delicious... in particular the yummy Pate Spread, the Bacon and Syrup on French Toast and the Mayan Pork and Potato Hash. 

Portions were gigantic, so please bring your appetite!
author: Lesley Y.

description:
A cute spot, for the most part. I will say, considering portion size, and the neighborhood (Mission), it is a bit overpriced.

The steak fries are phenomenal. Deviled egggs, goood. Pork cheek & pappardelle, also great.

There is 1 tv, and it's tiny, but i suppose it does the job.

I'm not certain I'll go back considering the other options in the area. Although, my girlfriend insists she would...to each their own!
author: Benjamin J.

description:
I had a wonderful experience at Myriad Gastropub! I came in with a group of 7 for dinner on Saturday night. The waiter, the chef's brother, was very hospitable and gracious! He gave great recommendations on the menu and was sure to refill our drinks/water. He emphasized the chef wanted her restaurant to have a family atmosphere and we definitely felt that!

For dinner, I order the hanger steak dish and YUM!  Medium rare, on the fattier side, and great portion size. (I don't like getting a large steak that I can't finish). The fat held all of the flavor and allowed it to melt in your mouth with goodness! The dish came with a side of potatoes (patas bravas), also delicious. I'm not much of a potato fan at restaurants because I find them to be over or under seasoned and/or under or over cooked. But these potatoes were perfect! I loved them! The cojita cheese was an interesting touch that gave a Hispanic vibe, paired with the salsa verde. Also, cooked to just enough crisp on the outside and extremely soft on the inside. My friends kept stealing them off my plate! Very good! This dish was the more pricer of the menu-$26, not bad for quality food and enough quantity!  

We got a complementary dessert since they ran out of the dessert we ordered! Blood orange angel food cake- very light and not overbearing like many dessert dishes. I guess I usually order desserts that are heavy chocolate-everything but it was nice to have something on the lighter side.

I am very excited to try more dishes at Myriad! Thank you for the great experience!
author: Marcie A.

description: I don't know why some places get all the hype and places like this seem to fly under the radar. I came here for brunch and it checked all the boxes and then some: excellent, attentive service; delightful cocktails; delicious food; and the biggest plus for me: they take reservations for weekend brunch. Why wait in line when you can check this place out?!
author: Susanna W.

description:
Food: 3/5    Price: 2/5    Service: 3/5    Ambience: 5/5

*** MICHELIN Guide 2016, 2017 ***

This was definitely my worst Restaurant Week experience... For the $25 pre-fix lunch menu, you get to choose a snack (deviled egg / pickled vegetables), a small plate (popped elote/ chicken-liver mousse), and lunch plate (roasted chicken salad / bbq pulled pork sandwich / oxtail pozole). The price came out to be same or even more than just ordering from their regular menu. The portion size were also MUCH MUCH smaller, which doesn't make any sense. 
 
Everything we ordered were extremely salty. Deviled egg was just 1 half of the egg, and had way too much olive oil on it. Pickled vegetables was just salty. Popped elote was pretty good, I liked the cheese on top - but the restaurant week deal was literally 1/3 of the regular size. Chicken-liver mousse on crostini was delicious - but instead of getting a pot with 6 crostini like the regular menu, you get 2 small pieces. On to the entree... Bbq pulled pork sandwich was pretty good, I liked the saucy and flavorful pulled pork. The house spiced potato chips served on the side was again very very salty. Roasted chicken salad was probably the highlight of the meal - I loved the candied walnuts, apples, and blue cheese combination. 

Overall, Myriad is definitely a great restaurant. The ambience is beautiful and some of the food was surely delicious. I would really want to give them another change. However, I have to say I was pretty dissapointed with my experience. I don't understand why you are paying more, for less food. It would be great if they had clarified it beforehand, or state it on the menu. 

Favorites:
* potted chicken-liver mousse, port-wine onion jam, crostini ($10)
* roasted chicken salad ($14) - watercress, frisée, apples, croutons, walnuts, blue cheese, whole grain mustard dressing
* bbq pulled pork sandwich ($14) - with creamy honey poppy slaw, house spiced potato chips 

Others:
* deviled egg ($2) - with salsa verde, breakfast radish, crispy shallot
* popped elote ($6) -  buttered popcorn with chili, lime, cotija cheese 
* pot o' pickled vegetables ($6)
author: Victoria L.

description: Fabulous late afternoon meal. From drinks to snacks to entrees to desserts, everything was perfection. Highly recommend!
author: Cinde S.

description: Really good menu, everything we ordered was delicious. Ruby slipper cocktail was superb. Our server was attentive yet cool and funny. No crazy SF hipster crowd. A gem of a brunch spot!
author: Ruby B.

description:
Wonderful brunch in the Mission.  Mimosas were free flowing and a splash of pomegranate juice made them heavenly.

Had an Indian/Middle Eastern style breakfast with eggs that was super creative and bursting with flavor.

Perfect place for a small group to enjoy Sunday Funday.
author: Robert F.

description:
This place is great!

I was looking for a pretty nice little place [not too expensive but also really good quality food] to take my boyfriend for his birthday and a lot of the other top rated stuff in the neighborhood we've already been to. After tons of contemplating between a bunch of options, I settled for Myriad after checking out their menu online. They had some really solid choices that I knew he'd like, such as the marrow, liver mousse, and hangar steak #meat.

I made a reservation for the occasion and we came over that night. It was Monday night and I think we happened on a night that wasn't so busy so it was pretty empty which is perfect because I think I personally prefer a quieter more intimate dinner than one overcrowded with loud music and people.

One thing to note is that the cocktails are all made with beer/wine/soju etc. None of the really hard stuff in a typical cocktail. I think we went with the Obrigado and the Mission Statement, and from what I remember, both were pretty good :) 

For food we took:
- potted chicken-liver mousse, port-wine onion jam, crostini 
This was great, served in a fun little glass jam jar with some really nicely toasted and seasoned crostini. Wine onion jam is so good, you can pretty much put that on anything or mix it with everything and I'm down. The mousse was a great balance of the nice liver-y flavor and was so smooth and buttery. We both have kind of an obsession with all things liver mousse/pate/foie gras related (which yes, I know they're all different but hello #meatbutter) so this was great and a good portion too!

- bone marrow with sherry demi-glace, tarragon-horseradish gremolata, toasted sourdough
Bone marrow is a buttery blob of fatty goodness. You either love it or hate it and we're big fans (note the comment in the last item). They give you two solidly sized halves of bone marrow seasoned and cooked to perfection, with more lovely bread to dip and douse it with. Neither of us had no shame in taking the whole thing and basically licking it clean, that stuff is just so good. It's rich so you feel pretty satisfied but I always find that I could use a little more marrow since it does go down quick. 
**FYI I just checked and this is no longer on the menu! Boooo :(

- grilled hanger steak with patatas bravas, cotija, romesco, salsa verde, grilled spring onions 
We had this cooked medium rare and it was really good--solid pieces of steak and the patatas bravas were great (also a favorite). It ended up being a bit too much potato but we cleared off the meat like the carnivorous people we are.

- pappardelle pasta with pork cheeks, peas, kale, brown beech mushrooms, tarragon, pecorino 
This was an unexpected favorite. I am personally a huge fan of pork and especially pork cheek is such a delicately rich cut of meat. This was cooked SO perfectly and pappardelle is my absolute favorite type of pasta. This was like doused in a gravy mushroom sauce and we had it perfectly seasoned. My bf said it was reminiscent of a really good french dish he liked so we cleaned this up easily. 10/10 would recommend

- sorbets: pomegranate prosecco spiced pumpkin 
Of course, despite both of us not being much of dessert people, I decided to at least order a sorbet for the occasion (yes, the restaurant knew we were celebrating his birthday via the reso) and they put a cute little candle in the ice cream. Our server was so nice the whole night really making this birthday pretty special with a cocktail to go with our dinners and a dessert cocktail to go with dessert, complimentary. Plus, we only ordered the sorbet but he added a scoop of the spiced pumpkin ice cream for us to try as well. Both were great and really refreshing, plus the ending cocktail was perfect to top off the meal and help digest it all.

Let me just say service here is phenomenal. Maybe it was the time/day/occasion but regardless, I was really super impressed and pleased with everything and we really enjoyed the experience, which was a special one. Just for that, I will be back time again!

P.S. I've also ordered food delivery from here and when I did, I will say the pasta wasn't as well seasoned as it was in the restaurant--regardless, it was still very good. I was also able to try the deviled eggs and the mgp steak fries which are hefty steak fries with bacon, chive, & sour cream, all pretty yummy.
author: Nerissa C.

description:
I went here with a couple of friends for dinner, and we all had a wonderful experience. We reserved out table through Yelp. They use Yelp Reservation, and they are constantly checking the app, but I suggest to make your reservation at least 20-30 mins earlier.

The venue is really beautiful, very well organized, and I really liked they had an open kitchen, I love the fact I can see chefs preparing my food right in front of me!

We had three different plates, a dessert and a bottle of wine. Easy to say they all exceeded our expectations.
author: Giulio C.

description: Try the grilled lam sandwich - stunning. Plus the staff is super friendly. We enjoyed it. So much that we had to come back before we left for Denmark.
author: Fredrik K.

description:
I *really* want to be a big fan of Myriad but after trying it twice and being underwhelmed, I see no reason to go back. The first time I stopped in was about a year ago for cocktails and while I don't remember what anyone ordered, I *do* remember how everyone disliked their drinks. Maybe a fluke due to a bad bartender but for somewhere advertising as a "gastropub" with a cocktail menu, it is puzzling.

On our most recent visit, we stopped in for an early dinner. We arrived around 4:30pm before the dinner menu was being served but we were able to order a pitcher of Modelo ($12 on HH) and an order of deviled eggs ($5 or $6 on HH) before putting in an order on dinner. I will say that the beer was extremely reasonably priced and served in a large pitcher. The bartender was extremely friendly and even kept our pitcher in the refrigerator for us behind the bar to keep it from getting warm. The deviled eggs arrived, however, and were greasy and salty. This was my first time having deviled eggs (embarrassing, I know) but A thought they were prepared really poorly.

By the time we finished our snack, the kitchen was open for dinner. I opted for the Veggie Skillet ($19) and A was feeling the Grass-Fed Burger ($16). Our food arrived quickly and we dug in. My Veggie Skillet was HUGE. I only finished about a quarter of it. The creme fraiche on top I think ruined the dish and I scraped it off. The flavor was fine and it tasted healthy but I was not impressed at all since I KNOW I have made similar dinners myself. Plus, even if the portion was big, I think $19 for chickpeas is a bit steep. I did have it for breakfast the next day with an egg, at the suggestion of the bartender, and I enjoyed it more. A didn't love his burger and found the "fries" especially disappointing since they were more like potato wedges. 

Overall, I don't think either of us are willing to give Myriad a 3rd try. I give them an extra star than I think they deserve because both times we were there, the staff was really friendly and were trying. I just think they are so expensive for a sub-par experience and no matter how many fancy ingredients you use, the food is neither upscale nor comforting.
author: Carrie W.

description: We arrived around 3pm, as we had a 5pm movie. Unfortunately they have a very limited menu between lunch & dinner. We drank more than we ate because of this. Good beer selection. Had almost everything available during this timeframe. Don't order pickled veggies as a selection because it comes with most orders. Good place if your going to Alamo, but during lunch or dinner.
author: Deb B.

description: The pork hash was amazing. Nice decor, great service. Even the coffee was pretty good. I approve of this message and will be back. Need to come for dinner next time.
author: J Evan M.

description:
*** In Short ***

Solid brunch in a casual, but trendy venue.

*** In Depth ***

Wandering into the Mission without any plans other than that of, "food, we hangry," my friend and I ended up at Myriad after a little bit of Yelping, pleasantly surprised that the place was practically empty towards the tail end of brunch service (I mean this literally, as we showed up right as they were about to stop serving brunch).

While we found the appetizers to be a hit or miss, and not particularly notable in either case, their entrees were solid. I would suggest a hard pass on the deviled eggs, which we found to be unbearably salty, but the Mayan pork and potato hash entree was excellent and worth trying. Service was also particularly pleasant and accommodating, letting us still order from the brunch menu, and also letting us switch spots when we requested something with better lighting (for food photos, obviously).

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Pretty expansive place, as they actually seem to take up two adjacent spaces, with plenty of accessible seating.

Bathroom - Two separate bathrooms, one in each space, and both accessible, even though only one is actually marked as such.
author: Johnny W.

description: Great spot in friendly Mission... Vibe of old Mission with nice casual menu including amazing updates on the Wedge and Burger.... Wedge was termed 'Jersey' after chefs birthplace but tremendously updated with awesome relish based dressing. Burger very good served with "fries" which were actually baked slices of whole potato - skin and all - turned crunchy.
author: Brent O.

description: Man! This place has it all. Extraordinary food and incredibly friendly and doting staff - extra props to Ross who is so kind. Hubby had the lamb sandwich to rave reviews. Me the Jersey Wedge Salad. Come here. Do it. You will not be sorry.
author: Beth B.

description: Myriad is superb! Unique options, flavors and just a cool place. I happened in from out of town and would highly recommend.
author: Bill M.

description:
I asked the cab driver to drop me and my fiance off in the middle of 24th street so that we could take a walk through Mission and find a restaurant. This will sound pretentious, but my fiance was wearing a fur scarf and I had a collared shirt, so we were hoping to stumble into a fancy, upscale restaurant to celebrate our last evening in San Francisco on our engagement "honeymoon." I didn't realize that Mission would be all dingy taquerias (don't get me wrong, those are amazing, but have their time and place). Anyway, we walked past El Farolito and across from Foreign Cinema (where we had eaten the night before) and found MGP. The Yelp reviews seemed fantastic, so we strolled in.

Our server Ross was excellent. He was friendly, patient, and lively throughout the evening. He brought us tasters for the two beers that we were deliberating over, took good care of us over the course of the meal, and made us laugh several times.

As for food, we ordered the deviled eggs, the pickled vegetables, brussel sprouts, and MGP fries as appetizers/my fiance's meal. I enjoyed the deviled eggs - the mellow, rich flavors of the mashed egg yolk was balanced by the acidic pickled onions. I only wish I had ordered more than 1 for myself. I hate pickles as a personal taste, so no comments on the pickled veggies, although I will note that my fiance did not eat any of the cucumber pickles (but did finish all the carrots and cauliflower). The brussel sprouts were fried (I think?) and deflowered/de-leafed, as opposed to oven-baked in the round shape. Peppered with bacon bits and an acidic vinigerette, the brussel sprout was the strongest dish of the evening and I would order it again. The MGP fries, which I had imagined to be like a nacho dish with potatoes, was more like a loaded-potato-skins appetizer. Not amazing, but not terrible either. 

We split the hangar steak - the meat portions were on the smaller side. It came pre-sliced, as most hangar steaks do, and totalled to only three medium-sized pieces. The meat was well cooked, tender, and juicy, but I'm not sure it was worth the price tag. The potatoes were plentiful (maybe double the meat portion) and delicious, but there should have been a better balance.

Overally, was debating whether to rate a 4 or 5 star, but we thought that the service was so amazing that it would be a disservice to dock a star. Would highly recommend this restaurant to anyone in the area!

(Thanks for the lovely evening, Ross!)
author: Justin Y.

description:
Firstly, I don't think this is a $$ establishment. Especially dinner, it was easily in the $$$ range for one drink and one main entree. 

Our waiter was attentive but seems like the no-nonsense type of person which I prefer. 

The Mission Statement cocktail--get it.
author: Yad L.

description: Food is outstanding!  Salmon had crispy skin and amazing flavors. The papperdelle pasta with pork check had the most wonderful flavors.  Check out this little gem of a restaurant!
author: vicki M.

description:
Good service and good food. Brussels Spouts were super addicting, I didn't want them to end. Started out with our free deviled eggs for checking in - they were tasty! For the mains, we ordered the burger and the lamb sandwich. Burger was good, definitely had that flame broiled taste + a sesame seed bun which is always the best choice for a burger. 
The lamb sandwich was good, but I ended up taking off part of the bun to get more of the lamb/jam, flavor combo to make it a bit less dry. It was served with basically plain arugula, so I would have liked a little something extra to give the arugula more flavor. I ended up dumping some brussels sprouts in there to spice it up a bit.
author: A S.

description: Yum!  We stopped by for happy hour snacks -- the popcorn (flavored like elote), deviled eggs and steak fries were all excellent and made with care,and $5 each. Great service!
author: Vanessa H.

description:
This place had impeccable service. The waiters were very thoughtful and moved us to s different table without us asking because they were worried the sun would get in our eyes. The food is good but the portions are small for the price you pay. 

The suggestions the waiters gave us were definitely worth it! Definitely would consider coming again.
author: Wendy H.

description: We visit San Francisco often and were glad to find some new American-style cuisine in The Mission. We were seated immediately; we had a reservation. It was a decent crowd for a Thursday evening, but they let us choose our table, so we were able to sit in a private corner in the back. I would definitely recommend the popcorn as an appetizer and also the cheese grits as a side. The burger taste was only average for the cost. There were four of us eating, two of us shared an entree, we only ordered sodas to drink, and our total was $110. We are from Vegas where all restaurant meals are expensive, but that pricing even seemed pretty steep to us for the meals at this establishment. They also stopped offering us any sort of refresh on our beverages after we had been there about an hour. Service was probably about a six out of ten.
author: Jess J.

description:
I was visiting friends in San Francisco and we went to Myriad with a group of 8. The experience was fantastic. I loved it.

Food: 5
Drinks: 5
Atmosphere: 5
Service: 5
Price: 5

Food:
We ordered a bunch of appetizers to share, as well as entrees. All were creatively crafted, beautifully plated, and impressively delicious. The highlights were:
-- Popped elote. Aka popped corn...popcorn. haha. A great dish to order and munch on during appetizers! 
-- Farm toast with goat cheese mousse, pine nuts, balsalmic, and basil. It comes with 2 pieces of toast. They could easily be split into in half so four people each get a half..or you may not want to share :-D 
-- Roasted lamb sandwich: I love lamb. The lamb in this sandwich was super tender and complimented beautifully by tomato jam and creamy cilanto aioli. The bread was flavorful, though adittantly got rid of the top half and ate it open-faced...more lamb in each bite that way.
-- Salmon with pork guanciale, lentil ragout, sherry, whole grain mustard aioli, and herb salad. The salmon was perfectly cooked and the pork in the lentil raguat was a wonderful meaty compliment to it all. 
-- Cochinita pibil, aka braised mayan pork tacos served with sour orange red onions, pickled jalapeños, green chile, and corn tortillas. The pork melts in your mouth. 
-- Grilled hanger steak with patatas bravas (aka fried potatoes) and romesco. A generous portion of steak. Perfectly medium rare. Crispy flavorful potatoes. 

Drinks:
We ordered bottles of wine and pitchers of beer. The wine was a lovely $36 bottle of Navarrsotillo tempranillo. For beer, they guys got a few different kinds. Love that you can get pitchers of the beer! They got and enjoyed the Hawk Hill Hefeweissen and a saison. The cocktail list was also impressive, and though we didnt try them, I would feel safe saying I'm sure they're wonderful.

Atmosphere:
Warm, inviting, and lively. The restaurant is quaint. Dim lighting gives a cozy feeling. We had a bar-level table for our group of 8 in a nook at the front of the restaurant. The one thing I'll say is that there is only 1 one-person bathroom for the place, so there's usually a line. 

Service:
Our server was fantastic. Great at giving recommendations and coursing out our food. It was my friend's birthday so I asked the waitress if they did anything for birthdays. She had me choose a dessert and they brought out two desserts with candles in them! It was perfect!

Price:
In general, San Francisco isn't cheap, but this is pretty affordable. Lamb sandwich is $15, hanger steak is $26. Bottle o' wine for $36. It's not something you do every day, but for a fantastic meal it, this is a worthy spend!
author: Rachel M.

description: Came here once for dinner and another time for happy hour. The time we came for dinner it was supposed to be restaurant week so we'd get a several course meal for cheaper, but when we got there for our reservation they told us they weren't doing that menu during the weekend. Nowhere did it say that online so that was a disappointment, but we stayed because of our reservation. Good food, they were accommodating to dietary restrictions, and I'm all for farm to table cuisine but I don't know if this place is worth the price. Happy hour had some good options. The deviled eggs were good, but watch out for the fried shallot if you're avoiding gluten like me. I had to spit it out even though it was pretty much the highlight of the egg; it's nice that you can check in for an extra one! Come here for a few snacks and drinks if you're in the mood, but don't know if I'd go back for dinner unless they actually offer their restaurant week menu.
author: Samira I.

description: Excellent food and really interesting flavor combinations.  We tried the Mayan pork and the pappardelle.  Great beer and wine selection and cocktails are with wines and soju.  Overall, this place deserves the Michelin Star. I would only ask for the service to be a bit quicker.
author: Taylor S.

description:
Came here on a weekday lunch and it wasn't that crowded.  The first thing that I instinctively wanted to do is to order a beer since it was a "gastropub" right?  When I got there, there were only about seven draft beers offered.  Huh?  I thought that they would have more but eh, live and learn.

In terms of food, we got the farm toast with the goat cheese mousse as an appetizer.  It was actually really good as the mousse was smooth and creamy and not too goat-y.  We also got the market salad and the pulled pork sandwich.  These were about $13-14 each and tasted OK but be prepared that the portion size is smaller than average.  So just be aware that a lunch entree itself may not fill your appetite.

Service was great and aside from a couple of flies flying around us, we had a good experience here.  A pricy good experience but worth the visit.
author: Ben H L.

description: Myriad Gastropud definitely made my day !!!  We were looking for a place where we could spend our free time.  I was surprised because it wasn't crowded here on weekend. A big selection of food and drinks. Our waiter was so friendly. He helped to make our order and we didn't wait a long time. Everything was fresh and tasty. Prices here are not so expensive. Highly recommend.
author: Henrry O.

description: Very friendly service and good ambience. Favorite was the salmon dish- wall cooked, well seasoned, good flavors with the chorizo, and the root vegetable mash made it stood out. The market salad was simple yet tasty; tasted like fresh ingredients. The pappardelle was very tasty but it could have used more Parmesan. The deviled eggs were very bland (as if lacking mustard).
author: Hector S.

description:
I can't believe I've only been here once, because I constantly find myself thinking about the myriad (get it?) of dishes I sampled during my visit. Although the food is casual, everything is ridiculously delicious. Just so you know what a fat pig I am, here's a list of everything I devoured:

-Deviled eggs
-Chicken liver toast
-Fried chicken sammies
-Shrimp and grits
-Lamb sandwich
-Butter-with-scotch pot de crème

I'm dying to try the burger, but we all know my ass doesn't need to get any bigger.
author: Suany W.

description: Tasty deviled eggs, great burger, delicious chocolate cake, and superb coffee. Portions were actually reasonable. I was content and not overly full after the meal.
author: Omar R.

description: Love the fact that they are open until late night, which is perfect for late dinner. Don't forget to check in to get a free deviled egg, which is super yummy!! Highly recommend their Thai wings. A perfect balance of sweet and tangy. Great amount of crispness as well. The pappardelle pasta has a surprisingly large portion and is perfect for sharing.
author: Kitty M.

description:
