This place is great! Highly recommend coming here for dinner. The food was amazing, service was excellent and we all had a great dinner on a Friday night. We ordered a couple items and all shared it. The food we had was:

Deviled eggs: very yummy, they had a crispy shallot on top which was good! 

Thai Wing: so crunchy and still so much flavor, I recommend trying them! 

Crispy shrimp and grits: I would come back just for this it was so amazing. The grits were cooked perfectly

Market salad: so crisp and refreshing. It had a nice light dressing with peas in the salad. 

Side of asparagus: good! Came on toasted bread with a sauce. Very delicious!!

Edamame: good starter to share with everyone

Salmon: one of my favorite dishes as well. It was cooked to perfection

Pasta: you have to get this when you go, this was one of the main reasons we came. There's so much flavor and the pasta is cooked perfectly. It's really a great dish. 

We ended with the zeppole. Word to the wise, DONT SKIP THESE. They are soft on the inside and crispy on the outside. They have an orange zest to them and melt in your mouth. The Carmel sauce they give you as well is delicious. 

Overall this was great and we all would highly recommend it!
author: Molly O.

description:
Had brunch this am and it was one of the few places open on new years day. In fact, we were their very first 2018 customers!

Anyhow, the staff were very welcoming and friendly esp the gentleman who waited our table since he too has a baby that's 14-15 months old so he understands and tried best to help us have enough room for our baby and the mess that she'll abt to make. 

Now food wise, we the a half order of the challah  French toast with bacon bits, the (summer?) salad,  the smoked pork hash, and the lamb sandwich.  Best was the French toast since the breast was just thick enough to soak up syrup only on the outside vs. being too overly soggy. Lamb sandwich had great flavors but a lil dried...but dish came with a heaping portion of arugula which was great. Pork hash was decent but could use more spiciness to it.  And last, the salad was great all around in terms of flavor of dressing which was not too rich, and dish was a great medley of fruits, (sunflower or pumpkin) , cucumbers, salad, etc.

Overall great place and one we will be back for dinner soon!  Can't believe I had this place bookmarked for so long and only got to try it just now.
author: Ben M.

description: This is an amazing gastropub in the Mission district. Classy interiors and excellent service. I got started with their mission statement cocktail which was just what was needed after walking all over SF all day. Its very refreshing indeed. For dinner I got the lamb sandwich.. this was amazing! The combination of moroccan jam, feta and aioli was heavenly good, I'd come back just to try the sandwich again it was that good. Overall a well deserved 4.5 stars.
author: Sudipto G.

description:
Possibly one of my favorite happy hours.

I always falsely assume that drinks in big cities are going to cost me an arm and a leg. So when I find gems like Myriad Gastropub with better offerings then most of the places in my own hometown across the country, I get tingly all over. You, Myriad, have just become one of my "Must Stops" whenever I'm in SF.

Came with a friend for drinks before dinner, and it ended up being a highlight of our entire trip. The service was abundantly friendly, the price was abundantly cheap, the drinks were abundantly satisfying, the food was abundantly delicious.

We came for the happy hour (if you couldn't figure that out from the first seven words of this review), which runs EVERY DAY from 3 to 6pm - more bonus points to them for doing this on the weekends! - and enjoyed $5 prosecco, $5 red wine, and a $5 snack (three deviled eggs topped with salsa verde radish, and shallots - there were actually quite a few vegetarian friendly options to choose from). This was a perfect way to whet our appetites (the opposite of wetting one's whistle, by the way) pre-dinner at a nearby restaurant.

What a happy happy hour it was indeed.
author: Steff D.

description: The lamb sandwich is to die for. A lovely gastropub with amazing service. A nice gentle gem in the mission
author: Doron K.

description:
Wow , what a treat . Don't past this place by 
Excellent and well prepared tasty delicious 
Bites , awesome beer selection . Sous Chef Sam 
Amazing, you know this culinary chef loves to cook 
Thanks for the great experience 
Can't wait to go back 
Gaby
author: Gabriel B.

description: It was decent food and decent service, definitely not something to actively avoid and yet at the same time, nothing special and nothing to go out of your way for.
author: Jeff B.

description: I've come here once before for lunch and came for dinner last night. This place is cool and food is good. Last night I got the wedge salad to start which I'm pretty sure I got last time as well. This wedge salad is REALLY good, definitely not good for you. Loaded with their house special 1000 island with bacon, cheese, croutons and pickled red onions, it really is delicious. I really wanted to get a side of the mgp potato wedges with all the fixings they offer so I decided to just get the chicken sliders and those for my meal. The sliders are really good too. Comes with a Mexican slaw in the sammie and picked veggies on the side. Would like to try this place for brunch some time
author: Katlyn H.

description: Great ambience, pleasant service staff.  The food was good but not impressive.
author: JP M.

description: The fried chicken sandwiches are divine! We also got the deviled eggs, salmon entree, and Mayan pork entree. Salmon was great but the pork entree was super dry. Hope they fix this but other than that service was great and hoping they get their liquor license at some point.
author: Shabnam E.

description:
Myriad was recommended by some friends at The Marsh. So glad they told us about it - because we may have never enjoyed this terrific dinner! 

9 people for reservation on a Saturday night. I noticed how small the place was and wondered how they would seat all of us... and they did just fine! Comfortable seating, and not pushy at all about turning over our table. Thanks for letting us linger! 

We had a bunch of starters and a few entrees we shared and several drinks and a few bottles of wine.. Super happy with everything. 

We loved the chicken livers, Thai wings, chicken sammies, shrimp and grits, deviled eggs and burgers. And desserts -- butter-scotch and fruit crisp. 

Everything was great - the service was spectacular! I recommend this place HIGHLY and can't wait to go back. I want more of those shrimp and grits, more of that pork cheek and more butter-scotch pudding! LOVE!
author: Marilyn D.

description:
Ok so I finally got to try out this place, Been wanting to come here since it open.
There was so much good reviews from friends and online. 
We (3 friends) ended up coming here only cuz LOLÓ closed at 4pm on Sunday. But nonetheless we thought it was a good decision..... right?  
Oh NO! ..... first the restaurant lighting was so dark that I had to break out my iPhone flashlight to see the menu.
Second the menu was not all it's cracked up to be. I didn't see what so special about this place..... did we come on a off time of the year??? If so please tell me when is the best time ?? 

We ordered fried Brussels sprouts, edamame's, fried chicken sammis, salmon with pork guanciale, and potted chicken liver mousse.
Out of all the dishes we had the best this was the potted chicken liver mousse. 
Salmon dish was very under seasoned. Salmon skin was not crispy, which most of the time it should be when it is pan seared. 
Edamame's and Brussels sprouts was good but nothing special about it. 
Chicken sammis was bit under seasoned and could of used some kick in the breading of the chicken or a sauce.

I didn't even bothered to take any photos cuz I wasn't worth it.
The waitress gave good service and that's why I gave a 3 stars instead of 2.
Anyhow I hope next time we will have a better meal experience if we decided to eat here again.
Completely disappointed after reading and hearing all the good reviews.
author: Bobby W.

description: Delicious food, great atmosphere and lovely staff! I'm a vegan and loved the salad and potatoes for brunch. I'm actually very full and it was so tasty. Seating was great and lighting was wonderful even on a semi gloomy day.
author: Staci S.

description: This place is pretty good. Very decent food and very decent environment. I would love to come back more often in the future.
author: William D.

description:
Dan was the man.

He provided great service, didn't forget our orders, refills, made great recommendations for apps (popcorn, deviled eggs and demgritsdoe!!!) and he was genuinely happy lighting up our Noe Valley salted caramel bday cake for our celebrants and rightfully earned our 25% tip. 

The food is another story.

We've seen the photos of the bone marrow. HUGE bones and so cheap for $11 when everyone else in this town is charging $16. It came to the table, we dug in and there was blood in it. Sent it back to the kitchen, the bones came back with an "extra" bone as apologies from the chef. Still undercooked. The sherry demi-glace didn't do anything to elevate a fatty delicious app to what it's supposed to be, instead,  we had to ask for salt to season it.

The farm toast is one of their popular items. Get it if you really must, but I recommend on skipping it. Again, nothing against toast, but it's just goat cheese and strawberry-rhubarb jam and some herbs/seeds. Did I miss something? for $10, I expected something more. Perhaps something like Delarosa's version. Now, THAT's a toast worth paying for!

The burger was also something I was eyeing. But thanks to Dan's recommendation, I got the salmon instead. Served with english peas, baby carrots and pea tendrils on mashed potatoes. It's clear that this should be the special dish that diners should be ordering. I love that perfect crispy skin. However, my friend's burger was overcooked and didn't want to send it back since they couldn't wait for another exchange. 

The bf ordered a veggie skillet with chickpea stew, bulgar pilaf, fava beans with a garlic creme fraiche. No bacon or any meat listed on the menu (go ahead and check the current online menu) He finds pork belly in his dish. He ate it and was like, "this is one delicious vegetable!" (ugh, it's bacon!) If I was vegan, I would've flipped my lid. (thank God I'm not and no offense to vegans out there.)

Due to the Myriad (ha) of problems we encountered with our dishes, sad to say, we would hesitate on coming back. I'd probably pop in to say to Dan (who's the man!) but that's about it.
author: Janice C.

description:
What a great find! Went during happy hour on a weekday and found this little gem superb!

We opted to sit at the bar and chat with the super friendly bartender.  ordered a glass of red wine and my gal pal ordered a glass of prosecco. We chose to have a little taste off of their happy hour menu before dinner at another location. The deviled eggs were top notch!

I would definitely like to come back to taste more of their great food! When back in San Fran, you'll find me at this great happy hour joint!
author: Kellie M.

description: Loved that pork pasta. Expensive but quality is high. The small dishes were all decent. I had the wings and various others.
author: Xiu L.

description: Quick lunch with my son. Good salad, nice French rose'. Son had the tomato soup and the chicken salad, also quite good. Quiet on this Monday lunch hour. Efficient service, friendly wait staff!
author: Pamela C.

description:
The food was very good. Creatively done with nice presentation. 
Best dishes were the salmon with mussels and the pork cheeks with pappardelle.  Tried a little of everything.  Brussels sprouts, shrimp and grits, popped elote (yummm),  lamb sandwiches and fried chicken sammies. All were nice for appetizers or would be a good light lunch. Got a pretty deviled egg for checking in but it was quite salty, my least favorite of the meal.
author: Jill a.

description: This place is delicious. The service is fantastic. I highly recommend the Challah French toast and the Mayan pork hash for brunch! The coffee is great, which in my opinion makes or breaks a place for brunch.  My boyfriend had the chocolate voodoo beer and he loved it as well.
author: Dirk N.

description: I heard about this place on Check Please. Decided to give it a try. The food was average and prices too high for what you get. Nothing special.
author: R R.

description:
We came for brunch and had a flight of champagne, deviled eggs, a side of maple bacon, coffee, and a tomato soaked poached egg with chickpea pancakes (gluten free). 

It was sooo good. Small plates and a nice selection of drinks had batter make Foreign Cinema worried.
author: Jeff D.

description:
3.5 stars for me. Was excited to try this spot based on the positive reviews, but found it underwhelming.

We had the deviled eggs, fried chicken sliders, wedge salad, and salmon. The eggs weren't anything special, and were drenched in olive oil and overly salted. The chicken sliders, while fairly tasty, were about the size of a tennis ball and the chicken felt like the rough size of a chicken nugget. Sliders aren't supposed to be large, but it would have been nice if it lasted more than two bites. The wedge salad, a nice mix of greens, blood orange, orange, nuts, and blue cheese might have been one of the best things we had. The salmon was crispy and served aboard a nice mix of lentils and vegetables.

The atmosphere and decor at Myriad are nice, and I can see how this can be a fun place to hang out or catch up over some small bites. The food, however, was unspectacular, and given the bevy of great food places in the area, I won't be returning anytime soon.
author: Tim X.

description:
I'm truly baffled by the 4.5 star Yelp rating...  My first visit was when it first opened and I thought the food was very average for SF and below average for the Mission.  I thought maybe they'll workout the kinks and improve.  A year later, I see the persistent 4.5 star Yelp rating and decided to try again and it was equally disappointing.

Pretty much everything is either missing flavor or texture and nothing stood out to inspire a return visit.  I took the recommendation of our waiter, the chicken sliders were dry, it is hard to screw up fried chicken but they did.  The cochinita pibil was dry and that is messing up slow roasted pork......  I can do a much better cochinita pibil, at home, in my Instant pot, for reals.  These are not complicated dishes and there is zero excuse for a 4.5 star restaurant to ruin fried chicken and slow roasted pork!

There are at least ten restaurants within a 3 block radius that are WAY better at the same price point.  I would recommend Hog & Rock, Lolo or Tacolicious instead.
author: Rosalyn C.

description: Love this place! Happy hour on the weekend?! Really good snacks and all the bartenders have been super friendly.
author: Tara K.

description:
I came here for a late dinner, and luckily my friend made a reservation. This place was crowded even at 8 pm. Since there was a big group of us, we sat at the table closest to the window, which doesn't give much privacy. Everyone walking outside can watch you having dinner with your friends because of the L-shaped window. 

Anyway, onto the food. We shared the goat cheese toast, which was pretty good. For my entree, I chose the papardelle with pork cheeks. It was just ok. I've had better papardelle, so I was kind of disappointed. The dish also tasted really heavy. 

The server was great, though. She gave great suggestions and was very professional.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Great food and drank.

Ambiance is nice, pretty standard. We had a reservation for a group of 7 and sat in the high table in front of the window. Thank you for the bag/jacket hooks! Nice helpful touch.

Marrow with Sherry luge - I didn't try it, but friends loved it. Presentation beautiful and it looked delicious.

Deviled eggs - Awesome. Wish $2 got you two eggs though. It's a bit pricey, but delicious nonetheless. The shallot crunch and drizzled oil made the dish. 

Parpadelle with pork - Great dish. It's very hearty and savory. The mushroom sauce and kale combo is delicious. I thoroughly enjoyed the meal and finished every last bite. Just be aware it's on the saltier side. 

Didn't have room for dessert, but we were celebrating a birthday, sooo....zeppoles and chocolate cake. The desserts are pretty small portions, so you totally have room. Go for it!

Oh, my cocktail! Best, best Persephone's on Fire made with pomegranate, agave wine, americano, lime, jalapeño, ancho chile. Could have had 5 of these. They're so delicious!
author: Priti K.

description:
Money-wise, Myriad is definitely on the high end of the double-dolla ($$) rating. The main reason I come here is because it's usually not busy, and reservations are incredibly easy to make (last minute reservations are almost always available.

For brunch I got the Mayan pork and potato hash with fried egg, smokey tomato salsa, queso fresco, and cholula-lime crema. The serving was rather small (if you're a guy you'll likely still be hungry) and I finished it all, which was surprising (to compare, I usually can't fit an In-N-Out cheeseburger + fries into my stomach in one go). The quality of food was excellent, though, with lots of smokey sour notes; I definitely get the Mayan vibe here. But for $16 I felt like the quantity left a little more to be desired. 

For dinner I've gotten the deviled egg appetizer ($2 is a bit pricey, but it's creamy and perfectly cooked, tasty but not too strong). I also got the hanger steak which was tender and juicy -- not too dry! 

What I really enjoyed was that the cook/owner (?) came by to say hello and ask if we liked the food. Truly appreciated the personal touch. The service here is probably a big reason I'll be coming back -- I know I'll get a table and I know I'll be treated well!
author: Christine L.

description: Favorite gastropub! Had some amazing sandwiches there for lunch and phenomenal service. Chicken sammies are SOOO good! Perfect crunch, perfect kick of acidity (I sliced in some pickled cauliflower that they came with), soft and scrumptious. Lamb sandwich with tomato jam was awesome too. Can't wait to go back!
author: Marina N.

description:
Came here for a date night dinner.  

We had a reservation and were seated next to the bar.  The issue with this is that they started doing blending in the kitchen which was quite loud and quite a mood buster! 

With all that, the food was quite good, which is why 4 stars.   The crispy chicken sammies, the lamb sandwich, the parpadelle were all on point.  Flavors were original, surprising (in a good way) and delicious!
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Did not disappoint. Went with a friend who has been here many times for brunch and dinner. We started with two mini fried chicken "Sammie" sliders, and each were individually the best chicken fried sandwich I've ever had. If they had a full sized version I'd order it.

We then shared a plate of paperdelle pasta with pig's cheeks and the vegetarian platter with lentils, veggies and creme fresh or something like that on top. It wasn't my cup of tea, but was a fine veggie choice. The pasta on the other had was stupendous and generously portioned and I'd go back just for that.

Service was excellent.
author: Jordan C.

description: We thought the deviled eggs were unremarkable, the peaches/goat cheese and fried chicken sammies pretty good . . . but the cochinita pibil is the BEST I've had anywhere, even in the Yucatan. You get a hunk of meat you pull apart yourself and put in the lime-chile corn tortilla and then dip in the citrus juices the meat was braised in. HEAVENLY good!
author: Frako L.

description:
They have a great selection of HH snacks.  They also have a decent selection of wines for HH and dinner!! Unfortunately, no alcohol for me. Prices are $5 between 3-6pm. I only got to try the devilled eggs from that portion of the menu.

For dinner, I had burger with a side of fries.  The fries were spicy, and had a kick to it which I actually enjoyed. I requested no onions, but they added it anyway. I had to pick it out. 

My dinner companion enjoyed the pickled veggies, but I have zero tolerance for it right now, so I can't comment on it.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Now truth be told, I think Myriad had a better vibe than Nombe did since it feels a bit more grown up now. Now understand the first time I walked into the space was a Yelp party several years ago, and the appetizers on the decimated platters had been devoured by my fellow famished reviewers. However, Myriad tones down the rustic-retro look for monochromatic earth tones and more soothing music, and it works, at least for this non-millennial diner. The menu is now more new American with Latin touches provided in dishes like Bacalaitos (salt cod fritters) and Cochinita Pibil (braised Mayan pork).

I started with an all-American picnic favorite, the $2 Deviled Egg with a slight Latin twist in the salsa verde, breakfast radish and crispy shallots. I ordered two of them thinking I'd get four halves, but no, it was just two halves (photo: http://bit.ly/1RjqWBU). I hate when that happens because then I'm too embarrassed to ask for another order. On top of that, they were a tad too pickly for my taste as I'm the type that goes for straight mayo, or should I say aioli? Any reservations I had at that point went away with my entree, the $24 Pappardelle with Pork Cheeks, Peas, Kale, Brown Beech Mushrooms, Tarragon, and Pecorino (photo: http://bit.ly/1QZAiU8).

I was tempted by the Grilled Hangar Steak, and chef Tricia Tracey even came by to wax fondly about it in a very close contest with the pappardelle. I didn't regret my choice as it was delicious in an earthy Tuscan way with huge chunks of savory pork cheek to satisfy any carnivore. This one is a winner. Buoyed by my main dish, I went for the $8 Warm Caramelized Granny Smith Apple, Cranberry and Pecan Crisp with Crème Fraîche Ice Cream and was downright gleeful about the combination of flavors and textures that were both familiar and refreshing (photo: http://bit.ly/1RjqYdd). Yet another winner, two out of three ain't bad and I'm certainly tempted by the other menu items.

FOOD - 4 stars...the pappardelle is a winner, something tells me there are others lurking on that menu
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...more pleasant than it was as Nombe
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...pretty attentive, especially when the chef comes to your table
TOTAL - 4 stars...even though it bears a strong resemblance to others in its culinary genre, Myriad deserves its prime spot on Mission
author: Ed U.

description:
It's with a heavy heart that I cannot give Myriad a 5* review. In fact, I was almost going to leave a 3* review as we were so disappointed compared to our expectations.

The idea came together to convince some friends from San Jose to come up to SF to have a great meal. We looked over so many Yelp reviews and decided on Myriad since it seemed affordable and had a 4.5* rating. We were excited to easily make a reservation for a Friday night with only a few days notice. That doesn't happen everywhere in SF.

Service was pretty great, I'll say that. The girl who welcomed us was somewhat new to the restaurant but was very friendly and helpful, and our server Charlie was nice as well.

The three of us had drinks and a smattering of food, and our total after tax was $171. I don't know how we got the bill that high as none of us were stuffed and we didn't really order that much food.

We split the Hanger Steak, which was the most expensive thing at $25. It was decent, but wasn't that big. We also split the Pork Pappardelle for $24, and it wasn't that good. I think that was the entire table's concensus, though maybe it was just mine.

The farm toast was great, as were the deviled eggs.

We were excited to get the bone marrow, and we had the sherry luge as well. My friend and I were disappointed when it was only half of a bone marrow on the plate, and we had to split that and then take turns doing the luge. Worse, our bill showed TWO sherry luge's. Maybe it was a double? I don't think so, and we surely didn't ask for one or even tell them we'd be splitting it, so I think it was just an error.

Nothing was standout amazing, and I don't think I'd return if I was in SF. There's so many restaurants to try, that's all. Maybe they just had a bad night, but none of us were blown away like everyone else was.
author: Rob P.

description:
The last time I came to this location, it was a different restaurant. I didn't realize there was a new spot and was surprised that it was pretty good.

RESERVATIONS: Made less than a week in advance for two on a Saturday at 7pm. They were fairly busy throughout dinner but there didn't seem to be a wait.

SERVICE: Good! I got a table near the door and appreciated that they asked if I preferred the door closed, in case it was chilly.

THE COST: $34.85 for 1 starter & 2 entrees shared between two people. 

SNACKS
* Farm toast ($11) - 4.5 stars
Great starter! Goat cheese mouse, balsamic, nectarine all went great together. 

LARGE PLATES
* Lamb sandwich ($15) - 3.5 stars
The bite I had was full of flavor. Salad seemed fresh. My friend enjoyed this.

* Cochinita pibil (braised mayan pork, $21) - 4 stars
Excellent cut of meat, very tender and soft. The broth is full of flavor. The corn tortillas were thick & fresh. A little hard to eat as a taco with all the broth dripping out, but it was still very delicious.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Super friendly service but on the pricey side for the Mission.  The lamb burger and arugula salad were excellent.  Good place to catch up with friends as an alternative to a dirty burrito place.
author: Chris L.

description: Dropped in for lunch last week. You can definitely tell someone put there heart & soul into this place. Everything is thoughtfully designed & considered. I wish I'd come with a friend because the menu had too many tasty sounding selections. I had the lamb sandwich & the obrigado cocktail. The lamb sandwich was deliciously perfect--thinly sliced & super flavorful on a brioche? bun. Came with a decent sized side salad, not overdressed & not a single wilted green--thanks to whomever for paying attention :)  The port cocktail was outstanding. I would come back just for that perfectly balanced refreshing drink even if I wasn't hungry. Service was great too. Looking forwarding to coming back.
author: Joel M.

description: A little overrated. The food is decent, but overpriced, and the beer selection isn't even that impressive. They seem to have a handful of very unique items, which is probably their saving grace.
author: Ram S.

description:
Had the toast, which I thought was a nice blend of subtle flavors. The cheese is pretty mild, but the truffle oil really brings it together. 

Enjoyed the pate as well, the sweet onions complemented nicely. Best of all was how we were brought a few extra crostini when our server noticed we had more pate left... This small detail took very little for them to do, but went a long way to making us feel noticed. 

The burger, which I'd read was a highlight, turned out to be good but nothing special. Tasty meet but to make it stand out I think it needs a bit more flair.
author: Tyler L.

description: My friends and I were looking for a brunch place that wasn't packed to the rim. This is a tough find in the Mission. We walked until we found this place.  We were treated really nice and seated immediately. Yes-- the food was amazing I got a breakfast sandwich, and my boyfriend got a lamb sandwich. The mimosas were pretty bomb too!
author: Alison J.

description:
Had the deviled eggs, lamb burger and the mayan  pork tacos. 
The hefenweissen beer was nice and cold. 

The deviled eggs were tasty with a lemon flavored olive oil. 

The lamb burger was big but gamey tasting. It came with a salad. The salad was good and lightly dressed.

The Mayan pork is marinated for 3 days. It was dry and not moist but the sauce/juice was good. Pickled onions and peppers were good. The tortillas came out warm and were good. 

Service was efficient and friendly
author: Bacon G.

description: Amazing food! We had several small starters to share. The devils eggs, ceviche, crispy spiced chicken... all were very good. Perfect mix of right flavors. The waiter was also very friendly, a bit weird, but fun!
author: Jolien D.

description:
Stopped in on a Tuesday night for a light dinner. Was able to get a table for four without a wait. The service was friendly and helpful, just the right amount of attention. The decor was a little rustic minimalist with a good vibe. 

We shared a few items amongst the table. All of it was very well done. The deviled eggs were outstanding and I'm not usually a fan. The fried chicken sliders had a wonderful slaw on them and I could have eaten more of it all by itself. We also had the chicken liver mousse which had these amazing caramelized onions on top, delicious!

My only criticism of this place is the menu is small.  They were also out of two beers on draft which only left six options. I know I'm being picky on this review and wish I could give them 4.5 stars.
author: Scott M.

description: This is such a great place for cocktails and food! We stopped by for lunch while in the Mission and realized we have definitely found a gem. I got the "Mission Statement" cocktail and it was so good with the elderflower! We ate the lamb sandwich which is one of the best sandwiches I have ever eaten, Thai wings, Brussels sprouts and steak fries with chipotle ketchup. The fries were super crispy and the ketchup is amazing! Everything was delicious and the service was super friendly
author: Amanda L.

description: Our waiter was awesome. First ordered "the freshie" really good cocktail. The food on the other hand was not so good in my opinion. The pappardelle pasta was not up to par, the pork tasted too much like pork if that makes any sense more like how it would taste/smell if it didn't have any seasoning. Other than that maybe it was an off day but I would recommend to try maybe my taste buds are just different.
author: Anna V.

description: Every dish we ordered was incredible. Loved the ambiance, too! The one thing I wish they had was a liquor license, but they make up for it with creative non-liquor drinks. I'll definitely be coming back here!
author: Savannah F.

description: Everything we had here was really good...lamb sandwich, chicken salad, and fried chicken sliders. The brussel sprouts were the best we've ever had so that needs a special call out. Well done, Myriad!
author: Scott C.

description:
My, what a nice find. I looked for reservations to dine with out of town friends, and found this. It is nice looking but not too off-putting to folks not used to SF prices.

They have a nice cocktail list along with beers, wines and other spirits. The food itself is pretty shareable. They are quite small, so for two people you might want to get 3-4 of the plates, depending on which.

The food was pretty delicious, except they were on the salty side, and I had to drink a bit more water than usual for certain bites. The pappardelle with pork cheeks was solid, as was the shrimp and grits. The cochinita pibil looked really impressive served on a leaf and what not - and it was really very tender - but the lack of spices make it a very single-noted dish. 

Anyhow, it was a very pleasant dinner for me and it's definitely left a strong impression.
author: Alice C.

description:
Dinner review. Restaurant week.

Mgp chips - 4/5
Popped elote - 3/5
Chicken liver crostinis - 2/5
Deviled egg - 2/5
Bone marrow - 5/5
Cochinita pibil - 5/5
Pappardelle with pork cheeks - 3/5
Ricotta zeppole - 4/5
Butter-with-scotch pot de creme - 5/5

Overall, bone marrow was "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
Tried this after watching "Check Please Bay Area". Door person seemed a little stress, & not especially welcoming nor attentive. Service started a bit slow although the restaurant was not full. Cocktails were ok, but not spectacular.

We started with deviled eggs & they were tasty. Next was the Jersey Wedge & that was very good. We liked that they lightly drizzled some dressing on the lettuce, but put more on the side for individual liking. Next was the potted chicken liver mousse. This was tasty, but not better than others we've tried elsewhere. Last small plate we tried was the spiced shrimp with creamy grits. This was very good with grits that actually tasted of corn. The entire dish was very flavoful.

We chose the papparadelle with pork cheeks which was very good. It  had a deep down mushroom flavor, but could have used a bit more salt. The burger on the other hand was very beefy & had a great charred flavor. We think their burger is actually slightly better than Chez Maman & Monsieur Benjamin. 

While everything was pretty good so far, the deserts didn't do as well. The pot de crème was nice enough, but the butter scotch flavor should have been stronger. The thyme shortbread cookie was not good. It kept reminding me my dinner fell into my desert. The tres leches-almond brown butter cake had decent flavor but was very dry. 

Overall, decent food & their bus persons were very attentive & hard working. Our waiter tried hard also but seemed a bit overwhelmed. We'd come back if in the neighborhood, but would not make a special trip.
author: Amen C.

description:
Relatively easy to get reservation in the Mission.  We had:
- Deviled eggs (3/5) - Pretty ordinary
- Chicken liver mousse (5/5) - Delicious combination of salty, sweet, and deep chicken liver flavor.
- Pappardelle pasta (3/5) - Seemed to have potential but was devoid of salt, leaving it rather disappointing, unfortunately.
- Lamb sandwich (4/5) - Nice lamb flavor that worked really well with the sweet jam inside.  Came with a tasty side salad.

I'd absolutely come back for the chicken liver and lamb sandwich.   Wish the draft beer list was a little better but definitely a good place to grab dinner.
author: Simon L.

description: Good food, atmosphere and friendly service. Taking one star away because as a "gastropub" we expected a whole bunch of beer taps but that was not the case. Otherwise, fried chicken sliders, MGP fries and deviled eggs were all delicious. Would dine in again!
author: Molly M.

description:
After one bite of the fried chicken mini sliders, Myriad became an instant favorite. 

We showed up on a busy Friday night without reservations, but were quickly seated at the bar (always a delight to skip a long wait!). Service for everything was fast, attentive, and all around perfect. We split the fried chicken sliders, the kale artichoke dip, and the burger... all of which were truly delicious.

I eat out A LOT, and few places are good enough to make me close my eyes and savor every bite. Myriad did just that. Seriously. 

All I can say is that it's perfect, and I will definitely be back again and again and again. This is also a prime location to have dinner before checking out the many happenin' bars in the Mission.
author: Fiona F.

description: I admit that at first I thought this place was too upscale for its location but the neighborhood changes all the time. Myriad is delicious, the menu is interesting, and the staff is fun and professional.
author: jessica v.

description: I just went to this place for the first time with no real expectations and I was pleasantly surprised. The food was fantastic, service, and ambiance as well. If you're looking for a great food on a casual date night, try this place out.
author: Keith S.

description:
Came in at 3 p.m... In time for their sip 'n' snacks & happy hour menu. 

Chicken sammies (crispy fried chicken sandwiches with creamy mexican cole slaw, honey chipotle mayo, and garnish of pickled vegetables) = good sandwich but it's made with dark meat chicken. He wasn't too happy but ate it nonetheless. Pickled vegetables are delicious. $11.00.

MGP potato chips (spiced and served with horseradish-chive crema) = Delicious, crispy chips with awesome horseradish-chive crema. I could have eaten a gallon of the crema. $5.00.

Chicken liver mousse crostini (topped with port-wine onion jam) = awesome. I would've loved to have more but I had to restrain myself. $5.00.

Service = friendly enough. 

Prices = moderate. Light lunch for two came out to $23.83 (including the SF mandate fee.)

Seating = plentiful. They have a full dining area, and some 2-tops and bar seating by the bar.
author: Fannie S.

description: Came here on the eve of Christmas eve. The place was pretty empty despite the reputation. We sat down right away for brunch without having to wait at all. The hostess let us pick where we wanted to sit and then she turned the space heat towards us since it was a cold day and we opted to sit by the window for some natural light. We started out with the chicken liver pate. It was fantastic with sweet onion on too and rich pate underneath. The portion size was good, the toast that came with it was a little too crispy. Then we shared the carrot and ginger soup which was the best part of the whole meal. It was warm and Spicey and sweet with yogurt on top. Just have It! I got the shakshuka. To be honest it was a little disappointing. It was basically two eggs in tomato sauce. No chicks peas, nor potatoes to give it texture. My boyfriend got the lamb sandwich which was So greasy his hands mushed into the bun. Overall, the food has a ton of potential and their game could still be improved. The service was fantastic. Worth checking out for brunch.
author: Anne S.

description:
Order the deviled eggs. You will say my name.

Farm toast+mimosa=win

You want to take my recs. Do it.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
Me and a friend were trying to grab a quick bite in the mission. We found this place because it had great reviews and no wait- we were on a time crunch.

They seated us right away, and service was pretty good.

We ordered:

Grilled hangar steak, which is a must try!!
Bacalaitos- which are pretty much fried fish balls
Jersey wedge- I wasn't too thrilled about this one- just over priced slices of potatoes
Potted chicken-liver mousse- Never tried something like this before. It's a mousse you spread on crostini. I liked the mousse- it was interesting. Definitely had that strong liver taste. Wish they had other bread besides the crostini. I don't like bread that hard.

I really enjoyed the food here. Definitely would not order the Jersey wedge again, it's whatever and poor value. If I came back I would order the hangar steak again and try some different plates.
author: Jessica S.

description:
In Cali, things move a bit slower then they do on the East coast. Everyone is very chill, laid back and relaxed...and sometimes because of that, things tend to take a bit longer.

I came in for dinner with a few coworkers last week, and our dinner took over three hours. Not complaining at all. After a long day it was nice to relax and unwind over delicious food and drinks. Our waiter was extremely knowledgeable and took a great deal of time to walk us through each course and give us tips on what to order (which was pretty much everything on the menu).

We started with dranks, naturally. Something very unique about Myriad is that although they don't serve liquor (wine and beer only) they have various cocktail options made with different types of beer and wine. I went with the sandbar which was really fruity and had prosecco in it. Yum!

We shared a couple of small plates including farm toast, fried cod balls and grilled peach and goat cheese salad. The farm toast was definitely the highlight (as promised by the waiter) and had a delicious creamy cheese and homemade tart plum jam.

Okay, so about an hour and a half later, we were on to ordering our mains. I ordered the pappardelle with beef cheeks, minus the beef cheeks. I don't care if they are a delicacy, anything with beef cheeks in it's name is not going in my stomach. The dish was great either way, and was almost reminiscent of something you'd order at a thai spot. Noodles sauteed in some kind of brown sauce with mixed veggies like straw mushrooms and kale. Soooo good that I had to finish every last bite.

And then, on to dessert. This time we didn't order and instead the waiter told us to trust him. At this point in the meal, I definitely did. He brought out an assortment of things- ice cream sandwiches with fresh berry ice cream, butterscotch custard and fried dough balls. Obviously this guy really knew a thing or two about how to impress five ladies.

Three hours later, we left full and satisfied. Although it's in a bit of a seedier area in the mission, don't bypass this spot. It's totally worth the hype.
author: Sara B.

description:
In my opinion, pickled veggies in a jar is very 2013/14. I was really into it back then, everywhere I went I must had my jar of pickled, that and watermelon salad. It was perhaps one of the primary reasons I went back to Citizen Band so much. it had both. So when he exclaimed, "they have pickled veggies. We have to get that." I was a bit of underwhelmed. But seeing that he shared my prior enthusiasm, albeit, two years too late, I did not want to turn him down. No one dared to turn me down when I was going through that pickled phase. Myriad Gastro has a very interesting selection of pickles. They were pretty and crisp. A nice contrast to the dark interior. 

Fried chicken sammies were very good. You know it's listed as small bite but it's not really. A perfect sharable dish.

Pasta was good. They were nice enough to split it down the middle. Sadly it encouraged me to eat more. I am a lot shorter and ought to eat less. But it is the right amount of pasta, eating it all by yourself would mean a lot of trail miles and it's not worth it. So absolutely do divide the dish up into two.

I realized that this was the restaurant that we'd have wanted to come for brunch. 

I was wrong about pickles being so passe. After eating here that evening, I did nothing but thinking about their pickles. I've gone so far to pin several recipes to my Pintrest board, all featured that unique colorful combo of veggies. Now I just need to make it.

Unless, we make it back before the water is boiled to make the brine.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Really solid place with cool hipster antiquey decor.  I ordered the greatest hits using Yelp reviews as a guide and here are the results:
- Chicken Sammies: great, and even better if you use only one slice of bread
- Deviled eggs - with lime cilantry oil?  Amazing
- Popped elote: it's popcorn.  Surprisingly addictive, delicious popcorn.
- Spiced shrimp and grits: it's as delicious as the photo, which looks DELICIOUS.  Logic check me later.
- Pot de Creme: butterscotch, yes butterscotch.  YUM
author: Aaron M.

description:
My group all agreed that this gem of a place seemed a bit out of place where it's located in the mission. In the half a block I had to walk from my uber to the restaurant one of my trusty flip flops gave out on me and I had to slide my way to the restaurant since hopping in one flip flop isn't an option when you're 7 months pregnant. Fortunately my colleagues came to my rescue and bought me a pair of comfortable new flip flops at one of the surrounding stores for only $4. Score! 

Once I had shoes we met our lovely waiter. His name is escaping me, but he is the proud older brother of the chef. In fact, when we asked for recommendations of what's good from the menu we discovered there isn't anything he does NOT like. And so we ordered a bunch of things to share...at least to start. All of it was good, but my favorite was what we named ourselves as fish balls. 

We opted for our own entrees and I got the  pasta option. It usually comes with pork cheeks, but no thanks for me. It was still very flavorful without the pork cheeks.  

No good meal ends without dessert. Since our waiter hadn't let us wrong get we asked him to put together a few desserts for our party of 7 which included some donuts, butterscotch pudding (yum) and something else that is escaping me but didn't keep me from eating it. 

It was a very leisurely meal. By the time we left several hours had gone by yet we didn't wait particularly long for anything to come back. 

Very enjoyable and I wish all the luck to our waiter's little sis! I can see why he's proud.
author: Andrea R.

description: Had lunch here last week and it was a huge disappointment. Shared the chicken sammies which were ok but no big deal. The chicken was crunchy but a bit dry and without much flavor. This was the appetizer. I then had the lamb sandwich which was not that good. The bun was hard and the lamb didn't have much flavor either. There wasn't much lamb in the sandwich anyway. My friend got the pozole and she said it was ok but nothing to brag about. All in all a disappointing experience specially after seeing how highly rated this place is on yelp. Not recommended.
author: John S.

description: I seriously recommend the fried chicken wings. So good and crispy. Very nice atmosphere as well! The service was great.
author: Laurel W.

description: First visit.  Loving the snacks and small plates!  Mrs. adored the Mission Statement (cocktail with whiskey and grapefruit).  Kids ventured out comfort zones and found new favorites.
author: Mike G.

description: This place was extremely mediocre. Our waiter was very pleasant and attentive but that's the best I can say. The deviled eggs were way too oily and nothing special. My wedge salad was blah. My girlfriends egg and cheese sandwich was plain. I would not go back nor recommend it to anyone.
author: Rude G.

description:
Thursday night, my girlfriend and I wanted to catch up over dinner and drinks. We arrived at 6:30, the place was nearly empty. Service was good, not exceptional.

We started with the mgp chips and dip and kale and manchego dip. The chips were great, the dip for them was interesting but too creamy and heavy, even though the horseradish spice was nice touch and gave it a kick, the flavor was good but not the heaviness. The kale dip was strangely sweet but light, interesting dish but not something that worked flavor wise.

The mains we got vegetarian skillet dish and pork cochinita. The skillet lacked flavor, my friend only ate half, being a vegetarian she's always limited on dishes, it also didn't look well played, basically a big pile. The pork was beautifully cooked, the tortillas with it were thick and it was basically all there was, I would have liked some vegetables paired with it, bread and meat is not my idea of well balanced dish. 

I was surprised by all the high reviews, that was not my experience. The wines were also pricey.
author: Inga W.

description:
Myriad is true to its name with an extensive beer and wine list and a well thought out seasonal menu that offers a tantalizing array of snacks, small bites, and larger entrees. The atmosphere is very...Mission. It's a compact, but open space with high ceilings and black and white tiled floors, mixed with hints of hipster. 

The bone marrow was absolutely delicious with the sherry demi-glace and tarragon-horeseradish gremolata smeared all over a delightfully crunchy sourdough crostini. It was buttery, flavorful, and beautifully plated. It was a little pricey for only one piece...but if you love marrow this one's a winner. 

Arugala, snap pea, and jicama salad w/ cumin-lemon vinaigrette was light and refreshing with great textural balance. Not super memorable, but then again...most salads aren't! 

The grass-fed beef burger was a bit disappointing for me and I wasn't a fan of the steak fries. I know they're supposed to be thick and meaty, but I felt like I was eating a baked potato. They lacked the crisp edges I was hoping for and it was very heavy alongside the cheeseburger. The MGP sauce was tasty though (think super awesome In-N-Out spread). 

Myriad has a unique cocktail menu with drinks like the Eastern Orchid with soju, lemongrass, ginger, and lemon, and the Black and White Ball, which has guinness, sparkling wine, and blackberry. Need I say more? 

Service is attentive and relatively friendly, but it felt a bit rehearsed. Prices are ~$10 for appetizers and $20-30 for entrees. I found most of the dishes average, but I did order rather lightly that night. I'd be willing to come back to try the salt cod fritters, spiced shrimp, and pappardelle pasta w/ pork cheeks. Overall, *3.5 stars* but I'll round up to 4 since they're new!
author: Deanna Y.

description: Brunch was absolute delicious. The grits were creamy, and went perfectly with the kale, English peas, mushrooms and poached eggs. Service was a bit slow but very warm. Plus for having reservations so you don't need to wait for a table on a Sunday which is always appreciated.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
OH EM GEE, I WAS IN FOODIE HEAVEN at Myriad. I did not try one thing that was even somewhat average. Everything was absolutely incredible {including the service!}. I loved their trendy, rustic atmosphere and even got some inspiration for my house! 

For snacks & small plates, we split  the deviled eggs, farm toast {Aaamazing, the perfect combination of sweet & tart}, bacalaitos {Adult fish sticks in the form of balls aka perfection} & grilled peaches {I'm totally making this at home, best idea ever!}. I would highly recommend all 4 of these dishes. 

For my entree, I ordered the grilled hanger steak and it was off the charts. If you are a steak lover, this dish is a must. It had a Spanish flair with one sauce that very closely resembled chimichurri. YUM, my mouth is watering just writing this. I almost {literally} licked my plate. For dessert, you cannot leave without ordering their butterscotch pot o' heaven.

They have a unique cocktail menu that was really impressive. They only have a beer & wine license but somehow created the most sensational craft "cocktails" using an impressive list of ingredients. Don't come here planning to get a plain ol' gin & tonic, but something even better!

Enjoy! You really can't go wrong with anything off of their menu!
author: Hailey P.

description: Excellent and interesting food. Top notch service. We forgot to disclose a peanut allergy and the chef remade the meal even though it was our fault. Some guests knocked over a glass water carafe and smashed it and the staff, again, was more concerned about putting its customers at ease than anything else. Great lamb sandwich, hangar steak, and the desserts are divine. We'll be coming back.
author: Beverly F.

description:
Myriad Gastropub was a nice surprise for a Sunday night. I am not usually a gastropub guy.

Prompt service, the salmon and brussel sprouts were great and distinct decor. I definitely recommend!
author: Alex G.

description:
The food is great and the service is amazing! Ross, our server, was super accommodating for all of our requests. 

The brunch menu is great and has options for everyone from sweet to savory. Great location and a nice interior looks pretty new, super comfortable and bottomless coffee, it was fun.
author: lorenzo f.

description:
Very reliable for dinner in the Mission! The food is high-quality, and the menu is diverse and great for people of all walks of life

I've been here multiple times and the service has always been friendly and really great!

The deviled eggs are really great. Every time I bring someone new to this place they always want to order more! The crispy shallot on top is sooooooo the cherry on top but for an appetizer. They can be ordered individually, so I recommend trying at least one.

The farmer's toast is awesome! That nectarine preserve is soooo yummy and all of the flavors come together so nicely! MUST order.

I always order the chicken liver mousse because I LOVE chicken liver mousse and Myriad's is one of my favorites in SF! Get extra toast :)

Good dessert options that are always delicious.

Great drink selection - I've enjoyed all of the wines and rosés I've had.

Pro Tip: Get the MGP fries as an appetizer - they rule and everyone will want some!!
author: Taylor S.

description:
3.5 STARS for an expensive upgrade from Nombe.

Myriad Gastro Pub apparently does not know how to spell "gastropub". They're a new establishment which took over Nombe, a struggling Japanese restaurant on 21st and Mission.   They offer a small selection of small and large plates, but most things were on the smaller side especially given the price. They have a cool looking, but OK tasting cocktail menu, and an extensive wine list which unfortunately did not meet expectations. Also, I want to say I was NOT a fan of the service. Overall, the food and drink were above average, but way overpriced.

* WHITE OAK CABERNET SAUVIGNON ($17) - 3.5 STARS:
The by the glass wine list is a decent length, they had two cabs and a malbec which piqued my interest. The White Oak was my favorite, compared to the Malbec, but was so expensive and not worth $17. The wine also came out very warm, and the server was unapologetic.

* GAIA MALBEC ($12) - 3 STARS:
Not a terrible Malbec, rich and a little sweet. $12 was too steep for the caliber of this Malbec.

* FRIED CHICKEN SAMMIES ($11) - 4 STARS:
Two small fried chicken sliders, and a side of pickles for $11. Kind of steep, but a tasty way to start the meal. The chicken was nice and crispy on the outside and tender on the inside, served with a sesame bun and a flavorful chipotle mayo. 

* ARUGULA SALAD ($10) - 3.5 STARS:
I thought this was a very nice, refreshing generously portioned salad. It's not unique or special, but a good filler dish. 

* BONE MARROW ($11) - 2 STARS:
99% bone, 1% marrow. 

* DEVILED EGGS ($2) - 3.5 STARS:
Pretty good, really expensive, deviled eggs. $2 for a HALF of an egg. 

* PAPPARDELLE with PORK AND MUSHROOMS ($22) - 3 STARS:
I love a good pappardelle, but this one was not al dente enough for me, and the flavor overall was too bland. 

* ROASTED HALIBUT ($30) - 4 STARS:
A really nice halibut pan fried and crispy on one side, and served with a deliciously savory concoction of fresh corn and clams. I loved the sauce and the flavor of the dish, but again $30 seemed way too steep for this dish.

* COCHINA PIBIL ($19) - 3.5 STARS:
Tiny. Portion. Better off going to a nearby Mexican restaurant. 

* HANGAR STEAK ($25) - 4 STARS:
A decent portion of perfectly executed hangar steak. I really enjoyed the steak but the potatoes were very forgettable. Overall though, a winner for $25 if you're looking for a meaty dish.
author: Jess C.

description:
Had dinner here with friends a few weeks ago. This place is very cute inside, I was surprised they didn't have more people in there. 

We started off with a few drinks. Their drinks are decent but a little pricey, considering they don't use hard liquor, but use wine (they don't have their hard liquor license)

We started off with their special appetizer, which was grilled peaches and goat cheese , and it was delicious. I had their salmon- yum! My friend had their salad and tomato soup , which she raved about  (as did her boyfriend). My husband had the pappardelle with pork. 

Overall- I would be back for dinner or brunch.
author: Tahima B.

description:
So I've been wanting to try this place for some time now because the food looked amazing, so when it came time to celebrate my parents 30th anniversary I couldn't think of a better place. We made a reservation for 6, but 8 showed up and they accommodated us with no problem since it was a Monday night. Before sitting down we ordered drinks from the bar tender, who ended up being our server, which I found interesting. He was very nice, but my husband and I did not enjoy our drinks (they were too citrusy and mine had a strange after taste. I would recommend getting  wine or beer instead.

Shortly after being seated we ordered some apps: fried chicken sammies, bone marrow, shrimp and grits and the cheese and bacon covered fries. Everything was good, but my favorite was the shrimp and grits. Every time I've had this dish elsewhere the grits have been super heavy and grainy, but these grits were smooth, fairly light and cheesy. Awesome dish. The bone marrow wasn't bad either and the sauce/ gravy was awesome to dip bread into. The other two dishes were ok, but didn't compare to the others.

For the entrées my hubby and I ordered both the salmon and vegetarian squash dish. The salmon was cooked perfectly and had nice, crispy skin on top surrounded by lentils. The squash dish had string beans and garbanzo beans with some breadcrumbs on top, which was a nice touch because it added some texture. We barely had any room for dessert, but tried the chocolate sorbet anyway. I didn't really care for it because it was strangely spicy and had a weird texture, but my dad tasted it and loved it. The dessert I wish we'd ordered was the pot de crema (?) because I had a taste and it was awesome!!

Overall the service was attentive and they always cleared our table and kept our water glasses full. The food was also timed really well. I wouldn't hesitate to come back!
author: Steph L.

description:
3.5 stars

I am surprised at how my observation of Myriad Gastro Pub and that of Yelp's consensus is so different.

There are some wonderful dishes but most of them are mediocre and overpriced (yeah I get it ... it's the mission and everyone has to pay a premium to be here).

Their version of bone marrow with sherry demi-glace, tarragon-horseradish gremolata, sourdough toast points (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/myriad-gastro-pub-san-francisco?select=yhYsu-7HPr0qdPB7D5NFaQ) was absolutely spectacular. The flavor, texture, and taste unbelievably good

The grilled frog hollow peaches, goat cheese mousse, toasted hazelnuts, micro basil (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/myriad-gastro-pub-san-francisco?select=NiO9E52bO2VfdSd2uwsedg)  was another spectacular dish. Anything from the farmers at Frog hollow I am in love with....this dish just puts them all together in a surprising and refreshing new way. Textures were just awesome.

The last dish that was phenomenal was the deviled eggs with salsa verde, breakfast radish and crispy shallot (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/myriad-gastro-pub-san-francisco?select=m38rlcHe3M8wlP7Fv7YybA)
. Not cheap at 2 bucks a pop....but the contrasting textures of the crispy shallot, the creamy egg, and the luscious salsa verde....just order a dozen and be happy.

....and now for the short comings.

cochinita pibil: mayan pork, sour orange onions, pickled jalapeños, green chile tortillas(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/myriad-gastro-pub-san-francisco?select=40mQF94k3zUYrJH8UwrKWg)....just a fatty piece of pork with minimal flavor and depth...a few slices of avocado, jalapenos, and onion. As a 19 dollar main dish this was almost insulting...think three tiny tacos.

fried chicken sammies, creamy mexican cole slaw, honey chipotle mayo, pickled veggies....you know when everyone raves about the pickled veggies the dish is in trouble. Just a very bland dish. Bread...meh. Fried chicken meh....no flavor, no texture....no bueno.

I must also point out that our server was a nice person but everyone seemed inapproachable....and almost put off and put out for having to work or be there.

There is also a vibe that is just meh. Perhaps is was how quiet it was there or some of my dining friends....it was sort of a buzz kill.

Maybe I would come back but with so many new places opening I would wait and see.
author: David G.

description: SO DAMN GOOD!!! Deviled eggs, pulled pork sliders, potato chips w/horseradish dip. All familiar dishes, but done in an elevated way. Incredible flavors and execution, beautifully presented. Not one dish was meh. Steak and fries, salmon to die for, Brussels sprouts like you've never had before! Butterscotch pudding was on point and also great wine list.
author: Srutih C.

description: Stopped in and tried out different menus items that were good and tasty. The place looks clean and new for being around for two years. The only small problem was my glass still had red lipstick and the nice waiter dropped my drink hitting my jacket. I will be back.
author: J B.

description:
Yet another restaurant that fell short of stellar Yelp reviews...

At $62/person after tax, tip and the mandatory 4% added for San Francisco employer minimum wage ordinance, Myriad was not worth it.  The food was average and the dishes were pricey.

Our party of four ordered 7 small plates to share.  I tried 4 of them:
*Bone marrow ($11 for half) - The standout dish of the night for me.  It had a nice sherry demi glaze and served with toasted sourdough pieces.
*Spiced shrimp and Anson Mills grits ($13) - I was in love with the creamy grits, but the five shrimp served on top of lacked spice.
*Crispy fried chicken sammies ($11 for 2 sammies) - They were good and this was my friend's favorite dish of the night.  The slider size sammies had a good honey chipotle mayo and served with a side of pickled veggies. 
*Deviled eggs ($2 each half) - It had a nice creamy yolk topped with salsa verde.  The crispy shallot gave a nice taste to it.

There was a big gap in timing between our appetizers and receiving our entrees.  We were seated in the back and I had a view of the kitchen.  I saw one of the kitchen staff looking at our table noticing that we weren't receiving our entrees.  After about 20 minutes of waiting, our entrees were finally served and it was disappointing.  You could tell that the kitchen rushed through our dishes.  I ordered the pappardelle with pork cheeks, peas, mushrooms and kale ($20) and it was barely warm.  The pappardelle wasn't cooked all the way and you could tell it sat there awhile from the way the pasta in the middle was dry, sticking together, and was slightly hard as I chewed on it.  One of my friends ordered his burger medium rare and it came out well. 

Our server was helpful and made sure that we had enough toast points for those appetizers that required them.  It was a bit annoying that he would tell us our entrees would be a few more minutes while we waited and waited.  

WHAT TO KNOW:
*Reservations can be made on Opentable
*Wine and beer, no hard liquor
*Street parking which can be difficult to find
author: Nicole S.

description:
Tried the chicken sliders , potato skin French fries, and the deviled egg.
The food was delicious with tons of flavor. A little pricey for the portion in my opinion (The chicken sliders appetizers came with 2- felt a serving of 4 would be appropriate if we had more than 2 people and were sharing.).

The beer selection was great - if you're into IPAs like I am they had 2-3 on tap that were good.
author: Giants F.

description:
Steak was good, beer was good, cocktail was more citrusy than preferred, and thai wings were not that good.
The place is nice overall and not crowded on a Thursday.
author: Abdullah K.

description:
Hmmm...I'm torn about this place.

First time I stopped in for a late afternoon drink and the second was a few days later with a group of 5 good friends.

We ordered a number of items:

Deviled eggs
Fried chicken sammies
Chicken liver mousse
Farm toast with goat cheese
Chicken wings
Olives

The best items were the deviled eggs and the pate. The eggs were especially crafted well and certainly had a "zing" factor. I like the pate and they gave us unlimited toast with it too. The rest was just ok. The farm toast was actually a bit soggy,

The thing that gets me is the prices. When I came in earlier for a drink they were charging regular prices for their "happy hour". I could go down the street to Rosamunde and pay a $2 less for the same beer. And then on top of the higher prices, they add a tax on the drink. I have a pet peeve about joints that add a tax to their drinks. Just add it into the price of the drink; don't add a tax after the fact, it's just a sneaky way to serve alcohol.

So the all right food and the high prices yields a 3 star review. The service was fine each time but I'm not sure if I'll be back any time soon.
author: Art O.

description:
I'm going to be generous and give them a five because I thought the service was excellent.

They go above and beyond.  My friends and I like to share and they plated our food individually for us.  It's not necessary but it's kind of nice.  Not sure if they always have time to do this but they did it for us and I loved how clean it was.

The food is also pretty great, I would say 4 stars at least for what we had which was the burger among other things.  The quality, favor, and presentation was all there.
author: Phillip N.

description:
A new gastropub in the Mission with awesome reviews on Yelp? I had to give it a try.

This is going to be a more extensive review, because well, I think Myriad is deserving of one.

Food Highlights:
- Pappardelle with pork cheeks, peas, kale, mushrooms: rich and flavorful, with generous portions of tender pork cheeks and a spring vegetables
- Halibut & clams: this one's for the seafood lover. Fresh filet of halibut with a perfectly seared golden skin, topped over a dreamy broth of corn and dried tomatoes   
- Shrimp & grits: you can't really go wrong with shrimp & grits but the grits here is buttery and captures the flavor of the shrimps really nicely
- Any dessert that speaks to you. I loved the butter & scotch pot de creme & stone fruit crisp with ice cream

The cocktails were fruity, refreshing and light. Think this place only has a wine & beer license, so not a full bar here. (Side story: my friend who had a very long week was not amused.)

For our group of 5, we were recommended to order 6-7 small plates to share and individual large plates. We were hungry, but even our hungry minds thought that was a bit much. We toned it down to 3 small plates and individual large plates, and we were absolutely stuffed.  

A few small service speed bumps along the way, which would normally notch the restaurant down to a 4, but given this place opened mid-June, I have high hopes things will only get better from here.

Robust flavors, fresh seasonal ingredients and modern / casual atmosphere. Will be back to try more of the decadent desserts!
author: Linda X.

description:
I can't even remember the last time we had date night and we don't even have kids.

I blame it on Mr. NSS who wants to bring Tater Tot (TT) everywhere. He loves that dog to pieces. Recently, while at Pet Food Express, I was at the freezer section getting TT's raw food. When I turned around, Mr. NSS had TT in a display stroller. He sped around the store like he was on an episode of Supermarket Sweep until they reached a burly man with a huge mastiff. He then tried to play it off as if I told him to do that. Dude, really? Nothing wrong with a straight main spinning around a girly dog in a pink polka dot dog stroller. Nope, nothing. 

We were long due for a date night so after tiring out TT at the dog park, we decided to check out the new restaurant, Myriad Gastro Pub that took over Nombe (opened on Wednesday, June 17th). Personally, I thought Myriad was more of restaurant that a "gastropub".  The global inspired menu is divided into snacks ($2-$7), small plates ($8-$14), and large plates ($14-$28). I read that the chef is from Thirsty Bear, Ramblas (tapas), and Momo's. No hard booze so there's only beer, wine, and loophole cocktails. There were more wine varieties than beer. Expect to spend around $50-$60 pp for a full meal plus an alcoholic drink. 

I started with the Eastern Orchid Cocktail: soju, lemongrass, ginger beer, lemon ($9): http://bit.ly/1Je2rrw. It was really refreshing but a tad too sour for me so I got a glass of Malbec ($12) for my second round which worked out perfectly for the meatier entrees. 

O U R  O R D E R
*Deviled Eggs w/ salsa verde, breakfast radish, crispy shallot ($2 ea): 3.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/1N0NnLK
Good amuse bouche type of starter. You can never go wrong with creamy yolks.

*Spiced Shrimp w/ anson mills creamy grits, albariño-butter sauce ($13): 3.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/1Je21BB
I really enjoyed the tender shrimp that waere nicely spiced but the grits were curdled and gloopy. However, it had good flavor and was buttery so I wasn't about to let it go to waste.

*Bone Marrow w/ sherry demi-glace, tarragon-horseradish gremolata, crostini ($11): 4.5 STARS
 http://bit.ly/1FwyriQ
I normally like bone marrow simply prepared with some sea salt and panko but I really enjoyed the sherry demi-glace as it added a great depth of flavor and robustness. $11 for one halved bone was pricey though. 

*MGP Fries w/ smoky thousand island, bacon, cheese, scallions ($7.50): 4 STARS
 http://bit.ly/1FwyvPx
I like skinny fries so this was all Mr. NSS' dish. Think a refined version of In-N-Out animal-style fries but with potato wedges. The smoky thousand island dipping sauce was deliciously decadent. 

*Pappardelle w/ pork cheeks, peas, kale, brown beech mushrooms, tarragon ($20): 4 STARS 
http://bit.ly/1ft9M9O
Solid entrée but at this point, I was too stuffed and had to take most of it home. The several bites I had were delicious--al-dente pasta, flavorful, tender pork cheeks, earthy mushrooms, and some kale to cut through some of the richness. A very comforting dish.

*Grilled Hanger Steak w/ patatas bravas, cotija, romesco, salsa verde, spring onions ($25): 3.5 STARS
 http://bit.ly/1CoedHW
Nicely seared and tender but needed a tad more seasoning to bring out the beefy flavor of the steak. Patatas bravas were crunchy and soft inside. The extra smoky thousand island sauce from the fries made for a great dipping sauce.

*Butter-with-scotch pot de crème, brown butter sable cookies, crème chantilly ($7): 3.5 STARS 
http://bit.ly/1LfL9cU
More boozy than buttery. Nothing wrong with that, I just prefer more of a buttery, caramel flavor. 

Service was very pleasant and attentive. Everyone from the hostess, our waiter, and to the busboy was really kind. We dine like AARP members so timing of our dishes were just fine. We were in and out in a little over 60 minutes. 

Haven't been to Nombe in years but the new space looks a lot brighter and warmer. They've changed the light fixtures and replaced the boring black tables with nice wooden ones. There's two separate dining rooms so it's good for date night or larger groups.

Parking sucks in the area but thankfully there's a parking lot up the block on 21st and Bartlett.

 As we were finishing up dinner, we were deciding on what to do...

Me: "Wanna go see a movie?"
Mr. NSS: "Hmmm, only if you do."

Me: "Actually, I'm kinda sleepy after that wine. Let's just go home."
Mr. NSS: "YES! I was hoping you would say that--I can't wait to see TT!"

This guy. =/
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Went for Saturday brunch with a friend. We both had the bloody Mary cocktail which was excellent.   I had the Shaksuka with chick pea flat bread. Hate to say, it was pretty bland. Needed seasoning, even salt but sadly there was no salt n pepper on the tables. The flat bread was seriously soggy by the time the order arrived. My friend had the fried chicken sammies. Now my friend is petite, but the sammies (2) are ridiculously small, about the size of a silver dollar. Two bites each, max. It was a bit of a shock to us both how small they were. We split a tres leches cake. Very very dense. Was Ok. Too many great places to eat in the Mission to go back. Service was beyond excellent. 5 stars for service.
author: Marguerite S.

description: My best friend and I dine around the city A LOT and we stumbled upon The Myriad after coming back home from a holiday trip. As soon as we arrived at the restaurant we were immediately greeted by the host. On our way to the table staff members were super friendly and greeted us, too. We felt so good to be there. We ordered and our food was absolutely delicious and everything arrived in perfect timing. We will definitely go back and recommend it to anyone who wants to have a great experience. I think it's our new favorite place.
author: JP P.

description: The food was fine. I think it's over priced but the ambiance is nice. The service was gruff and not what I expected
author: Johanah C.

description: I celebrated my birthday here last Saturday night with some friends and family. The food was tasty and the service was impeccable. I felt like we had a private wait staff at our beckon call. The only thing I would change would be to add some more beer to the menu, since I'm not much of a wine drinker. Some nice Belgian beer would be perfect.
author: J T.

description: Every dish we ordered was delicious! The Deviled Eggs first, then Popcorn (what?! So fun and tasty!) as appetizers, Coconut Ginger soup (my husband's fave), Thai Wings, and Farm Toast (my fave - bread topped with goat cheese and the perfect balance of sweetness on top). Friendly service as we meandered through our meal and chatted and laughed and enjoyed
author: Caroline H.

description: The Food was AMAZING. That's it. I can't say anything more than that. The service was IMPECCABLE. Again, that's it. You need to experience this restaurant for yourself. Absolutely delicious, welcoming, warm, hospitable, delicious, mouth watering, delicious(I already said that?). Please! Make a reservation NOW.
author: Carmen H.

description: I'm a huge fan of this place! Our server was super attentive, and did a great job of giving food recommendations. We started off with cocktails, and I had a tasty port-based drink. For starters, we shared the farm toast, which is a bit small, but delicious--the goat cheese and compote are great compliments. For my main, I had the lamb sandwich. The Moroccan jam was unlike anything I've had before and it went so well with lamb; I also liked that the lamb was shredded and spit roast style as opposed to a burger patty.
author: Benjamin A.

description:
Bottom line....Once you sit down you won't want to leave because you feel like you are at the home of your best friend!

The minute you walk through the door you enter another world. The atmosphere is warm and you are immediately welcomed in. 

The decor is gorgeous! If you look around, you notice that every detail has been thoughtfully planned out and meticulously executed. 

The staff treat you like old friends! They are charming, attentive, knowledgeable, hard working, and genuinely enjoy what they do. 

The food!!! We had the Shakshuka - a Tunisian poached egg dish with chic pea pancakes. A dish I've never heard of or tried before but enjoyed immensely! The grass fed beef burger was delicious and every bite was thoroughly enjoyed!

I highly recommended this fabulous gem!
author: Amy C.

description: They have a very limited menu between lunch and dinner (happy hour) which was annoying. Beer and wine only. Sat in the porch and ate some deviled eggs (I've had better) and some tiny chicken sliders (they were great). The server was very nice. The people watching from the porch was good but a little sketchy.
author: Adam W.

description:
1.5 stars. I'm rounding up to a 2 for my own sanity because this trip was a gift from my boyfriend before starting a program and I really, really wanted to enjoy myself. I did my research and ooh'd and aah'd about this place to my boyfriend based on the reviews and the menu. So I'm going to pretend this wasn't as bad a decision as it turned out to be.

The food was so underwhelming. We ordered several dishes but with the exception of the Thai fried chicken (loved the nice thin breading on it and the sauce) and the pickled veggies that came on the side of the sammies (nice tanginess and they managed to keep them crisp), I didn't care for the rest. 

The house made ginger soda was meh. The deviled eggs were served in a cold, small cast iron plate with olive oil on the bottom... Not sure why but it made them slippery and frankly detracted from the balance. Egg yolks in deviled eggs are rich enough on their own. 

The chicken sammies were $5/each at happy hour and I jokingly said, "Oh we could have had an in n out burger for this price!" and man I wish we'd done that instead. The sammies were on the smaller side of sliders and the chicken patties were too thin to retain any moisture. I could have been eating tofu and been none the wiser. 

The sherry sauce in the marrow was good but the marrow itself could've done with a tad more roasting and perhaps some flakey salt on top? It was just bland and unexciting and I felt like the sherry sauce was there to compensate for what was amiss.

Service was fine. They were attentive and accommodating.

Overall, the place was very promising but it just fell short on a little bit more thoughtfulness with the execution of the dishes. I won't be coming back.
author: Felisa D.

description:
This place was so good! We were actually a little shocked, given the excellent food, reviews, and Check Please Bay area nod that it wasn't totally packed on a Friday night. Maybe it's not quite close enough to the Alamo Drafthouse for people to have found it yet, but seriously...delicious and in a price range that's perfect for an slightly fancy elevated neighborhood spot. 

There was a vegan curry on the menu that night, but the waiter was very helpful in explaining that many of their items can be tweaked to be vegan or vegetarian. So instead of the curry I had the pappardelle with chard, pecorino, etc..and then the chef added fresh corn and salted butternut squash in place of the advertised beef cheeks. The portions are not gigantic, but everything is so filling and hearty that we were glad we had restrained ourselves to just the entrees and an order of the chips.  That left room for the tres leches desert which is now the second favorite version I've every had (R.I.P Platanos and their abuela's tres leches).

We will be back to try all the things we didn't have room for in this go round.
author: saru k.

description:
Awesome bar food/finger food that's a little more interesting than your typical burger and fries. We loved the thai wings, mini chicken sandwiches and ecote popcorn. The happy hour menu from 3-6 is a pretty good deal, with select snacks and drinks for $5.

Definitely recommend myriad if you're looking to split a few appetizers and grab drinks with a friend!
author: Sara M.

description: Oh my holy freaking gawd!!! Came here for brunch and can't wait to come back for dinner! Service was A+. I had a single deviled egg for $2, well worth it. Though not on the brunch menu that made the side of Brussel sprouts w butternut squash, cranberries and sage, outta this world. I had the lamb sandwich sans bread w the Moroccan-tomato jam. Jesus, Mary and Joseph, sooo tasty! Hubby had the pork hash and loved it. We'll be baaackkkk!
author: Ottis M.

description: Amazing deviled eggs! And really great service. I asked about the campanaro and the host described it much detail and even brought me a small glass to try.
author: Siri W.

description: Great food and ambiance. Everything we ordered was solid. Good for group or date night.
author: Ran X.

description:
Myriad is solid. No, I am probably not trekking across town or waking up at midnight to try and book reservations. But, is it generally a good option and are there times when it's a perfect fit? Absolutely. 

- large group meal - almost always space (and reservation availability) even on fairly short notice. Menu is approachable, and solid.
