- Reasonable price tag - ordering burgers and sandwiches you can get out for under $25 a person with tax and tip, shared appetizers and some people getting beverages. It turns out this is pretty tough at a sit-down restaurant in San Francisco these days!

- brunch - they take and have reservations for brunch!!! Really hard to emphasize how hard this is to find for solid brunch fare in the Mission. 

- drink variety - they're doing a lot with a little (and by that I mean creative use of a beer/wine license). The Bollywood tea / egg white cocktail is better than many desserts I've had out. 

- nice space - despite being on Mission Street the interior feels modern and very clean. The restaurant itself is divided into a few individual spaces that make it feel intimate while still enabling quite a few diners at a time. If you're going with a 4-6 person party I recommend requesting the booth in the front.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Wow,
This place was really fantastic! My husband and I dined here for brunch & will most certainly be back.
We order the lamb burger- AMAZING. Comes with a very decent sized good salad.
Chicken liver- standard but what was really great is the manager (I think) who boxed it up for us also gave us more crostinis to take home as we had used them all.
The chive biscuits were good.
We ordered a salad but didn't realize that the lab burger came with a salad & the manager who brought the food over realized it was waay too much sad & offered to take it back & did not charge us.
The mimosa was standard & good plus only $5 during brunch :)
If we came back and ordered any repeat items, it would be the lamb burger for sure!
The atmosphere was clean & minimal in a good way.
The bathroom was clean, modern, & cute.
The service was truly the best!! They were attentive but not annoying & went out of their way to provide excellent service.
I can't wait to go back because so many things are their menu looked great!
author: Ashley G.

description:
My friends have weird ambitions, except I can't really say anything because I do too, but they wanted to try brunch places on a Sunday during Restaurant week. I was down since I'm always down to try more restaurants. 

Myriad was our first of two places Sunday morning. We started off with elote and biscuits. The elote is popcorn topped with lime zest and a bit of cheese. The popcorn was slightly stale (not all were as crunchy as expected) but still pretty delicious. The biscuits were delicious. They came with honey butter (one of my favorite types of butter) and cranberry compote. I do love cranberry and this was just the right amount of tart and sweet. 

From the menu we ordered the Mayan pork hash and the shashuka. Off menu we got the grits with a poached egg and kale. The pork hash was delicious especially with the smokey tomato salsa. I think that's the best part. The shashuka was interesting, but I didn't love it. The grits were SO good. I love kale and poached eggs and it's just delicious! 

Protip: get there early and you'll be the only ones there. GET THOSE BISCUITS.
author: Nina Y.

description:
4.25 stars 

I'm hit with déjà vu at Myriad Gastro Pub's threshold. Oh yeah, its former occupant Nombe was a dud, explaining why I haven't set foot in this restaurant, split into two narrow rooms, in years. 

Happy to report a delightful maiden voyage navigating through Myriad's "globally-inspired" menu. In fpx fashion, I was in a weird eating mood; no Large Plates appealed to me (though I could see myself indulging in this section next time), so I went with a Snack & a Small Plate. 

I started with Farm Toast, slathered with goat cheese, dried cherry & apricot compote, pumpkin seeds, crisp sage, & a drizzle of balsamic. Savory, tart with just a hint of sweetness. I chose Roasted Butternut Squash Soup as my entree, & enjoyed its buttery, complex flavors. 

Would absolutely repeat this exact order, but with so many other delicious-sounding menu items, I probably won't.
author: Fancypants X.

description: The food was really quite meh. Papa teller looked so good but had zero flavors and the apps I tried were as good as a deli.
author: S M.

description: Tomato soup and chicken wings were great. Attentive and knowledgeable server made excellent recommendations for dinner.
author: Lacey R.

description:
Came for brunch late Saturday morning. Brunch was satisfactory, but I will not actively look to come back. Nice for big groups as the tapas style dining and diverse flavors are fun to share.

FOOD: 
- French toast was the highlight--a petite cross of two flavor-packed pieces that went fast at the table. Quite sweet but not overwhelmingly so. 
- Farm toast was interesting, but more of a farm crostini given how hard the bread was. I personally would have liked the bread to be softer in the middle.
- Popped elote was underwhelming. I thought we were buying the larger kernel corn (Inca corn when sold), but it was just popcorn, stale from being left out and barely seasoned with the promised cotija and lime. It felt like a joke to be buying a small dish of it for $6.00 when corn is one of the cheapest crops in the states. 
- Papardelle noodles came out somewhat stuck to one another and gummy where they stuck--this happens when the pasta is not properly dropped/stirred in the pot when cooking
- Wine cocktails--as Myriad has a beer/wine license but not a liquor license, all cocktails are made with wine or beer. I found them to be too sweet and not as flavorful as they might be were they made with liquor. I think my expectations might have been tempered had they been more clearly marketed as wine cocktails. 
- Salads--I was surprised by the lack of fresh greens on the salad. Though all the menu items were thoroughly enjoyable, I might enjoy some mixed green or rocket-based salads to offset the more indulgent items (when I went, there was only an iceberg wedge salad). 

SERVICE: 
- Polite and friendly. Food came out in a reasonable amount of time, and we appreciated their willingness to add on items and accommodate late arrivals. 

AMBIANCE: 
- Myriad tries to reflect its diverse flavor influences in its decor. I would call it casual-upscale. There was little light in the morning, a disappointment on days when it's actually nice in SF! I imagine this would be a cozy place for an outing at night though.
author: Helen W.

description:
Came here for brunch the other weekend. I had been meaning to try out this place since it opened a few months ago. It's definitely one of the nicer, more modern restaurants on Mission. We made a reservation just in case, but it was actually pretty empty when we showed up.

They have pretty good drinks. No liquor license though, so all the drinks are pretty light and made with soju, prosecco, and the like - very appropriate for brunch. I had the ruby slipper, which was prosecco with lilet blanc, grapefruit, and elderflower. Based on the name, I had expected it to be a darker color and more grapefruit-y, but it was actually heavier on the prosecco with a touch of grapefruit and elderflower. I also noticed an iced coffee cocktail with stout, cream, and chocolate bitters, which sounds amazing. Gonna have to try that one next time.

We had the deviled eggs to start - DELISH. They had some herby salsa and crunchy shallots on them. It was well-flavored and not too eggy. The pork and potato hash and burger were both solid brunch entrees.

Overall, I would say this is a decent, low-key brunch place in the neighborhood. Nothing really stood out to me too much, but this would be a good option if you want to avoid waiting 1+ hours for brunch in the mission. I want to come back and try their dinner sometime though!
author: Tiffany P.

description: Visited this place with friends over a Friday night. We had a reservation for 6 people which is prolly the biggest reason why we picked this place - They take reservations!!! The Freshie is a great drink if you want to get the evening started. For small plates, we tried the spicy shrimp and grits, thai chicken wings and chicken sammies. Loved their grits and the sammies were okay. The food overall was about ok. The pork papperdelle had well cooked pork with fresh pasta but lacked flavour. I found the place a little expensive and did not think the food matched it.
author: Mrunal K.

description: Great food. Menu looks like a lot when you first get there but food was fantastic. No liquor (only wine and beer) which was unfortunate but wine list is robust.
author: Mike K.

description:
Finally was in the area to check out this place. Loved everything! Loved the cider, loved the little bites. Our server was fantastic, and I like the atmosphere. 

I love how Mission became a casual hangout spot with wonderful dining options. But I hate the lines! We need MOAR restaurants! (entitled millennial speaking here)
author: Anelya S.

description:
Came here for our monthly dinner out and we had a great experience.  Our group shared several dishes.

Deviled eggs-  loved them.  Not that expensive eithere.
Farm toast- absolutely fantastic.  One of the best things we had.  
Homemade potato chips- Not bad but also not amazing.
Crispy fried chicken sammies- Good.  Very tasty.
Roasted delicata squashes & broccolini- We were given this by mistake but ate it anyways.  I liked the squash but a few of us didn't love the beans on the bottom.
Pappardelle with pork cheeks- Loved it.  One of their signature dishes. 
Spiced shrimp w/grits-  Loved the grits more than the shrimp. 
Pan roasted salmon - Perfectly cooked.  Loved the lentils that came with it. 

We also tried two deserts:   The roasted apple crisp and a butter-with-scotch pot de crème.  The apple was a bit better in our opinion.

Overall we really enjoyed our dinner at Myriad.   Service was polite and efficient and the restaurant is nice and open.  We didn't feel cramped as is often the case in SF.
author: Brian P.

description:
Nice place. I learned about Myriad Gastro Pub from a co-worker. I bookmarked it and figured that next time I'm in the area, I'd check it out. Well, last night we had spontaneously decided to go have dinner in the city with friends and not being a fan of waiting in line, I checked out the reservable restaurant on Yelp. Top of the list: Myriad Gastro Pub! No sooner reserved than thought, we were already on our way...

The word 'Gastro Pub' evokes memories of the time I lived in London where these places are popping up like mushrooms after the rain. While this is technically speaking not a Gastro Pub, the menu and ambience certainly lived up to the name.
 
What I really liked about this place was the friendly service $ the manageable menu (not too many but only not too few choices). Our waiter walked us through the menu and pointed out his favorites as well as the popular items. I went for the Moroccan lamb sandwich and the devil egg. I really liked the sandwich, especially the side salad which had a lovely spiced dressing. All four of us were, unfortunately, a bit underwhelmed by the desserts.
author: Uli B.

description: Food was fantastic and so was the decor. We were sitting out on a chilly Sunday since we had our dog with us. When I went in anf asked for the order to be taken quickly so we can eat and get out of the cold soon, they seated us inside and even got a water bowl for our fur baby. We ordered deviled egg, the house chips, chicken sliders and veggie skillet. The food was delicious!
author: Bella S.

description:
Great service, great food, great drinks! Not sure our waitresses name, but she had short reddish hair tonight. Greeting, order, and check back with us were perfect.
The shrimp and grits and burger were insanely good. Burger was honesty in my top 5 burgers I've ever had; cooked perfectly medium rare, sharp cheese, soft bun, great fat potato fries covered in bacon and Parmesan. I wasn't starving and the richness of the shrimp and grits was perfect to satisfy me. If I'm in the neighborhood, I'll be back!
author: Lisa H.

description:
Good service, good cocktails. 

I'm not super picky as an eater but I don't eat cheese or bread, and try to stay away from fried food too. I really like to eat fresh veggies + chicken and seafood.

The menu was too limited for me to be able to have much choice after eliminating those options, but my boyfriend liked his food.
author: Julia O.

description: Great food and service. The farm toast, shrimp grits, market salad, chicken liver and wings were all good.  There wasnt anything I didn't like, and it was a lot of food.  Lots of other items on the menu looked good, so it'll definitely be worth another visit.
author: Debbie L.

description:
Pass pass pass 

We came here for dine sf week and after battling for a parking spot, we came into the cute restaurant. The service is good, ambiance is cool(darker and music st the perfect volume, where you can hear people at your table). 

The food, it was disappointing and overpriced. We got lunch and so t was 25 for a fixed price menu, where you had a few options to choose from. We got: 

Popped elote- I was really excited for this because I LOVE elote. But it was so disappointing. The popcorn wasn't hot and it was just meh. There was barely any cheese on it and barely any flavor. It was just meh, definitely not worth the full price 
Pickled veg basket- our favorite thing we got. super crisply and lots of assortment
Their biscuits- pass. It wasn't warm or flakey and not flavorful enough. They served it with butter and a very sweet beet jam. 
Deviled egg- it was good but had WAY too much oil on it. 
Brunch egg sandwich with potatoes- it was good but very small and resembled a McDonald's sandwich. I felt like they barely put anything in it. Potatoes were good though
Tomatoe shukashun(or something along those lines)- this as the absolute worst. It was like a can of tomatoes and two eggs in a cast iron and by it was like, I mean that was literally what it was. They served it with these garbanzo pancakes which were way too oily. They should have added garbanzos/cheese/or meat in the tomatoes and eggs. I barely ate any of it 
Cauliflower soup- it was decent but not worth $9. 

Overall I would just pass, it was edible but not worth it. Our bill was $66 and we definitely left a lot of food and can probably eat another meal.
author: Jenny T.

description:
* $111.00 for 4 cocktails, one snack, two small plates, one large plate and one desert. 

Pros:
* Super friendly staff. 
* Online reservations made things smooth and easy.
* Great service from the hostess, waiter, and bus-staff.
* Delicious food.  'Farm Toast' was amazing,  'Chicken Sammies' were awesome, 'Hanger Steak' was perfect, and the 'Butter-with-scotch' desert was so good we almost ordered a second one.

Cons:
* Overpriced cocktails by the volume.  Specialty cocktail was $10 for a 5.5 ounce coupe cocktail glass.  $8 Stout was not even in a proper pint glass.  It was served in a 10 or 12 ounce glass.
* The Bone Marrow small plate is very tasty.  But you hardly get anything with this dish.  Quantity to value is not there.   Do not order this. 
* Not only do I dislike that restaurants want their customers to pay for San Francisco's health care access program.  Myriad adds their 4% HSF fee after taxes.  I understand the city  charges businesses an hourly fee for each employee who needs HSF.  But, restaurants should simply raise the menu prices to cover the HSF costs.
author: Cap P.

description: Incredible food and service. The place was cute and clean. Seriously the best staff ever so patient and kind. The food was out of this world I finally had my first shakshouka here and it did not disappoint.
author: VANESSA H.

description:
I thought the food was pretty lack luster. The service was good (but overworked and therefore slow)

My girlfriend and I had the Cauliflower soup, the salmon with lentil ragout, and the doughnut like dessert.

The cauliflower soup was bland and unappealing. The word "gruel" came to mind.
The Salmon and the lentil ragout was pretty bland.
I enjoyed the doughnut like dessert.

Definitely don't plan to go back.
author: Lars Z.

description:
Solid brunch spot. Myriad is one of the nicer places on Mission St, but don't let the sketchy street deter you from coming here! The actual restaurant has a good ambiance, and is never too crowded.

We ordered the french toast and grits with vegetables. The french toast was quite a large portion, but I enjoyed every bite of the fluffy, fried bread. I loved the bacon and pecan pieces on top as well. The grits were amazing - a nice smooth consistency with fresh and interesting vegetables. If I had to pick one, I'd go with the grits!

I plan on coming again to try their dinner!
author: Claudia C.

description: Great place in the mission for either brunch or dinner.  Didn't have to wait either time I came, and thoroughly enjoyed my shrimp and grits.  No hard liquor license but they have wine, beer, etc.  Love the ambiance! Casual and cozy.
author: Susan W.

description: Cool place in the heart of Mission district. We booked a table for 2 at 7:30 but called at 7 asking if it would be possible to come at 8:30 instead. Team is flexible and says no problem. Nice! Service was good and cocktails tasty. Food was ok but I was not blown away by anything. Better go with friends than for a romantic dinner. It's perfect to have a few drinks and share small dishes but not so much if you want to have classic dinner.
author: Clémentine C.

description:
Stumbled on the place by accident. 
I wanted something light and fresh. 
This was the perfect spot.
I had the market salad and the toasted nut and seed bread with chai butter and buckwheat honey. Everything was delicious. 
Market salad has arugula, peas, asparagus, snap peas, celery, cilantro, radishes, spiced pepitas and a lemon. Cumin vinaigrette. So fresh and good.
author: Craig M.

description: Pretty disappointing given the high star rating and the price. The food was under seasoned overall and the lamb sandwich was very dry. You can get better lamb from a street cart that costs less than 10 bucks. I would not recommend this place given how many great restaurants there are in SF.
author: Andrea N.

description:
4.5 stars. Solid neighborhood place in the mission. The food is excellent, especially the cochinita pubil (very authentic mexican food inspired). There was a bit of citrus that gives structure and balance to the pork dish. 

other things that we ordered:
bone marrow - solid, one large bone marrow, like the sauce that they had accompanied it which cuts through the richness of the marrow

market salad with kale - interesting medley of californian ingredients

parpadelle with pork cheeks - super tender, pasta cooked just right.we devoured it within minutes.

Also the bottle of pinot noir from santa lucia mountain that we ordered was excellent. very smooth and balanced.

Pretty laid back during the weekdays - not a problem getting a reservation at the last minute.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Our biggest complaint is that the prices were extremely steep for what was served. We ordered the toast and it was literally one piece of bread (ONE!) ... normal sliced bread from a bag, nothing special.. with some toppings for $14 dollars. We ordered a salad that was overly bitter and sour (again, nothing special) not filling at all for $16. We ended up ordering a few more plates (the eggs and the chicken sandwiches). The chicken sandwiches were the tastiest thing although, again, not worth the price. We later went for a dinner in a more central part of San Fran and paid less but ate substantially more and certainly tastier food. Atmosphere at this place was also flat. We would not return here.
author: Alex K.

description:
Appetizer: farm toast & market salad. Farm toast was the best toast I've ever had.

Meal: veggie skillet (amazing mix of flavors) & braised pork (super tender & flavorful).

Dessert: creme fraiche ice cream & ricotta zepolles (best combination)

Best meal in the Mission in a long time.
author: Kim N.

description:
Nice atmosphere, attentive service, above average food. 3.5 rating.

I went with a group of 6 people on a Thursday night and found it pleasantly uncrowded but still lively. The drink and food menu is well curated with a nice selection of cocktails, wines, small bites and entrees. I'm not so sure if "gastropub" is the best way to characterize Myriad, as I think it's a little more sophisticated and upscale. It's still a great place to socialize on a date or with a slightly larger group for drinks and fun foods.

The menu is divided into bites, small plates, and large plates. I'm in agreement with most of the Yelpers that the small plates are better than the larger ones. The farm toast, salads, and my shrimp and grits were better than the larger plates such as salmon, steak, and burger. Some people in my company thought the food was a tad salty, although I enjoyed my shrimp and grits. 

All in all, I enjoyed my time at Myriad; the price and portions are all reasonable, the atmosphere is just dark and pleasant enough to be comfortable, and service was friendly. I'd love to come back for brunch!
author: Kate M.

description:
Came for dinner and my friend and I thoroughly enjoyed most of what we ordered. To start off our meal, we had the Deviled Eggs, Popped Elote, Spiced Potato Chips, and Bagna Cauda, and Chicken Liver Mousse. The first four came as a set with the restaurant week prix fixe menu. The pate was added as a gluttonous a la carte addition. 

Our runaway favorites were the popped elote and the chicken liver mousse. The deviled egg was pretty solid too, but nothing to rave about. We both weren't a fan of the horseradish-chive crema that came with the spiced potato chips - definitely a little too strong on the palate. As for the bagna cauda, I enjoyed most of the root vegetables. They were roasted nicely and pretty delicious, but they were also served over a severely burnt crostini, completely inedible.

For our entrees, my friend had the pan roasted salmon and I went with the pappardelle.  My friend could not stop raving about the salmon. It was buttery and perfectly flaky. She wasn't a big fan of the accompanying lentils though. I thought my pappardelle was done rather well. The pork cheeks were plentiful and fall apart tender. The kale, mushrooms, and peas also provided a nice change in texture. I cleared this plate with ease....very enjoyable in my opinion!

For dessert, we tried the pot de creme and the ricotta zeppoles. The zeppoles were delicious! Fluffy and not too sweet. The two accompanying sauces were also divine! I loved the bourbon caramel sauce but the chai creme anglaise also provided a pretty refreshing twist. The pot de creme was very smooth, but pretty rich in my opinion. The scotch undertone did help to change up the flavor profile though. 

All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed my eating experience at Myriad Gastropub. Service was also very friendly. Our server, Patrick, was very attentive and definitely made our dining experience very enjoyable. I would most definitely be open to coming back to try more of their fun, globally inspired menu!
author: Elaine Y.

description: Went there by change with a friend. Food was good, the burger well cook maybe too many onions in the burger, even the bun really tasty. Fries really big but super good. Service a little slow.
author: Cristina C.

description:
Pros: GREAT waiter, was super awesome - strong drinks that were yummy (loved the pomegranate + jalepeno cocktail they have if you like a kick in your drink), the fried chicken sliders are BOMB, and that's coming from someone who lived in TX all her life, the burger was also really good - solid food overall.

Cons: The portions are pretty small; the sliders are tiny & a bit pricey, but hey it's san francisco
author: Lianne K.

description: The pappardelle was delicious! Edamame is hard to get wrong but the sesame seeds and and vinegar made it delicious and unique. The deviled eggs were only above average and that was the worst thing I ordered. Will definitely return!
author: James H.

description: Great experience here. The menu is a little too precious and the vibe is a little too hip, but when it came down to it, the service was excellent and the food was super tasty. Loved my steak and the Irish coffee dessert was, uh, powerfully good. ;-)
author: Jesse D.

description: Great tasty food, prompt and very friendly service, and wonderful ambiance. We were on our way to a concert and coming in from out of town had had to deal with difficult traffic so had only enough time to eat and leave. It would have been great to enjoy an extra course and coffee. Next time; it is worth another visit.
author: Karen P.

description:
Pleasantly surprised by the food here! We were a party of 6 looking for a brunch spot on a Saturday and found this gem. 

Seated immediately. No line. 

The FARM TOAST!! - goat cheese, honey-sage roasted persimmons, pumpkin seeds, balsamic?! So amazing. By far my favorite thing so far. Perfect for sharing as an appetizer. Must try!

Mayan pork w potato hash - this was also super tasty and flavorful. Good portions and hearty!

Their Cheesy anson mills grits with sautéed kale, poached egg was cooked perfectly. The creamy grits and the runny egg. Yum. I added a side of bacon to add some meaty goodness to my meal. 

Saw my friend eat the French toast - massive portions! 

Only qualm was that it was a hot day and no a/c.
author: Juliet K.

description:
I really really wanted to like Myriad. Sometimes I get so tired of having to make reservations two weeks in advance just to eat and I appreciate the ability to walk right into a restaurant and enjoy a good meal. I thought Myriad would be it! 

The first thing I noticed was the awkward layout of the restaurant. It's comprised of two narrow spaces that certainly do not help the flow of the restaurant. Once seated, the service was excellent. I ordered the special cocktail of the day - some sort of watermelon sorbet slushy with prosecco. It was pretty tasty.

There are a few things that I can't help but order every time I see them on the menu. I always fall for the pork belly, short ribs, and pappardelle. In this case, Myriad offers a pork cheek pappardelle which turned out to be such a letdown. The pasta itself was too thin and lacking in texture. The pork was not as tender as I had hoped and the flavors from the pork and peas did not "seep" into the pasta. It tasted like two mediocre dishes on one plate.

Despite my lukewarm experience, I'd be willing to give Myriad another try.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Came here last Sunday. 
The ambience is quite charming. We four ordered biscuits, deviled egg, wagyu sandwich, shakshuka*2, and Mayan pulled pork.

The biscuits we're not as fresh as we expected, mainly because the texture was not very fluffy, instead it's more like staled bread. The herb flavor was not quite infused as well. The honey butter didn't really pick up the honey flavor. ( I thought it should be honey, correct me if it was just plain butter).

Deviled egg is absolutely spot on! 

The sandwich and pulled pork are very good. Except the the beef was a bit over cooked. And a little bit hard to chew.. 

The shakshuka (don't know if I spelled it correctly) has rich flavor of tomato and herbs, but I think they should have reduce the sauce a bit more, it is very liquidy, that made it hard to eat with the corn pancake thing they served on the side. I think by reducing the sauce a bit more will enhance the flavor as well.

The dessert - butter scotch pot de creme was very rich. I like the two shortbread cookies!
author: Yann M.

description: Wow. What a delicious meal. Service was excellent - attentive and timely. We shared the popcorn and potato chip "snacks" - yum! I had the fried chicken sammies which were perfect morsels of goodness. Loved all the pickled veggies, too. I ordered the side of Brussels sprouts and found myself shoveling them into my mouth, they were so good. Others had burgers and salmon and were making happy sounds while they ate. I started with the "Old Timers" cocktail - lovely with a sprig of thyme floating on the top. It was a bit loud and boisterous, but so were we!
author: Esther L.

description: Our server was spectacular! The missing star is not for lack of service - we had great conversation and he had lots of knowledge. The deviled eggs were the best I've ever had. I was a little let down by the rest of the food. It was good by all means, just not spectacular. The flavors did not come through in the dishes the same as they were presented on the menu. Would still recommend to friends, everyone is different! Give it a try.
author: Jaci F.

description:
Good food, drinks, and excellent service with a hefty price tag.  I tried two of their cocktails and really liked the Mission Statement.  It's supposedly their most popular drink--and I can tell why!  Nice mix of flavors and I could barely taste the alcohol (in a good way).

Bone Marrow - A lot of other Yelpers raved about this dish but I wasn't wow-ed.  It just didn't seem worth the price tag for the amount of marrow, although they did give us two halves and not just one half as other Yelpers had received.

Salad - They had a special salad for the night and it was incredible.  It had fresh figs, baby kale, proscuitto and a lovely vinaigrette to balance it out.  It was refreshing, light, sweet, and salty.  One of my highlights of the night!

Roasted Halibut - This was delicious and I had some food envy when my friend's dish arrived and I wish I had ordered it.  Flavorful and perfectly cooked.

Lamb Sandwich - I ordered the lamb sandwich just because it sounded so good and I love lamb.  I thought it was alright.  Not spectacular but also not bad.

Hangar Steak - My husband ordered this dish and seemed pretty satisfied with it.

Service and the atmosphere was wonderful.  But, when the bill came out, I was shocked by how much we had spent.  I think I would return for drinks but probably not for a full dinner with this price tag!
author: Jess Y.

description:
Excellent. Had the deviled egg, autumn gratin, crispy chicken fried sammies and the roasted butternut squash soup. We ended the evening with a chocolate sour cherry bread pudding. While we didn't have any main entrees or alcoholic beverages, EVERYTHING was delish and the ingredients were fresh. The portions were shareable for 2-3 people and priced reasonably. To top it all off, the service and hospitality, simply superior.  Everyone from the owners, servers, chef, were warm, welcoming, and caring. That showed in the quality of the food and entire experience. 

As for the setting, the decor is industrial rustic chic and the ambiance cozy. It can be the perfect semi-casual date spot or a place for an intimate group gathering. We, were just two friends catching up over a bite who happened to stroll in to this heavenly delight. 

Right now, we've only scratched the surface of this place and no complaints - not often you come across a place that. It's a new place, but worth a try at least twice more. Given seasonal changes to the menu, even a regular go to. 

Planning to come back for brunch with friends so we can share because the menu has far too many mouth-watering choices for me to only pick one.
author: Ritu M.

description:
I would give this place zero stars if I could.  I went here this past Sunday for dinner with a party of 13.  We all ordered drinks when we were first seated and it took about 45 minutes to get our drinks.  The food took another 45 minutes.  Me and my friend ordered the Hanger Steak and both of our steaks came out cold.  The entire time at dinner, no one checked up on us once.  Literally, not one time.  We didn't even get a chance to order a second round of drinks.  When the busboy came by to get some of our plates, we even asked him if he can get someone so we can order drinks and still nobody came by.  This was the worst service I have ever encountered at a restaurant.  

I really don't know how this place has 4.5 stars on Yelp.  It is very deceiving.  I wouldn't be surprised if a majority of these reviews are from family and friends.  The service was horrible and the food was very sub-par.

The manager tried to offer us free dessert, but none of us even wanted to stay there a minute longer than we had to.  He tried to tell us they were understaffed for the night, but that's inexcusable.  Learn how to run your establishment!  I would avoid that place at all cost.
author: Andrew N.

description:
The farm toast, spicy shrimp and grits, and the bone marrow were probably my favorite things there. We also ordered the pappardelle, deviled eggs and the grilled peaches with goat cheese. They were all disappointments. 

My friend came here when it first opened and raved about the pappardelle. When we went, the noodles seemed store bought and overcooked. No cheese was offered either like the pictures. The bartender gave us a dessert, the pot de creme which was delicious (because I criticized that my friend had way more bone marrow the first time and this time it was so skimp. However, the sauce was really good)

Overall, a solid place with good beer and wine selections. I would stick to their beers and small plates!
author: Joanna S.

description: Place is a home pub, with good food n mellow climate. Went here for SF restaurant week, n loved it.
author: M N.

description:
We came for brunch and it was a lovely spot hidden in the mission, easy to miss if you are not looking. My friend had a reservation, but it seemed that there wasn't a wait at 11AM.

For the 3 of us, we shared a few things: mayan pork and potato hash, french toast, and a chickpea dish. The portions didn't look that big, but we got pretty full and couldn't finish off the french toast. Each dish was unique and tasty in itself. I would definitely recommend a combination of sweet and savory. There are so many brunch places that I'd love to try that I might not be back here for a while, but I'd still recommend this to anyone.

One note: I didn't have the coffee, but my friend said it wasn't super.
author: Cynthia X.

description: Impressive service. Causal vibe. We enjoyed everything- especially the burger and pork shoulder tacos in chili lime tortillas. Pickled veggies are in most dishes. Fun bubbly flight.
author: Vicki L.

description: Here for brunch on a Saturday. Fast, tasty, healthy, delicious. Why stand in line across the street? Highly recommend.
author: Talayeh N.

description: I went to this place for brunch based on the reviews, and I was so pleased that I did.  The Beef Burger was cooked perfectly, nice and thick - not some flat, pressed patty at all. I had the grits, kale, squash and poached egg dish - which I would love to eat everyday. The grits were creamy and the roasted vegetables were succulent and seasonal.  The French Toast consisted of big, thick slices of challah bread topped w/ bacon and maple syrup - what's not to like!  If I'm anywhere near the Mission - I'll be sure to find an excuse to go to this place again.
author: DM Z.

description:
So it was date night and I was taken to Myriad Gastropub. My eyes got way bigger than my stomach and ended up over ordering for two people. On the bright side, it allowed me to try out Myriad's different flavors and dishes to get an overall sense of what's good and what's not. 

Deviled eggs- This dish is pretty good. It's definitely a must try but I wouldn't come back and order it again.

Chicken liver mousse- MUST GET. Their mousse is perfectly seasoned with the correct texture. The purple onion jam and super toasted crostini went extremely well with the mousse.

Bone Marrow- OMG, also a must get! It was so deliciously prepared with the best sauce combination ever. I literally used the bread to soak up all the sauce on the plate; it was that good!!!

Farm Toast- It was delicious although after having had the previous three dishes it didn't quite compare. I think if you don't get any of the rich dishes above then the farm toast would be good, but if you did then just skip this. 

Spicy Shrimp- At this point my date and I knew we over ordered but we continued on because the dishes just kept coming. The shrimp wasn't spicy at all although the sauce was good. The grits were amazing! The quality of the shrimp used was okay. I would probably recommend this dish just for the grits.

Bavette Steak- We ordered this dish medium rare but it came out more rare. That was okay though because I would much rather have my steak more rare than medium. The chimichurri sauce it came with was delicious, the roasted potatoes were crisp on the outside and super tender on the inside, and the patatas bravas sauce was addicting. This would be a good entree to get.

I think at this point in the meal I would've rated this place 5 stars. What dropped it down to 4 was when we were ready for the check. Our waitress was nowhere to be found so after 15 minutes of waiting we tried flagging down another waiter even though we knew his responsibilities was for the tables next to us. I think he saw us waving our arms and saying excuse out loud but he blatantly ignored us. It wasn't until another 5 minutes that we were finally able to flag down our waitress to finish our dinner service by retrieving the bill.

Even with the service mishap, I will definitely return due to the fabulous dishes Myriad provides.
author: Rosanna N.

description:
Great service.  Came at 3:30pm on a Saturday and found out they only have a happy hour menu.  

I got the bollywood drink which was a little sour but tasty.  My husband got another drink that was super sour.  

We shared :

deviled eggs: Loved the fried shallots on it, but yolk wasn't creamy and it wasn't salty enough.

Chicken pate crostini was really tasty.  loved this dish.  

Pot o' pickles.  I didn't try this, but my husband seemed to like it.  

Total for the bill was $50.  

A-ok in my book, but would I come back for 2nd, nothing really stood out for us to make this a repeat spot . Maybe for the crostini...
author: Vi Y.

description:
Solid new addition to the gastropub scene, a good blend of some inventive dishes and polished but unpretentious decor and service.

We started with the deviled eggs with crispy shallot and salsa verde.  They were delicious.  Love me some good deviled eggs.

Then it was onto the fried chicken sliders with slaw and pickled veggies.  They were a'ight. Nothing spectacular but their sauce (kind of a sweet chipotle mayo) made them a bit more tasty.  The pickled veggies were a nice touch. 

I had their burger for my main.  Also solid, but wouldn't crack my top 10.  Just a good overall patty + cheddar + brioche bun. Again, the sauce made it shine and this time was their MGP sauce, which looked and tasted the same as their chipotle mayo sauce. 

Service was excellent.  Would return to try more offerings, solid all-around.
author: Saminda W.

description: Fabulous food. Citrus salad pairs with their champagne flight was delightful. Husband loved his lamb sandwich and Belgian beer.  Lovely way to pass a Sunday afternoon.
author: Ursula M.

description:
This is a really lovely place. The decor, the service, the vibe, the location -- it's all exactly what you'd expect from a cozy, yummy, homey, yet lively joint to spend a few hours with friends or that very special someone. 

I took my team here for a team dinner and it was pitch perfect. The reservation via Yelp was smooth and they gave us a comfortable, spacious booth right by the window where we could settle in and test out all of their delightful dishes and drinks. 

We shared a bunch of small starters and mains with some of the many standouts being the divine deviled egg, the shrimp and grits, the mini chicken sandwiches and the scrumptious papardelle pasta with slow cooked pork cheek ragu. 

While the service may have been on the slow side for some Americans, us Europeans really enjoyed the relaxed pace of the meal and even closed the restaurant down! 

So if you're looking for a warm, cozy and delicious restaurant with a faint air of Europe this place is for you!
author: Zeva B.

description:
Yum - what a delectable experience! The restaurant is cute with a slightly odd configuration given that there are two separate, long skinny dining rooms. They have an interesting cocktail menu - I didn't have any cocktails but definitely worth trying at some point. 

We had the following (which are so in the order of my preference):

- Cochinita pibil which was the most tender, fall apart pork to make pork tacos
- Arugula salad: I know it seems weird to like a salad so much but it was so light and fresh and the dressing was perfect
- Fried chicken sammies: moist and juicy chicken with a good ratio of chicken to bun
- Bacalaitos: the salt cod fritters were tasty but not very memorable
- Ricotta zeppole: They were on the bland side and not worth the calories

I would definitely return and hopefully for brunch!
author: Wendy L.

description:
The brunch is incredible. I had the challah French toast along with the zeppoles to start and the French toast was the best I've had. Great presentation and the bacon bourbon syrup is very, very good. 

The service was awesome and very attentive.  This place is a gem in the mission. Highly recommend.
author: Charlie S.

description:
Huge disappointment. For the amount you spend, this place doesn't exactly have stellar food. Inadequate portions and not that inventive when it comes to the menu or the specialty cocktails.

You could definitely do better within 5 blocks in any direction. This place looks nice on the inside, but you'll leave hungry and slightly disappointed, unfortunately.
author: Andy A.

description: We've been here a couple times for brunch and really enjoyed it. They serve delicious food.
author: Mega Team R.

description:
I have been here on two separate occasions for dinner and have immensely enjoyed the food both times.  It's kind of hard to spot but look for the name on the glass windows.

Parking: 
Not too difficult, only street parking though.

Ambiance:
Hipster | Cool | Flattering lighting (on the darker side) 

Wait Staff:
The first time was for a birthday dinner with a party of about 8, and the food was great, but the waitress was sooooooo s....l.....o....w......  She seemed to be frazzled and a little absent minded, but a nice person nonetheless lol.   This was the only downside I remember because I enjoyed everything else. (one star off for her).

The second time I came the wait staff was totally on top of their game and food and drinks came at very reasonable times for everyone considering we were a party of about 10.  

Food: 
The food was great this time as well, I shared a tomato soup and the pasta dish and they were both great.  I asked for a side of bread for the soup and they were more than happy to accommodate me as well. 

The chicken sliders and chicken wings were said to have been good, and people seemed to enjoy their burgers as well.  Honestly, I don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu haha.  

ILL BE BACK.
author: Christina L.

description:
Met my besties for brunch on a Sunday on one of the hottest summer days in the city.  We shared the deviled eggs, watermelon salad, and I had the lamb sandwich.   My besties ordered the special of the day, a chicken bahn mi mini sandwiches.

The watermelon salad hit the spot on the hot day. Cool and refreshing, with a nice dribble of olive oil and black sea salt.   Very refreshing.

My lamb sandwich was tasty. The lamb was seasoned well and the sweet  onion accompaniment fit perfectly. My besties bahn mi sandwich was good, but they found it to be too livery.   When I took a bite of the of it, I thought the chicken meat tasted like the processed frozen chicken breast that you can buy from Costco. Not bad since that taste good, but an odd comparison.  

I really enjoyed my meal and would come back again to try the dinner menu.
author: Marck N.

description:
Myriad could be a good place to take an out-of-town friend and show what San Francisco's expensive toast is. Myriad's Farm Toast is "fromage blanc, sage-roasted plums, toasted pistachio," and transcends typical toast and makes for a great starter.

Myriad has a lot of small/medium portions of pricy but extremely tasty food. We split the Heirloom Tomato Salad with basil oil and burrata (the daily special) and the Farm Toast. There aren't many vegetarian options on the menu.

We walked in without a reservation around 6:30p on a weekday. We had no problem getting a seat. By 7:30, the place was bustling, and as more people find out about it, I'm sure you'll need to be more strategic about getting a seat. The service was great.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Friends and I booked a table and arrived for the SF Restaurant Week around 12:20 pm. The hostess was so kind and lovely, even though we ended up being a little late due to traffic!

First off, let me say that the ambiance is so different and clean - sort of hipster yet modern with their wooden tables and different artwork/ mirrors lining their walls - such a change from mission street. We each got an order of popped elote, 2 small biscuits with butter and jam, and a main course. I got the ham and cheese sandwich with home fries (the other choices were a pork hash and shakshuka).

The appetizers were pretty delicious - not life-changing, but enough to satiate the appetite while you wait for your main meal. My sandwich looked like a gourmet version of a breakfast sandwich.... but it tasted better than one haha~ the bun was similar to a hamburger bun, but light and fluffy (and buttery?)! The home fries were just ... potatoes... I used a lot of hot sauce to bring more flavor to my dishes. The other dishes looked way better in my opinion though.

For the pre-fix course meal, it was a little pricey, yet I can't complain too much because I ate everything that was given to me. If you want a standard brunch meal for the restaurant week, I recommend you come here! (My friends said their cocktails were delicious~~)
author: Soomin S.

description:
I had a great time here last night. I probably had an interaction with every member of the staff and each was as professional as the next: from the hostess, our awesome waitress, a man who seemed to be the manager who folded napkins when people left the table for the restroom, and the gent who brought us wine. So food highlights...honestly I trusted Yelp and wasn't led astray:

-Pappardelle with pork cheeks and peas
-Farm Toast
-Grilled Peaches
-Fried Chicken Sandos

No full bar but my husband enjoyed a tasty spanish white wine while I had one of their ruby port/champagne cocktails (true to what the waitress told me: "like the best sangria you've ever had")

Note: people around us also LOVE the Halibut and Clams as well as the seasonal app with heirloom tomatoes and burrata.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Seriously cool place to get dinner or bring a date. Once again, Yelp doesn't disappoint. Even though it was prime time on a Saturday night we were quickly seated and our server got to us quickly, explaining that the cocktails are made with wine instead of liquor. 

What does that mean for the cocktails taste you may wonder? I think it makes them better. They're less harsh, smoother and a bit sweeter as a result. Cocktails are easy drinking and very satisfying as a result. 

Next came the fabulous food. We ordered the deviled eggs and farm house toast to start. Both were superb. The eggs had onion ring on them adding a delightful crunch. The creamy texture of the goat cheese was offset perfectly by the dense bread and toppings on the toast. 

Mains were the chicken liver pate, shrimp and grits, and pork cheek salad. I can recommend all three heartily, but if you're unsure about whether you like pate skip it, the portion is hearty for those that do enjoy it (counting myself among that group I was pleased) but isn't great to sample. The shrimp were seriously some of the best I've ever had the pleasure of eating and the grits complemented them well with buttery cheesy goodness. Why hasn't the west coast caught on to the grits thing!? Pasta was very interesting, almost reminding me of a more Asian preparation, but noodles were perfectly cooked and the pork cheeks nicely seasoned. 

Definitely coming back here next time I'm in the neighborhood!
author: Ian G.

description: The two of us the devilled eggs, Thai wings and lamb sandwich with salad. It was really delicious and would definitely return here again.
author: Jane S.

description:
Such a cute gastropub in the heart of the mission! Found this place on Yelp (as usual) and will be sure to come back for dinner. We ordered:

Appetizers: Farm toast and spiced shrimp. The dishes are extremely flavorful. I would highly recommend both dishes, but the spiced shrimp was my favorite. The grits were so good I was tempted to get another dish.

Entrees: The salmon was okay, definitely good but nothing amazing. 

I think the "snacks" are the stand out dishes here. Get a bunch to share. And be sure to also get this caramel mousse/pot thing for dessert. It was to die for!
author: Mia B.

description: Great food such a wonderful surprise for a small spot but loved, loved it...and ambience was wonderful...
author: Tamara H.

description:
Upscale but casual restaurant with good, bold flavorful food. The service is a bit over the top for such a casual place. 

Our waiters and wait staff were constantly checking on us (every few minutes) but not so much asking how we were doing but really making sure to freshen up our drinks which was nice. They even refilled cappuccinos with black coffee.

Best food items were the fried chicken sammy and the lamb sandwich for brunch. The French toast was too heavy (not surprisingly for being bacon and bourbon).
author: Victor W.

description: Shocking this place has received so many good reviews. Just went here and the service was miserable, our drinks never came, had to ask, appetizers didn't come, had to ask and the food took over an hour from when we arrived. Also the food generally was not so impressive and was unnecessarily greasy. This is not a gastropub, its just a greasy spoon posing as something more. Will never come here again.
author: Peter S.

description:
come & eat, what they brunch
order French Toast just because
if it's Iced Tea I love
drink away

dedicate Mayan Pork hash
and hold plates closer as you nash
eat it today
find Myriad ways!

don't forget, there could bervice
a fourth star added for service
if I hanger so much more
that's why I taste

maybe they have it on their menu
overlapping items from dinner
ask them to make
find Myriad ways!

::harmonica solo::
author: Dan B.

description: The place was good. The staff greeted you right as you walked in. We started with the mission statement as a cocktail (even though they don't sell spirits) it had a great fruity taste.  For appetizers the farm toast and spiced shrimp were great! Our second cocktail was the Persephone's on fire which had a nice jalapeño kick to it. For our mains the pappardelle pasta and grilled hanger steak were cooked to perfection. I would recommend this place for a nice quaint place in the mission. It's not to fancy, but the food is on the fancy level. Cheers
author: Gavin A.

description:
Wow!  Myriad was amazing.  This was definitely one of the best new restaurants we've been to in a while!

The food was really outstanding! My husband and I shared a mix of both small and large plates:

- deviled eggs (excellent!)
- chicken Sammies (very flavorful)
- kale side (delicious)
- pork paparadelle (a great mix of pasta, kale, and tender pork - we loved it)
- cochinita pibil (tender, braised pork served with avocado and tortillas - great)

Our meal was really exceptional, and we liked everything we ordered (which doesn't often happen)!

The only disappointment was my Eastern Orchid soju cocktail, which I found too sweet.

The service was attentive and prompt, and the ambiance is elegant yet casual.

Overall, an awesome addition to the Mission!
author: Barnali D.

description:
HIGHLY recommended.  Beautiful food. Beautiful service.  Beautiful servers.  Beautifully appointed.  

My new favorite brunch spot...will be back many times to come!
author: titus W.

description: At first, it was strange having brunch here, it's totally done over and up and I felt like I had been here before somehow.  I finally realized this space used to be where Nombe was just last year!  Anyhow, we had a great meal with attentive service in a cool, cute atmosphere.  I especially loved their grits (creamy, tasty with lots of flavor) and side of Jersey bacon (special house bacon that's got a good punch to it!).  Easy to get to by BART.  Good solid brunch - I would come back!
author: Maile N.

description:
I just love this place. It is what a great restaurant should be. Comfortable, friendly,  elegant, and most of all delicious. I have been here five time now. There has not been a single thing that is disappointing. The deviled eggs are divinely devilish! The halibut is one of the best and unique dishes anywhere. The lamb sandwich should not be missed. Indulge yourself in the grits. The wedge salad is a classic that has come and gone but Myriad is bringing it back again!! What a great update spicing up the dressing and adding some embellishments to this classic. 

Now that you are stuffed don't miss dessert. The pot de creme and zeppole are the stars but you can't go wrong. Order your favorite. For you vegans and chocolate lovers the sorbet is better than any dark chocolate ice cream in town!!! No foolin! 

I'm heading there this weekend for brunch. 

Btw the wine selection is also great. Ask Adam for recos. He is the best.
author: Damon D.

description:
We were thrilled with the food and service at Myriad. 

Farm toast: loved the caponata, pine nuts, micro basil.
Cauliflower soup: creamy texture and delicate taste, with kick from harissa oil.
Market salad: Somewhat less compelling - the greens were not the best (lots of stems), and somewhat bland.
Hanger steak: Good flavor. Patatas bravas were inconsistent: some of them were undercooked, and the fry on the outside was a little weak. This dish needed salt, which they brought to the table when we asked.
Zeppole: these were amazing, better than the best beignets I've ever had. Sauces were so flavorful. The superfine cardamom sugar was a revelation.
Pot de creme: nice butterscotch flavor. Thyme shortbread was less special.

Our server did a perfect job of packaging up our separate dishes into courses and taking care of us. Ambiance was energetic and fun, albeit very loud.

Overall, we're super happy we came here and hope to come again!
author: Bryan C.

description:
Service was on point. Our waiter definitely worked hard...it shows when they are aware of your table! I think it would have been better if there were more waiters! 

Food was definitely good...small plates and starters stood out. But main dishes did not wow me. I might try the steak next time.
author: Thomas C.

description: Myriad is a great place for dinner! I went with a group and we all left happy and filled. The  menu is creative but not vegetarian friendly (unless you want to order multiples of a few vegetarian starters). Among all of us, we tried the pickled vegetables and edamame starters. the edamame starter actually ended up being my favorite thing from the night because the black vinegar + sesame oil + tougarashi sauce made it taste so so so good. for the main meal, we shared the crispy chicken sammies, which was thankfully not deep fried and overwhelming. the atmosphere is definitely date appropriate but the lively ambiance and open space layout also helps the restaurant feel just casual enough to be appropriate for a friends hangout. i wish Yelp let you give half dollar signs because i would consider this not quite 3 for dinner, but 2 dollar signs is a bit too low. I'd come back here for a special occasion or treat yo'self type of night. keep up the creativity, Myriad staff!
author: Meryam B.

description: Went for brunch. Waiter extremely friendly and considerate. Great food, service and the restrooms equal to the venue (a rarity...for the life of me why do testosterone screw this up?). Highly recommend.
author: Eric K.

description: We loved our dinner at Myriad Gastropub. One of us is a local and two are from out of town, but we just stumbled on this storefront place, which is attractively dark and friendly. The local is a vegetarian, and she had a delicious North African skillet dish, with chick peas, some kind of grain, lovely spices and creme fraiche on top.  It looked like a small serving but she couldn't finish it all, and that was with help from the other two of us.  We also tried a cheeseburger, which came with big steak fries, and a wonderful lamb sandwich on a bun, with grilled onions on the sandwich and a very nice little salad on the side.  All in all a terrific meal, with a very nice waiter.  Not too crowded early in the evening, not too noisy, but just right.  I'd go back tomorrow if I could.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: I ran right over here after reading a smashing review of Myriad on Mission Local via Twitter! Yup that's what I do. Amazing burger and chicken salad finely paired with a big hunk of Magnolia IPA what a great pairing!! Fine service and clean as a whistle coming back soon 4 more! Kudos & Kisses to the Cook!
author: Lisa S.

description: Went here for a birthday party, and it was there 2nd year anniversary.  Staff was wonderful, friendly and attentive.  Food was tasty, and healthy, but the serving sizes were on the small side.  Would recommend this to place to my friends. Appetizers were very tasty.
author: Patricia M.

description: Great gastropub with an amazing vibe.  The owner is delightful and the food is exquisite! So yummy. A must try!!
author: Karen D.

description: Menu is somewhat eclectic. I really enjoyed my pappardelle and deviled eggs. No liquor license so they're doing these wine cocktails which don't cut it. Service was very good.
author: Eric C.

description: Pretty fun place.  The pasta with pork cheeks was definitely the highlight.
author: Mark S.

description:
Everything about this place is 5 stars!! The staff is super friendly, the food is outstanding. Whether you are in the market for a quality hamburger or you (much like me) want something more carnal...and delicious .. Like Bone Marrow, this is the place. Myriad caters to several palates but perhaps not allergies because I LOVE garlic! and the special ingredient can be found in several dishes using class and Spanish flare as the chef/owner Trish is a true professional who knows how to blend the right amount into a special list of ingredients. 

Standouts:

Chicken Liver Mousse
Shrimp & Grits
Farm Toast
Pappardelle 

Oh and if you want water, ask for it. It's a new California law which I support, they can only serve it if you ask
author: Brielle J.

description:
Fun menu, cozy yet upscale, non-pretentious feel, great beer & wine menu.
Food is interesting & delicious. Staff was full of positive energy & genuinely accommodating
Atmosphere is warm & well-decorated.

Ambiance
Atmosphere is warm & well-decorated. Bathrooms were clean & stylish. Glazed ceramic brick tiles. Even the soap smells good. Music, as we found out, was hand selected by a local DJ with spanish roots. Wall coverings are really dope - had an aztec-y mosaic texture to it. Dining tables are reclaimed wood. The joint has a cozy yet upscale, non-pretentious feel.

Service
Staff was full of positive energy & genuinely accommodating.

Price - $$
Pleasantly surprised at the bill for the caliber & amount of food & beverage consumed.
I think the most expensive dish was $28 - which we ordered. 

Drinks
Forbidden lowball - like a really fun grown up Moscow mule

Orpheus - really well balanced, almost marshmallowy, like an old fashioned

Cabano - natural sweetness comes from the summer fruits. Really tasty. Effervescence is nice

Sandbar - tastes like a night time mimosa. Got a spicy orange flavor to it.

Baliwood tea - has a milkshake smoothie texture. Dangerously easy to drink

Canela y cereja -  cinnamon & cherry, refreshing version of a portuguese sangria


Food
Deviled egg
was the best G.D. devil egg I have ever had. It was really crispy & herby. The salsa verde really set it off.

Jersey wedge
Thousand island has a little bit of a spicy kick. Good amount of bacon & toppings in general. Lettuce was crispy & fresh.

Farm toast
I love grilled bread. Super seasonal dish. Plum syrup was special. Well balanced. Sweet & savory.

Kettle chips
Chips were extra crispy & not too thin...totally f'n addictive bro. Plenty of dip. The horseradish was seasoned appropriately and didn't produce that nostril flaring effect. Great flavor. Love the little dish pan it's served in too!

Shrimp & grits
Grits were rich, creamy & fatty. Shrimp was seasoned nicely & smoky. Spanish twist on a southern classic.

Halibut with clams
That broth! So delicious, just the right touch and blend of brininess, sweetness, and sourness.
Halibut was cooked & seasoned completely perfectly. This one left a flavorful memory.


Dessert
Butter scotch Pot de crème
Would never ordinarily order this one, but came at the recommendation of our friendly server.
Like sending silk down your throat. Super dangerous, just wish there was more cookies.

Bellwether Ricotta zeppole
So airy & fluffy. Love the duo of sauces. It's like a choose your own adventure dessert. Anything with cardamon is a winner for me.
author: Flynn K.

description:
Wonderful service and great food! What more can one as for?

The staff was very warm and welcome. They were super attentive to our four year old. They even made her a special noodles that she loved.

Wifey and I had the lamb sandwich and burger. Lamb sandwich was phenomenal - I loved how the sweetness in the sauce mixed with the gamyness of the lamb. The burger was very good as well.

For dessert we had the ricotta bignets - very nice. I'll be back!
author: Anwar H.

description:
I was looking for a place to grab dinner with an old friend. He also lives, breathes, and sleeps food like I do, so I knew I had my hands full when I was tasked to pick the restaurant. Fortunately I found Myriad and reservations were surprisingly a piece of cake on Yelp! 

Service was very attentive and the food hit the mark. We went with the following:

- Fried chicken sammies - Two sliders with super crispy chicken in awesome honey chipotle mayo with creamy cole slaw. Be careful when you take a bite into this one as the flavor (and sauces) are explosive, literally. One of their specialities here. The pickled veggies were also super yummy - friend and I had to avoid our forks both going after the last piece. Great start.
- Bone marrow with the sherry luge - Also solid. We used the toasted sourdough to clean up the gremolata and sherry sauce. Then you take the sherry and pour it down the bone marrow and into your mouth, kind of like drinking your alcohol of choice down an ice sculpture. I've never done the luge using a bone before but it was kind of fun and really helped cleanse the palate of the heaviness of the marrow.
- Roasted lamb sandwich - Their other specialty. Hard to choose between this one and the chicken sammies. The lamb is thinly sliced with some great flavors of caramelized onions, jam, feta, and cilantro aioli. Yummmm!
- Butterscotch pot de creme - The perfect ending. Not too sweet. Creamy and delicious spread over the brown butter cookies they came with. I could've eaten two of these by myself.
author: Janet Z.

description: Phenomenal brunch ! Have the Shakshuka - it's amazing . Deviled eggs are fun as well. Little underscored Gem in the mish .
author: Maya z.

description:
As much as I miss Nombe, this space's former occupant, I had a pretty good first experience here and will probably be back. 

Easy to walk in without a reservation, friendly service (if a little over-attentive at times), and helpful information whenever we asked for it (and sometimes when we didn't, but maybe that's just new-restaurant eagerness that will calm down once they're settled in). 

The food was also tasty, but we only tried the salt-cod fritters ("fritters" to me were flat growing up, but fried balls of mashed cod and seasoning are conceptually close enough) and the pappardelle, whose flavor was awesome but whose noodles were so long it was awkward to share/arrange without cutting them. 

I did really appreciate the waiter offered to add a 4th fritter to the appetizer for a small upcharge so we didn't have to split the third piece-- not a big deal with two of us, but will come in handy if we bring a group (it's always so annoying when a 4+ group has to split a 3-piece app and the restaurant's only suggestion is two full orders). 

A little pricey for everyday status (we paid about $30pp to share an entree and appetizer plus one drink each), but still, a delightful meal in my neighborhood. Dessert looked nice, too, but I resisted the temptation. Looks like they have brunch service forthcoming, too.
author: Krista L.

description: The food is great, the drinks wonderful the service friendly-a great place to drop in when you're in the neighborhood-and across the street from the trendiest movie house in San Francisco
author: David K.

description: Happy to get a last minute reservation here on a Saturday. It's good, but not great. Short menu. Expensive for what you get, eg 26 for salmon at a gastropub? Tasty but not memorable. All in all, it was ok.
author: Andrew K.

description: I've been here twice for brunch now and had an excellent experience. The food is great, there is an extensive list of cocktails/mimosas and best of all you can make a reservation-zero waiting in line. I'll definitely be back.
author: Jasmine A.

description:
I can't say enough about what a warm and inviting place this is! Chef Trish is putting together some seriously yummy comfort/chic food that is sure to satisfy. 

We came by the other day and ordered a myriad (pun intended) of small and large plates with a group of 8. They were more than accommodating for our large party, and the courses came out in a timely manner. 

Among the memorable dishes were the bone marrow, deviled eggs, cochinita pibil, and the amazing burger. There were such an awesome array of different flavors to choose from. 

Don't miss the excellent wine list as well, with very reasonable regional wine and bubbles.
author: Isaias G.

description: The place is quite cozy and a great place for a casual night out. The staff is really friendly and provide great service. The menu is split up into appetizers, small plates, and large plates, perfect for any size appetite. I order the Crispy Fried Chicken Sammies and tried the steak fries and spicy shrimp & grits. Everything was absolutely fantastic! Really good seasoning on the fries and amazing sauce on the chicken sammies. A must stop if you're in San Francisco's mission district!
author: Trevor P.

description: Just came in for happy hour--the $5 drink/snack options are awesome! Great ambiance and excellent service from the bartender on duty (Mon. 02/20, 3-4pm).
author: Joshua K.

description:
I didn't plan on going to Myriad the night I went.  I was off to Alamo Draft House--not sure if I could eat there (outside the theatre) as I had a 10:30 pm seating.  The bar was uber crowded so I decided to find some where else to eat.  Myriad is so close to my home and I had not realised it was there.  So close but so far away...  

I sat at the bar which I always love to experience as a first business.  I ordered a chicken sandwich and shared the shrimp and grits--both fantastic--un-expected and so pleasing.  

When I went there was not a full bar--beer and wine and creative cocktails minus spirits--I didn't taste any but I hear very good things--I will have to try at some point in the future.  

The service was attentive and I really liked that it is so very close by.  I'll visit again.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
Had the veggie skillet. I'm not even a vegetarian, and it was great.

Good service, nice people. Convenient location in the Mission (ie easier parking than Valencia).

I would definitely go again.
author: Ej E.

description: We had such a wonderful meal and time here yesterday!!  Page was our server and she was great! The entire crew is amazing.  The food was fantastic!  I'm craving more.  We ate as much as we could. Started out with the happy hour snacks and then for dinner Hubby ordered a boring burger (which turned out to be amazing and not even boring, I will need to get my own one day.  I had the cochinita pibil all kinds of yum!  Oh and dessert!! Do it!!! The butterscotch pudding was divine! Made with real butter and scotch! . Yesll be back as soon as we can!! Thank you all for the lovely time and for making amazing grub!
author: Martha H.

description:
Fun and interesting menu - tough to choose what to get but everything was great. Chicken Sammie's were my fav. But the thing that really puts this place on the five star list for me was the perfect service!!
That is sadly so rare in SF these days. It was refreshing to have nice, attentive and helpful waitstaff. Thank you!
author: Laura H.

description:
This restaurant is creative.  We read the menu and were intrigued by the description of the snacks and small plates.  
Some of the dishes worked and some didn't.  The deviled eggs were flavorful and accurately described.  We ordered a second one.  The farm toast was very good though not quite as described online.  The effect of the addition made the dish sweeter.  That worked better for my husband and less well for me.  The toast and goat cheese were wonderful.
We split a main dish of skillet vegetables.  For both of us the vegetables were well prepared, and if the dish had not been overwhelmed by smoked pimiento, we would have really liked it.  It tasted of liquid smoke because of the smoked quality.  There was for us too much bulgar wheat, dominating the chickpeas and the peas.  It was pretty oood, but the proportions were wrong, and the pimiento was overbearing.

The sorbet, especially the Mexican chocolate, was excellent.  The chocolate cake with the olive oil and chocolate sauce was a disappointing mix that tasted too much of olive oil.

It is hard to be critical of such creative efforts.  We wish the dishes had worked better for us.
author: Che S.

description: The food were superb! Our group really enjoyed the ambience, drinks, and the food! Can't wait to be back again!
author: Eunice M.

description: Always great food but I'd argue their portions are always on the small side. Lamb sandwich was tasty but the bread was toast on the bottom and under toasted on top. Brussels sprouts are amazing
author: Andrew P.

description:
Myriad is a good place for a bite but I didn't think the food was that exciting.

Farm toast - lots of flavor on a crunch bread, good
Market salad - cilantro was overpowering, not a fan
Fried chicken sammies - delicious bite sized sliders
Bellwether ricotta zeppole - best thing we had here, complemented the sauces very well! definitely recommend this for dessert

There wasn't anything else on the menu that made me want to come back and try. It's still a good date spot. Service is excellent.
author: Pansy L.

description: This was actually quite a wonderful experience I waited too long before I wrote this review. I know I rarely ever get 5 stars to restaurant but this place had it all. I remember everything was delicious and the service was superb. I must go back again to write a better review
author: Erin L.

description: Please please for the love of humanity never discontinue the Roasted Chicken Salad. I can't  live life without it.
author: Kayli B.

description:
Mission statement cocktail 
Farm toast 
Deviled eggs
Lamb sandwich 
Everything is so delicious! My friend and I had a great time there! Will be back for sure!!!
author: Kalena S.

description:
Myriad is only a few blocks away from our house and had been eyeing this restaurant for awhile but the menu was always "ifs and maybe's" for me and bad reviews on service. The TONY wanted steak and was being very particular that night and I couldn't yelp anything we could both enjoy so compromise ensued. 
I walk by this place every night on my way home off the Bart and never seems too packed but not in a bad way. Always comes off as a good "communal friends dinner" vibe. We had a small table for us in the back but still comfortable and a very easy going atmosphere and accommodating waiter. 
Of course we ordered the deviled eggs (I may have ordered more when the BF was in the bathroom but it is what it is), chicken liver mousse, bottle of wine, and he had the Hangar steak while I jumped to the butternut squash soup at the last minute. 
All good and reliable dishes; what stood out for us was the chicken liver mousse. HUGE portion; I could spend days eating this. I love you. Marry Me. Don't let the BF see this.
I liked the butternut squash soup as well; simple and nice drizzle of oil on top. But again, most places can do soup just fine. 
The reason for 3 stars; BF was like A-ok on steak and deviled eggs. Mind you, we had Marlowe the night before and that got us all twisted on great deviled eggs. 
I want to go back and will go back; heard horrible things from friends on atrocious service who go there often (which kept us from lingering in ever); so hopefully they cleared out the bad staff.
author: Kelly T.

description:
Needed a quick snack before climbing at Mission Cliffs.

Popped in to this place.

Zing...my snacks appear in moments..

Zap...they are tasty

Everyone is smiling...genuinely glad to be theee.

Even "I'ts a beautiful day" by u2 is on the sound system.

Epic

Thanks mystic
author: Evrett K.

description:
First let me say that my wife and I absolutely loved the food and service at Myriad.  The popcorn appetizer (the Popped Elote) was yummy - not too simple, not overly seasoned; the potted chicken liver was a pretty fair alternative to foie gras torchon, and the Pibil was, in a word, fabulous.  Our server was attentive but not overly so and was very helpful with questions.

The only reasons to hold back the fifth star were that the decor was fine but a little chaotic and that the LED spot lights up at the ceiling level were both turned up too bright and, due to their color temperature and light quality (probably a low CRI for you lighting geeks) cast a pallor on the dining room that would have been better served by the warmer Edison bulbs in the three chandeliers that were also occupying the space.

We'll see how it evolves and give it another try in near future...
author: Josh M.

description:
Really nice place. Drinks was great and food was awesome. 

The deviled eggs could have been better though. But everything else was excellent. Will surely be back
author: Milana R.

description: This place gives of a weird feel at first.  When you enter the place is great they have 2 rooms an the paper towels in the bathrooms are really soft.  The fried chicken sliders are to die for they are nice and crunchy and the service is great.
author: Gabriel R.

description: Adventurous meal at a restaurant true to its name. Every dish was distinct--a world tour in your mouth, haha. Plus lovely service. A little expensive.
author: Rachel D.

description:
Myriad Gastopub is a fairly new spot in the mission that I have been to twice. 

Deviled eggs are so good. Definitely get them, even if you aren't a huge deviled egg person. 

Farm toast- I loved this. The bread is fresh. Everything on it just goes together so well. 

Crispy Fried Chicken sammies were delicious. I love these. The honey chipotle mayo is a nice touch and I liked the crunchy slaw. 

Thai Wings- I didn't like these very much

Bone Marrow- I was a big fan of this. The bone marrow was so buttery and had delicious flavor. 

Roasted Lamb Sandiwch- This was okay. I liked the apps more then the mains.
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
What gracious people host and cook here! We were given a quiet spot for lunch upon request; the service was informative, friendly and gave us plenty of privacy.
The food was delicious: my friend and I split the Lamb sandwich with Moroccan tomato jam, the brussel sprout hash ( heavenly ) and the roasted chicken salad. I eat a lot of salads and with chicken; how this one could be so different and tasty  is amazing to me.
The lamb on the sandwich was succulent.
My friend has been a cook ( at home) all of his life and he also  enjoyed the food a lot. 
I will be visiting this restaurant frequently.
Thank you!
author: Jane B.

description:
Just had a delicious couple dishes in this Mission gem. Cocktails, on the session side, were delicious. We enjoyed the Mission Statement. Moved into appetizers: obligatory deviled eggs because of course... Bacalaitos were a pleasant surprise, great texture and flavor then moved onto the Braised Pork.
Food and drink were great, service was informative and attentive, only downside was the tight table arrangement. Recommended!
author: Ted M.

description: At the risk of making this gem harder drop in on, I love this place! Stumbled upon it with a large group in summer on a Sunday. Returned on a Friday with a friend recently. The food is excellent, reasonably priced for a big city spot. A cross between comfort food and fine cuisine, it has something for everyone. As a vegetarian, I found it welcoming and delicious. My server Sara was fabulous, everything I want in a server. Her skill and warmth complimented the food and beverage. My small dog was also welcomed, and she had a deviled egg from the starter menu. You owe it to yourself to stop in.
author: K U.

description: Great spot! Loved the food our four top all had delish dishes. Buy a bottle and they waive a corkage. Thanks Mark! The pasta with pork ragu & peas was a highlight.
author: Michael L.

description: Thanks to my girlfriend, we were able to grab brunch in the Mission with a reservation, which is nearly impossible! Mimosas along with farm toast and cheesy grits- super tasty and rustic presentation. Loved every minute and bite of it
author: judy l.

description:
Short and sweet 
1. Deviled Eggs - ehh 
2. Chicken Liver Pate - delicious 
3. Shrimp and Grits - good but not wow
4. Pappardelle pasta - good rustic stick to your rib plate. 
Overall, good dinner.
author: Quang W.

description:
Love this place! Delicious, Caring, Easy.
Service was so nice. Owner is a sweetheart who really cares about the food and the guests.
Popcorn, Wedge, Marrow, Pot de creme.
Say No More!!
author: Joshua F.

description: Maybe this is more of a brunch place? We came for dinner and some things were great, others just mediocre. The farm toast and the apple crisp were both very good. The burger and steak fries were a solid mediocre. I'm not dying to come back here, but if nothing else, the service was fast and friendly and the drink menu was solid.
author: Megan B.

description: The food was delicious and the menu offered a lot of options for people with different culinary preferences. Ambiance was great, drink were tasty and everything was affordable. Great service too!
author: Jessica M.

description: I came here on a Saturday around noon for brunch and was seated right away. Although the service was a little slow, the food was delicious. I definitely recommend getting the Roasted Lamb Sandwich and Farm Toast.
author: Janice J.

description:
