A group of us went to Myriad Gastro Pub the other night after unsuccessfully finding a place with a small wait time. Fortunately, the wait at Myriad was only 20 minutes so we decided to try it. We ordered some drinks from the bar and the cocktails were great. Later, we ordered dinner and most of us got the burger. The burger was pretty good, but nothing really special. The large steak fries on the side were very tasty and crispy in a good way. 

One person that was with us ordered from the Small Plates section and got the shrimp. It looked pretty good, but I did not try it. However, just be aware that the dishes that come from the Small Plates section are actually really small. The staff was pretty nice and we did encounter any issues with them at all. They also split our check without fussing about it like a lot of places in San Francisco. This still baffles me how the biggest tech city in US, has food places that are either too cheap or too dumb to split checks properly.

A couple of small gripes, is that they only have one bathroom for both males and females, so there will frequently be a line of people waiting outside of the door. But the bathroom was really nice. Also the noise level at times got pretty loud for such a small place, to the point where everyone in our party had to almost shout at each other in order to talk.

PROS
- Decent food
- Good prices
- Great cocktails
- Low wait times
- Nice staff

CONS
- Only one bathroom
- Can get loud
author: Steven S.

description: Great menu choices.  Pros: deviled eggs are tangy and delicious, pappardelle pasta dish does not skimp on the mushrooms and pork, the side of grits is very hearty. Cons: chicken sliders are microscopic, steak is too lean of a cut for me, beers are too expensive (pint of IPA for $9).
author: Steve D.

description:
Trish the owner and founder knows how to cook..really well. 

I'm moving here in a week and during one of my work stays, I decided to eat at Myriad due to the great reviews. After having some great cocktails, I found out Trish was originally from NJ, just like me! Anyway, the food we had was amazing, I am definitely coming back. Great service, I'd recommend the salmon as it was cooked to perfection.
author: William E.

description: Nothing special whatsoever.  It's cute, great interior, and great staff.  However, if you want a meal it's trying to be fancier than it should, and at way too high a price point.  We went for a slew of small plates and apps.  Potato chips ($6...come on now) and deviled eggs.  Fried chicken sandwich (now this was like $11...you should go to Wes' down the street, and get his fried chicken sandwich for the same price, then tell me to my face that these sliders were close to quality or quantity), shrimp and grits (actually fantastic grits!), chicken wings (left un-eaten because of the gross mint marinate and then fried), and cauliflower soup (very bland and uninspiring).  There was nothing hitting to warrant a $70 check, so unfortunately I'll wait til yet another place rents this death spot.
author: A A.

description:
They have a bunch of loophole cocktails which was a concept pretty new to me. I ordered the Bollywood chai which I loved. 

Farm toast was just ok for me . The bread was a bit hard for my liking. The Vegetarian skillet was perfect. Sizzling at the right temperature and flavor was spot on. Not many options for a vegetarian such as myself but I would go again for the cocktails/
author: Vasini G.

description: I love this place! I come in all the time and the servers are always so nice, they make you feel like family. The food is superb and always consistent, and I love their wine selection. This place is great for date night too. Five stars!!!
author: Brooklyn S.

description:
It's started really well, the host at the door was pleasant and accurate in explaining the wait.  The wait want too bad considering it was Saturday night.  When we were sat, our server was Patrick.  He did well in thoroughly explaining the specials and the intricate methods of the way some of the entrees were prepared.

He brought out the water, which we quickly found out were mistakenly syrup/sugar water.  Patrick raced to exchange them for the regular tap water.  However, it was after this when his mood took a turn and our sever Patrick began to come off as someone who is on a rush to get us out of the restaurant.  He rushed through taking out order, he rushed through our drinks.  It changed the experience for our dinning pleasure all the way around.  

Nonetheless, the food was half delightful.  The bone marrow looked yummy but it simply just tasted like fat - no infused seasoning.  The pappardelle pasta also lacked taste.  And the salt cod fritters were mushy inside (more like tuna'ish), so was disappointing when you were expecting cod.  

The other severs/bussers were courteous.  He ambiance is elegant, and the food matches through its quality.  However, while I hate to put people on the spot, Patrick did not deliver tonight.  It's a shame.
author: Jim B.

description: Great server, food was an unappetizing mishmash of flavors.
author: Christi C.

description: Cool little place with some interesting food. Everything is small serve but very tasty. The alcohol selection isn't vast but the guys know how to pair the right food with the right drinks for you.
author: Herbert H.

description:
The food was fabulous.  We started with chips and pickled veges.  The chips were light and crisp with an excellent dipping sauce -- well worth it.  The pickled veges were also a hit as a light appetizer.  Though not generally a cider fan, I enjoyed the pomegranate cider, which was not too sweet.

For mains we had lamb sandwich, hanger steak, and pork tortilla. They were all excellent, with the lamb and port tortilla getting particular raves. The pork tortilla comes as a steak which pulls apart easily with tasty corn tortillas, jalapenos, and a nice sauce.

For dessert we had the chocolate cake with cherries.  Both the cake and cherries were a big hit!  We were also pleased that the whole bill was about $40 per person after tip. Good value for the city!

The atmosphere is pub-like, but don't let that scare you away. It was a pleasant environment and not too loud.  I'd definitely go back.  My only small complaint was our server was excellent but simply too busy to be attentive -- perhaps they were short-staffed for the night.
author: Brad B.

description:
GREAT. 

Light fare. Full flavor. Incredible presentation. Reservations through Yelp. Great service. Cool atmosphere. 

Super cool Kickstarter startup story too. 
Grateful employees top off the experience. 

Highly recommended!
author: Michael B.

description: Myriad was great! The service was excellent and the space is super cute. Everything was great. 5 stars for the vegetarian squash entree -- amazingly delicious! It was a really nice bean ragout with broccolini and squash. The kale side was also excellent. Mom loved the pappardelle -- great pasta with really good mushroom ragu. Happy hour specials were excellent.Apple cobler dessert was awesome.
author: Jen G.

description:
Solid option for brunch. 

I liked this place - it was an easy place to come for brunch, especially in an area where brunch can be quite stuffy.

The service was good - our waitress was very cool and nice. The drinks were also really tasty and fun. The food was good, but didn't blow us away.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Nice cooking but overpriced for modest portions, both small and large plates. If you make dot.com wages, enjoy. Otherwise there are plenty of Mission places offering food that's just as nice at a better price.
author: tw s.

description:
TL; DR - Another ADD restaurant (Appetizers, Drinks, Desserts), with inconsistent service. 


~ Good service: They understand the basics of human psyche, and allow you ample time, and keep coming to check in. They are prepared with all the answers, along with recommendations. However, empathy isn't quite their forte, as exemplified by our server's lack of care when we had to eat around the meat in our entree (we are 'pescatarians'). 

+ Great beverages. No really, they are incredible. 
-- (+++) Watermelon slushy: this was the special of the day. The first sip punched you in the face with flavor, and continued to expose layers and layers more as the seconds passed. It was neither too sweet nor too sour. Perfectly balanced. Big kudos to the alchemist that prepared this.
-- (~) Forbidden Lowball. Complex medley of spice, tobacco and the organic sweetness of liquor. However, while it was the server's "hands down" choice between two Cardamaro-based cocktails: this and the Wayfarer, I must respectfully disagree.
-- (+) Wayfarer: Very good. Again, complex and involved like the Forbidden Lowball, but no mixer makes the drink remain that way as the time passes.
-- (-) Sandbar: This one was the most disappointing. It was grapefruit juice and sparkling wine. Highly de-recommended.

+ Good Appetizers. 
--(+) Chips were good and flavorful
--(+) Farm toast was filled with flavor, but too jammy/fruity/sweet. The plums dominated the flavor, instead of accentuating the wonderful flavors of the cheese and nuts.

- Meh entrees.
--(~) The Cod had no real flavor of its own. The corn salsa bed beneath had good flavor. The clams, nothing spectacular. NOTE: It's rare to have a seafood dish include meat. This dish had pork. I think this was the outlier on the prices, and was not worth the price.
--(+) Spicy Shrimp with Grits were good in flavor and consistency. 

~ Good dessert
--(~) We had the pot-de-creme. It was flavorful, but didn't floor us.

Myriad isn't overpriced. But it's not cheap either. I think if Yelp could show $$.5, that would be most appropriate.

The server did appear to be very rehearsed (It's funny - I used this word, and before submitting, saw someone else's review using the same term!). I don't really like it when that happens - I'd prefer that servers were hired for who they are - for their own personality.

The only surprise throughout the dinner was the server's severe lack of care when we expressed disappointment at seeing meat in our entree. The cod dish has "guanciale", which we now know is pork. This was our oversight. We generally ask about an ingredient when we suspect it might render our meal useless. It's rare (almost never) that we find a seafood entree that uses meat, so we didn't really look deeper. When we asked the server about this foreign presence in our meal, his reaction was basically "Yes, that's meat. It's pork. It's listed on the menu. Enjoy your meal". 

We might go back for light fares. But for dinner, I'd skip Myriad.
author: Kunjal R.

description:
Had a fabulous experience at Myriad Gastro Pub!  Both dinner and service were exceptional.  We split the potted chicken liver mousse, the bacalaitos (delicate salt cod fritters), bone marrow and jersey wedge - all highly recommended.  
Dessert was a tough choice, with so many tempting concoctions.  We opted for the warm caramelized granny smith apple, cranberry pecan crisp with creme fraiche ice cream. It was amazing!  
You can tell that the chef and staff really care!
author: Jeannie S.

description:
Have been numerous times now, having had brunch and dinner. Both were good and have no problem returning. 

Their Mayan hash is delicious for brunch. And the dinner specials are excellent. Just feel like for the money not outstanding. Tables are so close together; staff constantly on you. Needs a little tweaking, could be improved in a few areas. Namely, upon arrival to a nearly empty restaurant and asked if we had a reservation... Turns me off. 

But, I'm willing and able to overlook certain things. And give another try. Just step it up. Newly opened and attitude doesn't sit well with me. Me and my money got lots of options. Don't screw it up.
author: Elizabeth Q.

description:
You had me at spiked watermelon slushie!

A little bit sad about Nombe being gone, but Myriad is pretty tasty. 

We got the chicken sammies (kind of small..), chicken liver mousse (good!), bacalaitos (salt-cod fritters, a bit small) and the farm toast (goat cheese, honey-sage roasted persimmons, pumpkin seeds, balsamic - really good!). 

Shared the lamb sandwich and the steak (perfectly cooked, not huge) and was too stuffed for dessert. 

For me, the piece de resistance was the watermelon slushie (read: dangerously delicious): a scoop of watermelon-mint sherbert drowning in prosecco that you can drink or scoop or stir up. YUM

Definitely come by for drinks or with a bunch of friends to share a bunch of dishes!
author: Vivian C.

description: Great service, good food and drinks. Try the Thai wings and you won't be disappointed. The grass burger fed burger and wedge salad were also a hit!
author: Valster P.

description:
Here's what this place does really well: put interesting ingredients in close proximity to one another in interesting ways. Your mouth is like: "wow! I have never had this combination of these tastes all happening simultaneously...and I like it!" 

The other thing they do well is customization. We had our own little skillet with the gratin. They actually make their on ketchup! Awesome steak fries are cooked to order.

We met the chef and her brother. These are good people doing really good work. You need to support their efforts. These are the kinds of folks you want to see succeed. Based on the meal we had, it's hard to imagine them NOT succeeding. The food, service, ambience, and especially the presentation were really excellent. Don't pass this place up...
author: Mike M.

description: Great food, we had many many small plates and were too full for mains. The staff was awesome and very attentive, food was solid, ambiance was nice. Great spot, it was pretty packed for a Monday.
author: Cameron F.

description:
I like salty food but they took salt to a whole new level. Never have I had steak so salty. The burger was good but also carried a salty flavor

Service was alright. Not really sure why this place is so highly rated
author: Louis D.

description:
My favorite brunch spot with delicious, exciting menu full of staples (French toast) with novel twists and, most importantly, also takes reservations.  

I had the grits with sautéed veggies and poached egg.  Grits were buttery, perfectly cooked and decadent in their own right. The mushrooms and kale had that perfect caramelized sear. Partner had the incredibly delicious French toasted with bacon pecan butter goodness. 

The waitress was awesome. Made all the right suggestions and anticipated all of our needs. Tempo was great.
author: Tom K.

description: Delicious food and great service. Got tons of starters and a few large plates and shared everything. Pappardelle and hanger steak were outstanding.
author: Jannine V.

description: I was visiting my friends from Dallas and we decided to go to a movie in the Mission at The Alamo Drafthouse.  Afterwards we stumbled into this restaurant not knowing anything about it.  We were pleasantly suprised by everything we ordered!! The sammies, shrimp and grits and the veggie plate were BOMB!!!! Absolutely DELISH!!! Such a great place to go pre or post movie.
author: Katie A.

description: Went here last night for my birthday dinner. Our server was David and his service was excellent. He had a lot of recommendations that were on point: We started out with the Grapefruit IPA and Cubano for drinks and the grilled peaches and bone marrow for our small plates. It was a delicious mix of sweet and savory. For our entree, I had the Pork Pappardelle and my boyfriend has the Hanger steak. We finished the night with the berry/fruit crips cobbler with ice cream. All of our food and drinks came in a timely manner and David's timing and tempo to our table was great.This was the perfect dinner.
author: Gaozong Y.

description: I was with a group of 6 that came for brunch on Sunday. The meal was incredible - probably the best grits I've ever had. Great drink selection and very friendly service. Well done!
author: Amanda D.

description:
Visited Myriad for breakfast and ate ALL the bread things - except the french toast. Gougeres, biscuits, toast, fried chicken sliders, cheese grits, and lastly deviled eggs. 

We were overwhelmed with deliciousness, and seriously had a hard time deciding what we needed to try. (We're already planning our next visit back.) Stand out for us were the farm toast (goat cheese, honey-sage roasted persimmons, pumpkin seeds, balsamic), and the fried chicken sammies. We shared 6 small plates/sides and left very full.

Service was really friendly, and fast. I cannot wait to go back and try out the dinner menu.
author: Margaret I.

description: This place of was fabulous!! We saw it on check please and it stands up to what they say.  I had the lamb delicious. My friend had the pasta plus we had dessert   Highly recommend Butter with scotch
author: Sydney M.

description:
Stopped in for a quick bite so I sat at the bar and got bone marrow and kale spouts (balance the fat with the green).  Service here is great.  The current owner noticed that the bones they used for my order were quite lacking in marrow content so she prepared me an extra bone, up front without my asking.  It was really good, flavorful without tasting "fatty", so an almost perfect preparation.
I balanced the marrow with kale sprouts which were also really tasty.  Great flavor without excess bitterness (kale should always taste a little bitter).
Draft beer selection has mostly local brewers, which I also really like.  Had a Proving Ground IPA which went well with my food.
Overall, a great quick bite experience.  Will have to come back to get a full sit down.
author: John A.

description: Fun atmosphere, tasty food.  They accommodated my vegetarian friend with a salad from the kitchen since there wasn't much for her on the happy hour menu.  The mini chicken sandwiches were indeed mini, but mighty tasty.  I hope to come again for the full menu.
author: Anne G.

description: This place can be pricey for entrees but their small plates can be combined to make a fantastic and economical dinner. Also check out their happy hours. The place is pretty quiet during that time but it is in a great part of town and a perfect place to meet a friend.
author: Lydia W.

description: The salmon was almost too overcooked, but thankfully they did not let it sit for too long and I ate quickly. Salmon was sitting on a bed of raw pea shoots which are so much better cooked. So close to a good dish.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Persimmon and goat cheese mousse toast was killer.

The shakshouka is a must have.

Also -- met Trish and she's pretty dope. Myriad is definitely worth checking out.
author: Britt M.

description:
Everything was good, but not great. I'm not sure if I would come here again at this price point. Maybe, maybe not.

Brunch food:
-polenta with kale, mushrooms, cheese - initially quite good, but became very oily once the dish cooled down to room temperature
-cheddar bacon gougeres
-farm toast - This was good, but not spectacular like I had hoped from the reviews. Maybe my expectations were too high, or maybe it's because I make similar, sometimes better tasting toast concoctions at home. Do you know what actually goes great with persimmon? Foie gras.
-deviled eggs (my favorite; pickle flavoring?)
-ham, cheese, sandwich - oddly enough serve on a hamburger bun

Pro: No, wait at 12pm on a Sunday in the mission!
author: Aleyna S.

description:
If you are looking for a dining experience that's akin to a good friend making you a fabulous meal in their home, this is the place for you. Chef Trish and her team welcome you with open arms and feed you amazing food prepared with love.

The physical space is hip and warm. There are so many touches that make it interesting and eclectic -- the warm colors, the beautiful wallpaper in the main dining room, the lights, funky mirrors, signage and the various roosters perched around the place.

And of course there's the remarkable food. The Jersey salad does the chef's home state proud. It has lots of flavor and just a little heat. The halibut entree is a piece of heaven. The fish is perfectly prepared and the sauce begs for some bread to sop it up. My fiance had the pork and raved about the amazing flavors. It was a party in his mouth.

The deviled eggs and potato chips are two of my favorite starters. Pair them with one of the creative cocktails on the menu and you are off to the running start.

Be sure to save room for one of Pastry Chef Mark Smith's yummy desserts. You simply can't go wrong with any of them but the butter-with-scotch pot de creme is to die for. I found myself wanting to lick the jar.  My man is a crisp fan and gave the fruit crisp with homemade ice cream two thumbs up.

Myriad could easily become your go to place for great food and wonderful atmosphere. You need to check it out for yourself.
author: Anthony H.

description:
I woke up thinking about plums on toast and peaches with goat cheese.
And then I remembered the bone marrow. 
And the hanger steak.
And the halibut & clams.
And the deviled eggs that started the night and apricot & blueberry crisp that ended it.
Did I mention that we also somehow managed to eat salt cod fritters & knock back a few cocktails? 
And there may have been some butterscotch custard & some port, but now my memory escapes me......

No wonder I am still full. 

Wow.  I can't believe someone has finally broken the Nombe curse.  
We LOVED going here when Nick Balla was the chef, even though the decor was weird and disjointed. 
Once he left, it sadly devolved, and it was a empty and lonely place.
There was no joy. 

Now- we have an actual neighborhood restaurant- owned and run by a seasoned, professional female chef.
This is the San Francisco we know and love!!!!!
No stupid tech money.
No restaurant group with loads of money to throw around and convince us they are the new it place with insane prices and food that leaves us wondering why we only got 2 bites for $15. 

No hype, no smoke and mirrors. 
This is a restaurant with REAL FOOD.  That makes you happy, full and excited to try the next course. 
The restaurant finally feels put together - nice space, touches, lighting, wood and it just feels cozy. 
Like someone has an actual vision and plan and has done this before and will do everything in her power to keep us coming back again and again.
And the servers and all the staff knew about the food and could answer questions and gently tease us when we cleaned out plates and were nearly licking our fingers, it was all so damn good. ;)

When we left, I booked 2 more reservations and cancelled reservations I had at other places with friends later this month. 
This is my new favorite neighborhood spot, and I can't wait to become a regular.
Myriad, thank you for bringing joy back to this space. 
And for making my picky wife really really happy.
What you risk reveals what you value......
author: Alisha A.

description: This place is really fantastic. The liver was amazing. My friend and I had the bone marrow and the sherry at the end was a great touch. Reasonably priced, great atmosphere, nice service, and really great food! This is now on my list of regular spots in the mission!
author: Janice T.

description:
We went there with our four kids and we had a great evening!
The service was warm and welcoming, with an attention to details.
The food was delicious, with innovative combinations and perfect cooking. 10 days after, I still remember the slowly cooked pork.
The wine list was great. After many bad experiences in California, we finally tasted a great bottle of wine.
We warmly recommend this place.
author: Francois G.

description:
Yelp inflation at play again...the deviled eggs were great if a little salty.  The gougere and biscuit were lovely but tiny.  We ordered the chicken and dumplings as part of the Sunday supper - it was fine. Totally mediocre.  The pappardelle with pork was likewise just meh. The banana bread pudding was insulting.  Cold bananas in the middle and it clearly had not been warned enough.

I would not go back.
author: A S.

description:
Some of the 3-star yelp reviews of this place are hilarious.  Especially some of the criticism of the service--e.g., the service seemed "rehearsed."  What could that possibly mean?  Or: the server was "nice but seemed unapproachable."   What could that possibly mean?

Anyway. 

We tried brunch at Myriad today and I swear, we kept ordering things because we didn't want the meal to be over.  Everything was so creative and tasty.  We started with some phenomenal deviled eggs and a watermelon dish that was packed with flavor.  We also got the Tunisian (I think) eggs poached in a rich tomato concoction that was served with some thin, crispy chick pea pancakes to die for.  And then there was the pork and potato hash with cotija cheese, all the elements just singing together.  Though we were plenty full, we couldn't help ordering the blueberry pop tart with flaky, light pastry (four bucks!) and an ice cream sandwich dish that I will be dreaming about till I get back to Myriad again.  

Some yelpers have complained about the prices but for what you get, I thought the prices were totally fair.  I hear the old Boogaloos space is on the market for $17K a month--a new restaurant with diner prices couldn't make a go of it in the new Mission.   

Our server was adorable, charming, and also gorgeous.  Oh and she knew the menu very well and made great recommendations.  Can't wait to go back for dinner.
author: Michelle C.

description:
My husband and I came to Myriad to celebrate our anniversary and couldn't have asked for anything better. Service and food were exquisite. I am a vegetarian who doesn't eat dairy, and he loves meat, but we found dishes we both liked and shared many that surprised us. The farm toast was an especially surprising standout, as were the deviled eggs and house potato chips. I might even be convinced come here again just for the starters/small plates!

The staff was exceedingly courteous and available, and on a Wednesday night it was not crowded with nice ambiance. Would definitely recommend this one.
author: Anna P.

description: Delicious, fab decor, great service. Loved it!! The fish , the cheesy grits, and all desserts were amazing! Fantastic latest addition to the Mission, go check it out! Definitely will become my next favorite!
author: Sabrina A.

description:
Everything here was on point! The atmosphere and vibe of the spot is very comfortable and casual. Our server, David, was extremely knowledgeable about menu suggestions, but what I really liked was his personable approach with our table. Before even getting into the "menu discussion", he was just talking to us about our weekends and made us feel like ol' pals from the get-go. 

Chef Trish and her staff came correct with their offerings. My table split the deviled eggs and bone marrow for small dishes. I proceeded to order the burger afterward. It was made just right and fries were delicious, as well. I'd definitely come back. Maybe even bring a date. If she (my date) gets lucky. ;)
author: Kevin G.

description: Really attentive staff, the deviled eggs were delicious and the lad sandwich and arugula salad was amazing! Good drinks, good vibes and reasonably priced for the area. Will definitely visit again!
author: Ger F.

description:
As a foie gras lover with qualms about force-feeding ducks, I really enjoyed Myriad's chicken liver mousse. Served with the standard onion jam, it had the same rich, creamy texture and hint of liver, but with less guilt about animal cruelty. The chef came out and explained how it was made, when I asked about it!

The bone marrow was also excellent, but don't order it with the chicken liver mousse! I made that mistake, and got overwhelmed by the cumulative richness of the meal.

I went at an odd hour, so there was plenty of seating available. The waitress was helpful, and I appreciated getting more crostini without having to ask.
author: Zack L.

description: Service was friendly. The atmosphere is pleasant. We both had the arugula salad, it was good but not special. The grits were a bit too cheesy for me.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Went with a few other people and we ordered A LOT of food. Every single thing was delicious. Can't wait to go back.
author: Russ S.

description:
Boffo! Chef Trish Tracy delivers an outstanding gastropub experience with flavorful dishes in a setting that is inviting and comfortable. Even though there are so many other dining options in SF, this restaurant feels like a place that I'll be happy to count on as my home base. What really makes this a winner for me is that each dish allows the flavor of the individual ingredients to come forward and harmonize beautifully with the others. 

Things not to miss:
Deviled eggs with salsa verde, breakfast radish and crispy shallot 
Jersey wedge: iceburg, smokey thousand island, pickled onions, bacon, dry jack
Potted chicken-liver mousse, port-wine onion jam, crostini 
Cochinita pibil: mayan pork stew, sour orange onions, jalapeños, green chile tortillas 
Pappardelle with pork cheeks, peas, kale, brown beech mushrooms, tarragon
Cheesy anson mills grits 
Stone fruit and berry pecan crisp served warm, crème fraîche ice cream 
Butter-with-scotch pot de crème, brown butter sable cookies, crème chantilly

Too much??? Maybe at one sitting but I'll be happy to come back and eat my way through the entire menu.
author: George H.

description:
This is a great new restaurant. The space is really unique with cool decor. We had a very filling meal for two and we split a bunch of plates, plus it wasn't too crazy overpriced like most of the new restaurants in SF. 

Devil Eggs - Yum Yum 
Salted Cold Fritters - Yummy Yum Yum 
Bone Marrow - Yummy Yummy Yummy Yum
Pork Stew & MSP Steak Fried - De-fuckilous 

But the best part of it this place was that there was no line or 4 month waitlisting. In other words, don't go here because I always want to be able to just walk right in to eat.
author: Jen S.

description: We went here for a date night one evening looking for something in the Mission with small plates/ tapas.  This was a nice little place with a great menu.  We shared some small plates; deviled eggs, pickled vegetables to start and then went for the spicy shrimp & grits, jalapeno thai wings, and MGP Fries.  All were excellent.  The grits were creamy and smooth and the wings were sweet & spicy, flavorful and not overly spicy.  I also had the "Freshie" cocktail and was quite happy with this as I am a sweet cocktail lover.  For dessert we shared the Mexican sorbet & the butterscotch pot de crème.  The Mexican sorbet was not overly sweet, with a hint of cayenne and cinnamon.  The favorite was definitely the pot de crème, delicious!  Both served with the best shortbread ever.  Our waiter was one of the best waiter we have ever had anywhere.  Attentive, provided recommendations based on our interests & input, knowledgeable about the menu, never rushed us.  We had a great evening and would definitely come back and recommend to others.
author: Steven B.

description: Fairness alert.  It was the limited happy hour menu from 3-6 pm.  Neither of us drank alcohol.  2 people, happy hour, no alcohol it was a little pricey.  The food and service were good.  Decor and ambiance were nice also.
author: Sfclint O.

description:
Great and friendly service, creative and inspired dishes, great beer selection, go there! This place definitely deserves your business. This chef is doing cool stuff! 

We went on a little beer/brewery crawl on a Saturday afternoon and popped in here in between breweries to see one of my husband's old friends who is now managing the place. 

We ordered the deviled eggs with crispy shallot (I could have eaten 10 of those), the popcorn with Parmesan and lime (SO GOOD!!), and the house-pickled vegetables (pretty standard, but that's all I want out of pickled vegetables), and a couple beers and had a great time. 

We can't wait to go back for dinner!!
author: Osh J.

description: Celebrated my bday during lunch time here. Order a glass of mimosa and the lamb sandwich. All I can say is bomb.com! Sandwich was so juicy. And the alcohol complimented it so well. Will be coming again real soon.
author: Jason J.

description:
Great new gastropub, which took over Nombe. My date and I were able to walk in without reservations on a Saturday night. I really liked how they renovated the new space - it feels a lot more intimate and cozier, with a casual retro ambiance. 

The food and service were both fantastic. Highly recommend getting the deviled eggs and the fried chicken sammies. Both were delicious and flavorful. We also shared the hangar steak, which was also good and perfectly cooked, but the potatoes bravas were a bit salty. We didn't get to try the drinks but they all looked really good. Definitely will be back to try again.

Overall, great new spot in the Mission.
author: Vivian H.

description: A bit noisy, but wonderful service and great food. Got a table on a Saturday night without a reservation!
author: Connor S.

description: Great food. Great service. Saw them on Bay Area Check Please (got thumbs up from all reviewers), we were not disappointed.
author: Leonard S.

description:
My chef friends spoke really highly of Myriad so when we were invited to join them we jumped at the opportunity.

What a great space, meal and overall experience.  The staff was lovely, the chef warm and kind and the food, well the food is super tasty.

I kind of categorize it as California comfort food.  The flavors meld well together and are traditional style dishes with a fresh twist.  Good portions, fair prices.  What's not to like?

Items had the night we went (copying and pasting from the menu so I don't mess up)

-deviled eggs with salsa verde, breakfast radish and crispy shallot-- yummy!  Glad I stopped at one to leave room for everything else.

-mgp spiced potato chips with horseradish-chive crema (mgp is their house spice mix) 

-farm toast: fromage blanc, sage-roasted plums, toasted pistachios (really light and tasty)

potted chicken-liver mousse, port-wine onion jam, crostini (OK super crack and a giant portion-- we asked for more bread)

bone marrow with sherry demi-glace, tarragon-horseradish gremolata, sourdough- bone marrow is one of my favorite guilty pleasures.  Beefs answer to butter.  This did not disappoint.

pappardelle with pork cheeks, peas, kale, brown beech mushrooms, tarragon (my main course-- super tasty not too heavy)

grass-fed beef burger, pickled things, cheddar, mgp sauce, brioche bun, steak fries (hubbies choice-- holy crap the steak fries are the bomb!)

We will definitely be back.  Oh and before I forget the soju cocktails are kickass in a way that will take you down...

Back for brunch soon.  Thanks Trish for the hospitality.
author: Monika S.

description:
First off, we were a little skeptical of this place because it wasn't crazy busy on a Saturday night, but we decided to go for it.  My brother and I were immediately greeted by Sera, the hostess.  Not only was she cute, but she was extremely helpful!! She was able to tell us what was good on the menu and what items she personally enjoyed.  After speaking with her for about 5 minutes, she informed us that our waiter would be with us shortly.  We both thought she was a waitress by the amount of knowledge she had over the whole menu.
Once our waitress came over, we were even more impressed by the service.. Our waitress ended up being one of the GM's of the restaurant (I honestly forget her name), but we didn't find this out until after dinner.  She also told us some of her recommendations and we decided on the some of the best plates of food I have had in a while.  
The cocktails were bomb.... you know they had booze in them, but were tasty enough that you could pair them nicely with dinner.  We got this bread to start with... it was the best piece of bread I have literally ever had.. it had goat cheese and apricot spread on it.. I was truly shocked... then we got the salmon and the pork tacos... we split and both of them were equally bomb.  After dinner, we were speaking with our waitress and we all shared an incredible glass of wine.  we thanked her for making our night!!! and would definitely recommend this place to anyone passing by the mission.  both of these two ladies made dinner special.
author: Andrew S.

description: Doesn't have a full bar. Not actually a gastropub. Food was good but really overpriced. Service was good for the first part of the meal. Given the competition, I can't see them lasting.
author: Eggy P.

description:
Friendly staff. That to me makes or breaks a restaurant. From the hostess to the bartender to the other staff members this place delivered. And I haven't even gotten to the food. I sat at the bar, felt welcome and comfortable sitting at it as a single. Some restaurants layouts don't lend itself to this but Myriad got this right too. Lighting is dim but not too dark, music at the right level, cutlery/glassware/dish ware also gave a quality vibe. 

Ok, the food. Wow. Top shelf. 

Heirloom tomato salad, fresh and delicious with fresh burrata was amazing. Halibut with clams and a broth that a sane man would kill to soak it up with bread, ridiculous. Ice cream cookies that bring you back to childhood. I was still licking my fingers after they took the plate away - yes I definitely used my hands and these cookies (2 of them), with blackberry ice cream were stupid delicious. 

Paired with a reasonably priced Tempranillo and they have one very satisfied customer. 

They've been open just 2 weeks and have their sh*t together. 

Yum.
author: Mike T.

description:
Tried Myriad last night for an impromptu birthday dinner with two of my close friends. I hadn't heard of Myriad before, but we saw availability on OpenTable with no reviews, so we figured it'd be nice to try it out! Little did we know it was so new and had 5 stars on yelp...

ATMOSPHERE - 4 stars
I came here once before for American Bao Bar's pop-up restaurant; at the time it was a Japanese restaurant. I quite like the decor/set up now--the space is divided into two sides, one with tables only and the other with half-tables and half-bar. The ambiance is nice--dimly lit, not too loud, but not quiet either.

FOOD - 4.5 stars
- Deviled eggs: standard, can be a tiny bit on the salty side
- Heirloom tomatoes, burrata, charred croutons, and balsamic: the small plate special of the day - very tasty, really can't go wrong with tomatoes + burrata
- Fried chicken sammies: OMG YUM. served on HAWAIIAN ROLLS--what?? the fried chicken was crispy and very juicy; I do wish there had been some element of spice though
- Bacalaitos: my friend described it as a "very fancy fish stick" -- we love fish sticks. 
- Grass-fed beef burger: fairly standard burger. tasty, but not anything extraordinary
- Pappardelle with pork cheeks: yum, this was definitely one of the highlights of our meal
- Ricotta zeppoles + chai creme anglaise + bourbon caramel: such light and delicious little fried balls of dough!

DRINKS - 4.5 stars; very solid cocktail list
- Mission statement: yum!
- Forbidden lowball: yum!
- Wayfarer: yum! -- more on the bitter side; sherry flavour is very distinct
- Cubano: yum! very refreshing and light
- Orpheus: aftertaste reminded us of a very dark chocolate -- not as "yum" as the Wayfarer, but it grows on you

SERVICE - 4.5 stars
Our waitress was really personable and quirky, and offered us great recommendations. She also went ahead and got the chef to add on a third fried chicken sammy for us since we had three people (each order comes with two). As far as timing goes, the food all came out very quickly.

PRICE - 4 stars
Food + drinks for three people (everything I listed above) was $160 after tax. Not bad at all, I'd say.

OVERALL - 4.5 stars, rounding up to 5!
author: Krystal M.

description: Very happy with this find. We had the goat cheese toast, deviled eggs, salmon, bone marrow, and their polo ulnar mushroom pasta dish. We loved everything except the salmon, which was still great. Just jot amazing like the others. It was a bit fishy, so I'd give it 4/5 stars. No wait, and great cocktails as well.
author: Roxy W.

description: Chicken liver mousse was very nice.  Pappardelle was alright, nothing that special.  Lamb sandwich was nice.  Everything was fine.  Just another gastropub in the Mission.
author: Marcy R.

description: This place is absolutely delicious! Our fried chicken  sammys and pork cochinitas where so good I did not have a chance to take a photo. Outstanding tomato soup too! Trisha and her team are excellent. intimate lighting; perfect place for dinner for two or a group of friends.
author: Anthony M.

description:
Nice layout and great decorations for this new place. Everything looked fresh and the cocktails were delicious as well. Service was friendly and attentive despite kitchen being a bit slow.

Try the Cubano cocktail, the Lamb sandwich and of course their Deviled Eggs!
author: John D.

description:
Exceeded expectations. The food, drinks, and service were amazing. Since this place just opened probably good to get in here as soon as you can. I imagine that in the not so far future its reputation will make it a popular place, ultimately making it harder to get the very individualized (and awesome) service you can get today. Think of it as being able to eat and enjoy the finest food at a very expensive upscale restaurant while still in a relaxed casual atmosphere. 

Things to try:

* Deviled Eggs
* Farm Toast
* Bone Marrow
* Hanger Steak
* Ice Cream Cookie

Every single thing you try will make you say "wow." Just listen when you're dining... you'll hear "wow" from all corners of the restaurant as everyone tries their first bites. Good job, well done, to the folks at Myriad Gastro Pub.
author: Russ N.

description: I'm almost afraid of letting ppl know how awesome this place is bc I want to still be able to get a table. Everything we had was delicious and our server was great -- he was clearly a fan of the restaurant and menu so that was sweet. We ordered the deviled eggs, shrimp & grits, chicken sammies, and pork cheek pappardelle. Omg that pappardelle, tho! I smile just thinking about it, it was that good. Will def come again to try out the rest of the menu.
author: Tavia Y.

description: This is one of my new favorite spots in SF.  No waiting for seating with  a reservation.  Gracious and attentive service.  Delicious appetizers and small plates.  Hearty main courses.  Reasonable prices.  My personal faves:  the wedge salad with smoky thousand island dressing is huge and delicious, the house made potato chips with dip and deviled eggs were wonderful, and my burger was outstanding.  Reasonably priced wine by the glass and amazing desserts.
author: Thomas H.

description: Great spot!  We tried the Farm Toast, Spiced Shrimp, and Market Salad and they were all amazing.  The grits with the shrimp were so creamy and flavorful.  The market salad was a mixture of many different types of greens, and had a good variety of flavors and textures.  I would highly recommend this place.
author: Megan C.

description: I had a wonderful experience sitting at the bar. The bartender was super nice and helpful with selecting drinks and she also made great recommendations on dishes. The bone marrow, deviled eggs, and butternut squash soup were delicious. I'll definitely be coming back.
author: Nina K.

description:
I'm kind of OCD about being on the Paleo diet. 

Sooooooo naturally a place that actually service marrow bones is on my bucket list.

I wanted to have them done by a professional before attempting to make them on my own just in case I effed it up.

Myraid definitely set a standard for all marrow bone dishes in my future.  I highly reccomend giving them a try!
author: Stacy B.

description:
Came here for drinks after a very hectic outside-lands-week trip to Ocean Beach (long story short: praying it'll never be so crowded that I have to take a Lyft to the beach again). Sat at the bar and had the Mission Statement (fermented whiskey, grapefruit, lime, elderflower), which was what the bartender recommended when I asked him for something that was "fruity and doesn't taste like there's alcohol in it." 

The drink was divine (been thinking about it since that night) and best of all, didn't trigger my asian-glow/body's general rejection of alcohol (probably a sign that I should come here more and play ragecage with cheap Italian beer less). 

We were slightly hungry so we ended up getting the fries because they were cheap and I was with potato aficionados. Potato aficionados that were crushed when a small plate of exactly 5 thick-cut potato wedges were placed in front of us, as they had expected more (I also expected more - but hey, it's SF). 

If our bartender wasn't lowkey eavesdropping, I probably would've given this place 3 stars due to the potato disappointment, but my friend Khrizia's (official lover of potatoes in any shape or form) loud complaints inadvertently somehow convinced Stephen (not Steven) to give us not one, but two free plates of FRESH DONUT HOLES, one with bacon bits, and the other with lemon frosting. 

In summary: drinks are great, skip the fries, complain loudly but nicely, and collect your free donut holes - if you're lucky. Hopefully I'll be back to try the halibut someday. (Thanks Stephen!!!)
author: Elizabeth W.

description: Great place to eat. Thanks God we made reservations the restaurant became crowded rapidly. I had the spicy shrimps with grits in a small plate. It was creamy full of flavor and delicious. My friend got the lamb burger and loved it. Great service, good price, I recommend it nightly.
author: Katy C.

description:
Myriad is clearly still finding its footing but overall it was a very good experience.  The appetizer portions are a bit small but everything was so well seasoned that you got a ton of flavor out of each bite.  Definitely hope this spot makes it!  

What we ordered for 2:
-Devilled Eggs (1 each)
-Bone Marrow
-Flank steak
-Mayan pork stew

The devilled eggs were nothing really special.  The oil they were topped in was pretty much the only differentiator from any other devilled eggs.  They could have also been larger.

The marrow was amazingly seasoned and came with what appeared to be some kind of curry sauce that was fantastic soaked into the bread.  The actual quantity of marrow in the bone was a little smaller than what I would have liked to have seen.  

Both entrees were perfect.  The flank steak had a terrific crust around it and they didn't overcook it.  We asked for it rare and that's what we got.  The mayan pork stew was personally my favorite.  The sauce it came in had the perfect balance of spice and salt.
author: Matt J.

description: Amazing service and great food. The portions are small by design, however the quality of the dishes is extremely high. The bone marrow was amazingly savory and the pork entree was easily one of the best entrees I have had in the city outside of the top tier restaurants. Would definitely recommend to others.
author: Kyle J.

description:
My boyfriend and I have been to this place a few times and are always impressed! The only thing we wish is that they would have indicators on the menu items that are GF, veg, etc. 

Other than that last night I had the red baby kale salad(amazing) and the roasted heirloom squash dish - both full of flavor and so delicious. My fella got the hanger steak and was definitely the winner that night! Between the perfectly cooked steak, the chimichurri , and whatever that roasted chipotle-tomato sauce they used it was incredible. Will definitely come back!
author: Sonia M.

description: Good venue, excellent staff, so-so food, drink prices seem excessive for being non-liquor (they don't have a liquor license). We tried the chicken wigs (oily, not-spicy or popping with flavor, but a good portion for 2; was expecting some amazing flavors and all I got was acidity); the burger (simply had to flavor, not even the gooey toppings could save it; the "fries" were 4 giant potato wedges that didn't satisfy; it was like eating a baked potato, which is not what you want with your burger); and the cochinita (the sauce was salty and it didn't pack any heat or have any depth. And they don't know how to make tortillas: like Indian breads, a tortilla should puff up when cooking so it is not dense and raw in the middle; also it had jagged edges the first sign that it wasn't made correctly.) we had 2 drinks the mission and the Persephone's and they were tasty but for almost $12, literally were like juice. Either order beer or wine or stick to non-alcoholic, you'll get the same effect. Not impressed with the food or drink and won't be back.
author: Miriam L.

description: Really nice food! Really good balance of mild and spicy flavors. The blueberry crumble was amazing. Will go back again.
author: Seba L.

description:
Awesome new spot in The Mission to get homey food with a nice eclectic style, yet still refined. The food really is simply delicious! Having shared several things on the menu, it's hard to pick a fave, but I'd have to say that the fried Chicken Sammies, Chicken Liver Mousse , the Halibut and the Lamb Sandwich we're definitely the crowd faves. And dessert..  YUM!!! Great place for meeting up with friends or just grabbing a drink, or even a nice date spot. 
I've already have a dinner date planned at Myriad in the near future. ;)
author: Em R.

description: Delicious, seriously tasty food. The service was even better. Very warm, with opinions (I really appreciate that) and opportunity to taste wines by the glass before choosing. The owner came out and talked with us in a very warm and casual manner before admitting she was the owner and officially welcoming us (I also really appreciate that).
author: Andi T.

description: The Market Salad was composed of sparkling fresh arugula, sweet English peas, chopped crunchy vegetables and dressed lightly.  The pork cheek pappardelle came in a hearty portion. The pasta itself was cooked to a perfect al dente. It was full of tender pork bites and brown beech mushrooms, which deepened the umami flavor, in an expertly reduced glossy rich sauce.  Wait staff was attentive, good natured and made menu suggestions.
author: Martin H.

description:
Absolutely delicious evening with 6 people.

Recommendations: 

 - Chicken Sammies: Astounding. Get two orders and enjoy the kick.

 - Market Salad: Super refreshing. The toasted pumpkin seeds are a nice touch.

 - Heirloom tomato and burrata: Simple, but great ingredients make this dish.

 - Bone marrow: wonderful smokey flavor
author: Michael D.

description: Simply a great place. Food, atmosphere, service. Ate here once based on Yelp reviews and was thoroughly impressed. Deviled eggs, olives, chips are great starters. Lamb sandwich was tops. Came back a 2nd time and was just as thoroughly pleased. This time had the salmon.
author: Christopher L.

description:
This place really lives up to its reviews.  Location is not ideal, but prices are about 20% less than new places in other sketchy parts of town.  

Food is all great!  The tomato soup may be overlooked by many visitors focused on typical gastro pub cuisine, but I strongly recommend you try it.  Fantastic!  Mini fried chicken sammies are also amazing.  I wish they'd open a sister-restaurant that sold them regular sized.  Bone marrow was god, albeit a very small portion.  Everything else I've had there is also solid.  And great beer and wine selections, all very moderately priced (e.g., $6 beer options).  Have not had a cocktail there.

Place is not too large and can get a bit loud.  If there are just two of you, I suggest the seating against the left wall in the right room.  It's probably the least loud.
author: mario k.

description:
4 with option to upgrade to 5 on a return visit

Roasted butternut squash soup: 4/5
Bone marrow: 4/5
Salmon: 4/5
Apple crisp: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Music: 4/5

Went there as my pick for my annual its-Super-Sunday-and-I-can-walk-into-any-damn-restaurant-I-please-except-Milennium-without-a-reservation-and-be-seated-immediately-for-dinner meal.

The butternut squash soup was fine.

The bone marrow was luscious. The only thing keeping it from being a 5 was that the toast was over-browned.

The salmon was cooked medium-well as requested, came with a piece of satisfyingly crispy skin, and worked well with the other ingredients. I savored every bite, cutting the salmon into tiny bites to allow for maximal surface coating with the sauce. I'm on the border between 4 and 5. I gave it a 4 because my mouth didn't have an orgasm, but I was very happy with it and took my time with it.

The apple crisp was heavenly.

Service was friendly but not overly so, and well performed. They volunteered that they normally did the salmon medium and followed my request for medium-well. They always checked if I was done before removing plates. Offered to comp me a salad - guess Super Bowl business was even less than expected - which I declined, wanting to leave room for dessert. No attitude that I wasn't ordering alcohol. When I asked about one of the artists on the random play they got the information for me and now I'm listening to the group at home.

Music at a medium volume and a well selected mix.

Just so you know, there's a 4% surcharge. That's okay because it is clearly marked on the menu, including their web menu. (I've downrated places and put them on my no-fly list for either leaving it off the menu or obscuring it with smaller type or other hard-to-read print. That is NOT the case here.) I think the prices with the surcharge added are fair.

I would definitely eat here again.
author: Charles B.

description: i went with a large group.  everything we ordered look and smelled delicious! i had the shrimp and grits dish! amazing.  i didn't know grits could be that creamy.  my friend ordered me the drink with the jalapenos, it  was made just right!  the staff was friendly and service was great!
author: Serenity A.

description: Food quality and presentation were excellent. Shrimp and Grits and Kale Sprouts were delicious. Large plates are a good size if you have an appetizer before. Everything was very tasty including the cocktails! Excellent service snd clean restroom. Only dis-advantage due to the size of the restaurant is the tight space between tables.
author: Joey O.

description:
Despite a very busy weekend in SF, we were able to get a reservation and our table was waiting when we arrived.

Our party enjoyed the deviled eggs, bone marrow, salted cod fritters, wedge salad, cheesy grits, halibut, burger and hanger steak.  All were very good with the bone marrow and cod fritters outstanding.  ...and the pot du creme was quite good, too.  It wasn't overly sweet as so many are.

Lastly, the service was outstanding.  A restaurant that knows the proper way to clear plates is after the last person is done eating, and then doing so in mere seconds.

We will be back.
author: Robert K.

description: We actually wanted to go to a restaurant across the road which was full and this was mean to be as Myriad was epic. Very laid back, New york style decor and chilled out ambience. We were a group of five and shared a mixture of starters and would recommend the devil eggs and fried chicken. For mains the burger is melt in the mouth amazing and the guys all head the pasta with pork cheeks which they raved about and are still talking about. Also don't forget to have a Caffé Torino cocktail to finish things off... the perfect iced coffee cocktail to top the evening off.
author: Nicola T.

description: Lamb burger is tasty. Pulled pork is a beyond filling with lots of sauce. Pazole needs more time to let the flavors develop.  Check out Myriad if you're looking for different type of eats.
author: Heather R.

description: This was my first brunch at Myriad with two friends; and again, the experience was delightful, delicious and d'wonderful! We started out with the most exquisite mouth-watering goat cheese & chive biscuits with local honey butter and home made preserves - each small biscuit was treasured and cherished - and we could have eaten dozens instead of the rest of our brunch - they were so good. At the same time, as this was the first time these friends had come with me to Myriad, I also ordered the farm toast with goat cheese, persimmons, etc - which my friends also found delicious. They tend to be rather critical, but each had the grass-fed beef burger, that they found absolutely delicious. I had the shakshuka - tunisian tomato poached eggs - which again, was so delicious, I craved even more. Then there usual wonderful desserts. Every meal here is a delight and a wonder! Thank you, Myriad!
author: Wolf B.

description: Very good! Hip and trendy with innovative twists on spices and pairing! We came to the mission district from our hotel in the union square area to get away from chains and experience something a little more authentic and we were very happy with our choice. The service was quick and helpful and the food was delicious!
author: Scott S.

description:
Entire experience was just okay.  

Food:  Pretty good.  We ordered several dishes.  Nothing was over-the-top memorable.  

Atmosphere:  Not very intimate.  The high ceilings and not great lighting make for a dark (not in a good way) experience.  The whole ambiance was off, but the space is a tough one.  Felt like they focus on food, but they need a better interior designer.

Value:  Mediocre.  Thought it was a bit pricey, even by SF standards.
author: Jag A.

description:
I don't understand SF's fascination with lines. I just cant do it.

Lately, when seeking out restaurants on yelp, my eyes immediately scan to the bottom on the home page: "New businesses in San Francisco"

I know what you're thinking, what a rebel I am.

Two things: a) I'm too lazy to search by food type and b) most new restaurants are too new to have a line.

Myriad Gastro Pub was instantly moved to the front of the line. Why? Because they took online reservations.

I made reservations for Sunday brunch, table for two. A simple task for most, but believe me when I say..... it gets messed up more than not (or I end of being one of "those people" in a hyped up line anyway). Oddly enough, I've walked past Myriad a handful of times but just having paid much attention to it nor have I ever wondered what it was.... Just assumed it would be another mission hot spot closed in a few months like the ramen place before it.

I was excited to dine in after I did a bit more research and read some reviews, it looked promising despite my hatred for the neighborhood.

We opted for small plates as we indulged in a heavy breakfast so we opted for:

1) Deviled eggs. GOOD. Not "wow" good, but good. I was expected more flair in the ingredients (as most "gastro pubs" do) but it just tasted like my mom's. Don't give me wrong....i like my mom's deviled eggs, but I wouldn't pay $2 each for them.
2) The cream cheese pop tart. This just straight up sparked my interest. I think it's been years since I've had a pop tart, and this one was a reminder why. It was a bit too sweet for my liking but it paired nicely with the cream cheese. You can never go wrong with sweet and savory (unless you're the jerkoffs at dr. teeth down the street.... But that's another story for another  day).
3) The watermelon salad: the winning dish of the brunch. Very cool, refreshing and tart. Had a nice kick of sea salt which put it a notch above great.
4) Fried Chicken Sammies. Good, but not great. The pickled veggies on top were a nice touch.... But for $8, I should've gotten another order of the watermelon. I did enjoy the pickled bell peppers on the side, so much so that I now want to make them at home.

What I appreciated most was our service. Our server was Ivy (at least that's what our ticket said, the jury is out). She was super friendly, but not annoyingly friendly. She was prompt, yet we didn't feel rushed. She gave recommendations, yet didn't slam the "deal of the day" down our throats. And she was just a nice breathe of fresh air for SF. We dine out, often, and my lady even had to pull her aside and tell her how fantastic she was.... So yeah, it was that good. Someone promote this girl.

I was weary of the neighborhood and the trendiness t hat I was expecting, but couldn't have asked for a better experience.
I was a tad bummed that I didn't get the opportunity to try the bone marrow or some of the dinner items... but that just means that I have to come back. for that, I am okay with.

Thanks myriad for the outstanding brunch experience and "Ivy" for being the cherry on top.
author: Ryan L.

description: Very good food. I had a veggie dish (there aren't many options so whichever one had the word vegetable in the title). I hope I have a chance to come back and eat it again in the future. It was a bit loud inside but overall good ambiance.
author: Marley W.

description: I've been passing Myriad for lo these many months on my daily walks.  Well, we finally managed to get there today for lunch on this rainy holiday.  I am pleased to report that we had a grand time.  The overall vibe is just my style:  service is attentive but not over  the top (by that I mean whenever we needed something, someone seemed to be available).  We started with deviled eggs -- among the best I've had.  My partner opted for the hamburger which he said was perfectly grilled.  And I loved that it is accompanied by five or six amazing fries cut, I think, from russet potatoes.....so much more preferable than a plate half covered with forgettable box fries.  I chose the lamb sandwich and that was equally remarkable.  Overcooked lamb is dreadful while underdone lamb is stringy.  I'm not sure how the chef prepares this lamb, but it was beautifully grilled with a hint of a charcoal finish.  The Mr. reports that his glass of rioja was more than acceptable and I discovered that Pilsner Urquell is even better in the can....who knew?  I suppose the highest compliment I can offer is that we will definitely return (soon) and we certainly hope that Myriad will be part of our neighborhood for many year to come.
author: Nigel P.

description: Lots of seating, nice atmosphere, friendly staff, and solid food. Not slammed for brunch like most places. An interesting and tasty selection of dishes.
author: Cole G.

description: Whoever is giving this place 4 and 5 stars must have no taste buds. The food was bland and, yes, it's not very expensive, but there are plenty of delicious inexpensive places in the mission. The deviled eggs were drowning in oil and tasted like a straight hard boiled egg. I also got the vegetarian entree made up of broccolini, butternut squash, and white beans. Again, zero flavor and undercooked beans. I actually asked for salt. My boyfriend got the lamb sandwich which he said was 'ok' and 'dry'. I always feel like people rate less expensive restaurants easier. Just because you have a happy hour and reasonable prices doesn't mean I'm giving you a pass. Not going back.
author: Bita A.

description:
Whaaaaaaatttt so good. Get the following:
Chicken Sammies
Farm toast
Butternut squash gratin 
Shrimp with grits
author: Angela L.

description: I enjoyed an excellent meal at Myriad. Wonderful service, delicious food, and a overall a great evening!
author: Chris B.

description:
So I'm a bit delayed in writing this review - about two weeks ago I visited Myriad for brunch, and then a couple of days later, for their happy hour/dinner.  And I will say this - both the food and service on both visits were FANTASTIC.  Bites included the deviled eggs (the sprinkling of flaked sea salt MAKES them), butternut squash soup (velvet yumminess), polenta/grits with squash, kale, and poached egg (very good - but made especially delicious with my addition of a little of their bourbon bacon maple syrup), chicken sammies (simply yum), and the cardamom-sugar donut holes.  No, they're not actually called donut holes on the brunch menu but their name slips my mind!  

The service - both in the restaurant and at the bar - is attentive without being invasive, and also seems genuine in terms of their interest in your enjoyment of the food, which is often missing in some restaurants.  Also, I feel that for the beautiful quality of the food, the pricing is quite good.

The only element of the experiences that seemed a bit odd was the music playing on both occasions.  It was sort of an old Motowny-type vibe.  Don't get me wrong - Motown is fabulous.  But for the contemporary food preparations (from a multitude of cultures) and the cool (but not hipstery) environment, it doesn't feel like the right fit.  Maybe something more adult alternative - the likes of Craft Spells, Of Monsters and Men, Chet Faker, Death Cab for Cutie....Or perhaps even R&B/Soul inspired but more current - Jill Scott, Miguel, Joss Stone... But who am I kidding - the music doesn't matter a ton with food this damn good.

Lastly, I'll be curious to see if this remains a 7 days a week joint.  I love going into a great place on a Monday or Tuesday night and always being able to find a seat at the bar for great bites of food.  But, it also makes me worry that a place like that may not be able to stick around for the long haul because of the costs involved.  I wouldn't be surprised if Myriad ends up being closed for those slower evenings; but maybe over the next couple of months the news will travel about this lovely neighborhood restaurant and they won't need to be :)
author: Lisa T.

description:
My friend Trish came to me 2 years ago with a crazy idea -- she was going to raise money on kickstarter, from investors, and from the Small Business Administration and open her own restaurant to serve terrific, personal food at reasonable prices.  And OMG she did it!   The food is absolutely delicious (try the farm toast, the pork, and that delicious butterscotch custard), the service is good, and the atmosphere is somehow sophisticated yet homey.  Congratulations, Trish.  You had a dream and powered it on through.  Talk about grit and determination.  Really wonderful.

When you go to Myriad -- be sure to say hi to Chef Trish.  And say that "brother George" sent you!
author: George B.

description:
Got a sneak preview, and right out of the gate Myriad is firing on all cylinders! 
Chef Tracey's experience at the helm of much larger places shines through here in the cozy Myriad space where she can really focus on all the details.
Our small party each had something different, and while everything was delicious, these were the rave fav's at our table:
Deviled Eggs - okay, everyone does them, but these are the bomb!
Farm Toast with fromage blanc and some earthy/sweet roasted plums
Jersey Wedge Salad - how they "smoke" Thousand Island dressing I have no idea, but this was all tangy goodness, with bacon of course!
Bone Marrow - nom, nom, nuff said.
Roasted Halibut with clams, guanciale and some crazy good broth - more bread please!
Pappardelle pasta with pork cheeks, kale, mushrooms and peas 

Had a few sides (how did we eat it all?) that were also great, but somehow you have to save room for dessert... Butter-with-Scotch pot de creme - butterscotch pudding all grown up!!! 
Apricot-Blueberry Crisp - summer in a bowl with a heaping of creme fraiche ice cream.

Knowing the menu will be seasonal means - gotta get back soon to have these favorites while they last! And can't wait to ry what comes next! Great beer and wine list to choose from - something to please very palate, including some cocktail concoctions that looked tasty but we didn't try, opting instead for some nice bubbly and wine pairings.

The signs over the kitchen and bar say it all... EAT.... DRINK!
author: Jimmy G.

description:
The food is an absolute delight at Myriad! I can't wait to go back again to soak up more of the warm atmosphere and eat my way around the world. Chef Trish's stunning menu has so much to offer. 

It's difficult to pick a favorite, but I can't say enough good things about yummy the lamb sandwich or the delectable halibut. Ok, homemade spiced potato chips dipped in the horseradish cream and the fried chicken sammies are scrumptious. The service we had for our table of 4 was stellar. 

The craft beers on tap, the affordable wines go so well with the globally inspired food 

Save room for dessert.  

Wow! Just wow!
author: Mary Beth M.

description: One of the only places my boyfriend and I could get a reservation on Friday, so there weren't super high expectations. We ordered a bunch of things to to share. Pretty much enjoyed everything. The chicken liver was probably my favorite. The bone marrow was tasty but the portion was shockingly stingy. The bone came with two pieces of toast but the bone only had enough marrow for each of us to have a small but. Pretty disappointing. Steak was really well cooked.
author: Laura G.

description: Love love everything about this place! Food, ambiance and service was awesome. We ordered all of the vegetarian dishes (weekday veg) and it was all delicious! Especially the squash bean dish. The slices of fried garlic were delectable. The beet drink called Crimson Fog was so good that I ordered a second. Can't wait to try their bunch and meat option dishes on the weekend!
author: Chauanh D.

description: Second time there, pappardelle was on point. My bf loved the 15oz steak special. Great service too.
author: E T.

description: Great dessert and decent wine list. The ambiance works so that you can speak to another person, and the lighting is low-- hence it makes a good place for a date. While I did not try the food, I'm convinced that it is worthy of checking out next time.
author: James T.

description:
Had an early dinner here before a party in the neighborhood on Saturday night. It was hot that day and still warm in the restaurant when we arrived at 6:30. The front windows were open so that helped cool things off. Our server apologized for the heat and told us about a special cocktail made with frozen watermelon. It sound refreshing but we didn't try it. 

I had a champagne cocktail and my date has something with whiskey. Both were fine, but nothing too exciting. My second drink was made with port and similar to sangria. This drink was delicious! I will get that one again. 

We each had the deviled egg. The crispy shallot was the best part. Otherwise, not much different from what we make at home. And, there was too much oil on it for me. I tried to wipe some of it off first and it was still too much oil. 

I ordered the salad with the pepitas and avocado. This salad was delicious. Nice mix of ingredients, not too heavy on the dressing and the avocado was perfectly ripe. Not too soft but just soft enough to be creamy.

The best (and most interesting) part of the meal was the butternut squash gratin. Slices of squash with onion, sage and two kinds of cheese. It comes out in a sizzling little skillet which you are warned is very hot and not to touch. Duh. So while I'm being very careful not to touch the skillet, I (stupidly) accidentally touch the handle with the side of my middle finger. That area where your finger connects to your hand that is rarely touched by anything. No tough skin, no callouses. WOW it hurt. I plunged my hand into my water glass, took a huge swig of my cocktail and tried not to yelp in pain. Our server brought me ice and offered to find burn medication. He was very gracious about my careless move. I was so focused on scooping out the gratin goodness I didn't even notice the handle. My burn hurt for a good 15 minutes and then it was just uncomfortable after that. It was all worth it. The gratin was that good. And, my date let me have most of the dish because he felt bad I'd burned myself. 

My date ordered the burger which he said was good and the fries were the best fries I've ever had. More like wedges sliced thick and fried so the edges are super crispy.

For dessert we had the ice cream sandwiches and the peach oat pecan crisp. Both were delicious.
author: S T.

description: Food was fantastic. David with the man bun was amazing as he entertained us with the menu and really just in general. Great place. Have to go back for dinner!
author: Johnq D.

description: Wonderful atmosphere, savory and delicious food, and very courteous staff. We came on a Friday night without reservations and the staff squeezed us in even though it was busy. We started with the deviled eggs, butternut squash soup, and chicken sammies. All of them were scrumptious especially the sammies! For the main course we shared the hanger steak with patatas bravas. The medium rare steak had the perfect blend of smokey crispy exterior with soft chewy interior, complemented well by the patatas. Will definitely come back here again :-)
author: Sandeep M.

description: We ate here last night for a birthday dinner, it was very cute! One thing I wish I would have paid attention to was that the "cocktails" listed on their menu are not real liquor cocktails, but drinks made with fortified alcohol so they are essentially wine cooler-type drinks. Still very good! The Mission Statement was refreshing and not too sweet. We got the shrimp and grits, which were amazing!
author: Rachel G.

description: AMAZING! !! Every single dish was delicious. We had a party of 5 and everyone loved all their selections from the chicken apps to the pork entrees to the chocolate cake and zeppola desserts! My new favorite place in SF!
author: Sue A.

description: What a great place to meet, this wonderful woman I have been dating wanted to take me out in the city ,and this place has quality and variety and services top-notch; love it !-)
author: Josh Y.

description: Went with a large group and had a great time! Nice, eclectic atmosphere. I would highly recommend.
author: Jim W.

description: Cool new restaurant with your choice of several small dishes. Enjoyed each one we ordered. Also a great environment and location in the Mission. Definitely check this place out!
author: Harris G.

description: Myriad Gastro Pub,a great eating experience! What a welcoming atmosphere, very rustic but comfy and understated. We started with a bottle of rose bubbles, paired with the salt-cod fritters-fried capers(yum!), the sammies( fried chicken sliders with a Mexican slaw, honey chipotle mayo) and spiced shrimp and grits! Just to start! The clams and Halibut we couldn't stop eating, but if you just want a burger, they know how to make it-brioche bun(another yum!)  Don't forget to order the piping hot fruit crisp. This menu is like revisiting my childhood. The service was great, attending to our needs but allowing us our space to talk and visit . This is the place you want in your neighborhood!
author: Sarah D.

description: This new Mission gem has great atmosphere, amazing food and top notch service - a fabulous addition to the neighborhood (without trying too hard). All the food was amazing - tried the deviled eggs, arugula salad, wedge salad, chicken sammies (!!), shrimp/grits, the DELICIOUS cochinita pibil and a nice bottle of vino. Portions were great for sharing and very satisfying. Our server was warm, knowledgeable and attentive - and Chef/Owner Trish stopped by at the end of the meal to visit like an old friend. Ok, she is an old friend but that doesn't make it untrue! Do yourself a favor and give Myriad a try.
author: Jonathan J.

description: I ordered the cochinta pibil, which was pretty tasty and came with some nice green chile tortillas, enough for four small tacos. The tap beer is expensive, but the service is excellent.
author: Maximillian M.

description: What a great new restaurant for SF!  I wanted to try a new place for a change and i was definitely not disappointed! I got the BLT soup (so good!) and the hanger steak...loved it!! The place is cozy and inviting. Will definitely return.
author: Marcia T.

description: I could drink their watermelon granita, prosecco slushies every day of my life! Terrific chicken liver mousse; pork cheek pappardelle to die for. Super friendly service and chef. Just excellent.
author: Jessica C.

description: Yummy! Came for dinner on Friday night and it was delish. Can't remember everything we ordered but enjoyed it all. Standouts were devilled eggs, farmers toast, chicken sammies, kale and fig salad... The chocolate cake for dessert was super rich and the cocktails were solid. Stuffed afterwards! Very attentive staff. Would recommend and return.
author: Lisette P.

description:
I wanted to like this place but the decent food was marred by the service and a couple of other things I'll mention below. 

We went for an early dinner before a show. The restaurant was essentially  empty so it was confusing as to why we were seated right next to a 20+ person very loud birthday party. We were clearly in their way and we felt weird being in the middle of this. It also meant ear-busting laughing and all the rest of what happens with a big group. 

About 15 mins into our meal someone decided it was, for some unknown reason, time to turn the lights down. Atmosphere? Not sure, but it meant we could no longer see what we were eating - dark, loud... Since when did restaurant dining need to mimic a nightclub?

Then trying to get the check so we could make our show on time... 15 mins later we gave up waiting and tracked the waiter down ourselves and paid at the exit. 

Honestly, can't remember the food itself as the overall experience was just frustrating.
author: Natasha C.

description: Excellent service, excellent food! Cannot wait to come back and try the rest of the items on the menu. We had the deviled eggs, farm toast, fried chicken sammies, roasted lamb sandwich, and the steak fries. Everything was amazing.
author: Meredith S.

description: Love Love love this great food, ambiance and great customer service in the Mission at the all new Myriad Gastro Pub. It just opened 2 weeks ago and we were lucky to make a reservation on line via yelp. Chef Trish brings it all with great appetizers to shared plates to main entrees and comes out to meet all the patrons too. Plus the specialty drinks were incredible and priced right with a great wine list too! I am definitely going back there with my 6 friends to enjoy this new hot place and great customer service Wesley gave us as the new manager. 10 Stars for Myriad Gastro Pub with easy street parking and right across the street from Lolinda on Mission & 22nd. WOW WOW WOW! Now Go enjoy!
author: Johnny D.

description: The entrance is a little confusing as there are 2 doors to the restaurant. Once seated the service was good but a little slow. We had ordered mostly small plates but also a larger dish, but our server hadn't put in the order for the larger dish until we'd finished our previous dishes. My server did bring a little wine to try while I ate my larger dish; that was definitely a plus. The prices are a little high but I wanted to check it out after reading a review about the place.
author: Rachel H.

description:
My husband and I live across the street from Myriad and it is our go-to place for fantastic food and amazing service.  We have gotten to know the chef and owner, Trish, over the course of our last few visits.  She comes out to say hi whenever we are in (which is often).
